caption: Aalborg petticoat with tasseled drawstrings, half silk and wool, 1840.
description: This Danish petticoat from Aalborg is made of fibers of half silk and wool, with silk stripes woven into woolen fabric. The Scandinavian people purposely wove some stripes in the warp fibers to make stripes on or near the hemline, thus spacing stripes to the average length needed near the hemline It is uncertain what dark color this apron is, but paler color was need for the stripes. The drawstring gathers the waistline to fit, with the excess hanging. There is no waistband
source: Aalborg Historical Museum, Item #13441.Given among other permitted Xeroxes of some items when Carma's research day was finished too soon.

caption: Abigail Leonora Snow Morely is seen here in a warm day dress of 1840s.
description: Leonora (1801-1872) wears petticoats underneath which cause minimal fullness over her knees. She has a needleworked collar on the high neck, as well as white cuffs against a medium toned color of dress wool.This ample skirt shows that she is well fixed for lovely clothing and all her needs. Her bodice shows a stiff corset around her rib cage, with fairly loose sleeves left from 1830s, but little caplets, trimmed in dark braid at the upper armseye. Likely there is more braid other places on the bodice if not seen in this image.  Her batiste white day-cap is well sewn with shirring down each side of her cheeks and seems to be anchored with wide black ribbons under the chin.She is not wearing gloves. A dark shadow obscures her left arm and shoulder.
source: Lds Church Archives.

caption: A black wool flannel petticoat is worn as a cloak over a poor Irish woman's head.
description: The cloak is tied on with a man's colorful woven "crios" belt to help manage it over her head for cold winds.
source: Anne O'Dowd, curator of the National Museum of Ireland

caption: Above-wrist glove of black childskin with very smooth, fine seams.
description: A glove reaches over the wrist to bracelet length. Minimal stitching is on the back of the glove.
source: Gloves in Carmas collection which she wore, herself , in the 1960s.

caption: The Adams family, parents and baby girl, a portrait taken at sudden death of their infant. 1840s
description: It was possible for a fairly wealthy couple to rush a child to a daguerreotypist if their baby died, in order to depict the precious one for remembrance. This little girl is wearing a horizontally striped dress with a small band around the waist. There is some unclear decoration of the front yoke. Black shoes fit over pulled up stockings. The sad young father wears his best business clothes of silk vest under M-cut lapels, with a black, silky, long, loosely-knotted tie and its jeweled stick-pin. His trousers are a paler dark shade as is the fashion. His hair is below the ears with a jawline beard. The mother is in a black silk dress for this daguerreotype of the mid-1840s. If a young woman were wealthy enough she already had mourning clothing in her trousseau at marriage. Her bodice is gathered from shoulder to center waist point, while her dainty, white lace, flat collar has a ribbon of ombre silk in center front. A textured black shawl hangs low on her arms. Her center-parted hair lies in ringlets in front of her ears, and her eyes are shadowed with weeping. Museums of Europe and America have displayed many little baby or toddler dresses that were treasured and never used on other child. If a young child had died within the first 18 months, parents could not bear to give away a small keepsake dress for boy or girl, and may even have framed it on a wall.
source: Many similar Daguerreotypes are found online at Daguerreotype of dead child. This portrait is at: https://www.flickr.com/photos/28085772@N06/2810353720

caption: A large, fancy knitted white wool shawl on an Irish woman (detail).
description: A photo taken in Galway County, on the west near the Atlantic coast of Ireland. This is Brigid Mkinerney Kelly More, in 1900, but her knitted designs have been used for more than a hundred years. They were all used in the 1800s and very probably long before.
source: Ann O'Dowd, FIND TITLE (National Museum of Ireland, Dublin,1990; Photography Valerie Dowling, CitrionPress.

caption: An Amana colony of German-Americans whose members shared all things in common. 1855
description: The Amana Colonies are a group of seven village settlements of German Pietists in Iowa. Calling themselves the Ebenezer Society or the Community of True Inspiration, these Germans first settled in New York state near Buffalo. In order to live out their beliefs in more isolated surroundings they moved west to east-central Iowa in 1855. They lived a communal life until the mid-1930s. Women wear black aprons, long sleeves, and white or black head scarves.
source: Photograph from "The Amana Colonies," printed by the Amana Society in 1974, now registered with National Park Service. (Text condensed from Wikipedia.)

caption: Amy Hyde, with a very serious expression, wears a typical, center-gathered 1840s bodice with a voluminous skirt and petticoats. ca.: 1840s.
description: The dress in this formal portrait might be colored, or shades of black, grey and white. (Carma has often seen that purples and white were a basic color scheme.) This glossy silk dress uses elongated paisley shapes which are simplified into the intriguing design of two darker colors with white. Like many dresses of this time, a shirred bodice gathers diagonally from a shoulder blade seam in back, forward into a solid shirring at the center waistline. The gathering appears to have been smocked at the waist. Amy wears a small lace collar and a line of white on her cuffs. The narrow sleeves are bias cut and fit easily around the bend of arms. Her 1840s, sheer day cap has ribbon bows on the sides, and untied, curling, silk ribbons dangling down. Amy was the daughter of John Hyde, a minister near Rochester, NY,
source: Photo portrait in the Eastman International Museum of Photography, Rochester New York. Photo by Carma. Free use.

caption: An aging Welsh woman doggedly wore her old mourning clothing until she died.
description: In the 1800s, this strong old woman had inherited her magnificent hat from an ancestor of the 1700s. Beneath it is a black, sheer, ruffled lawn "bonnet" (day-cap) with silk ribbon ties This garb was still worn from her lifetime of mourning for many close and honored relatives' deaths. Her skirt was heavy grey wool with tucks in the hem that shorten it in old age. Her slightly lighter grey wool shawl hangs over a black jacket. Hand-woven decor on the shawl is a very pale grey stripe with a red stripe above it. One shoe of fine leather is barely seen. A gloved hand holds her cane, and the other holds a mourning handkerchief in her lap. This image was possibly taken in a photographer's indoor studio arranged by her well-to-do family members. Her history tells that she was so industrious she took governance over a very large farm when her husband and some of her 10 sons died one after the other of unexpected causes. She ran the whole business in charge of her last sons and other workers for all her years until her death in old age.
source: Photo Donated to Carma by, Bliss Brimley Hansen author of Thomas Job.

caption: An English carter in a smock and a derby hat
description: Smocks were the most commonly worn clothing of the working class throughout Europe, Britain and America. The upper one is the coat smock front with 10 buttons. There is little embroidery on the collar. Shoulder added embroidered rain guards and there are buttoned flap pockets. Extremely dense smocking covers both front and back of the smock. A close-up of the gathers and two button cuffs is very interesting because smocking stitches do not continue all around the sleeve cuff.
source: Gertrude Jekyll, Old English Household Life: Some Account of Cottage Objects and Country Folk (New York, HarperCollins Distribution Services; Revised edition, September 1975).

caption: An English charwoman tries on her mistress's bonnet while about her daily labors.
description: The maid is delighted to secretly see herself as a person of a higher class.
source: Engraved for Godey's Ladys' Book 1848 Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine.(Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840.) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections.

caption: An English chimney sweep with better-dressed boys.
description: No boys want to be touched by a chimney sweep because they would be instantly blackened by him.
source: Art sketch in ink and wash

caption: An Icelandic Folk Costume front and back.
description: The bodice and skirt are high quality black velvet and have decors of sterling silver with flowers. Silver chain lacing with hooks fastens the bodice front, and double silver stitching outlines back seams. The silver theme continues on the belt. The apron is a plaid of all the shades of black to blue to silver of the ocean's colors. The black velvet cap has a huge long tassel ("skotufa") on one side that hangs well past the shoulder. Even the tassel has some silver jewelry at the top. If a woman were in mourning, she would wear a plain black apron. A white linen blouse with tiny buttons in front is fitted at the neckline, while large sleeves are gathered into wrist bands. She wears black stockings and shoes.
source: Model Nancy Jean Oliver wears her aunt's fine sewing of this black Icelandic costume. Her aunt, Betty Robinson, made many trips to Iceland from Spanish Fork, Utah, to find the proper silver jewelry to be sewn on the dress, as well as to show relatives their origins. Photos by Carma.

caption: An Irish colleen with two shawls, an apron, and a green plaid skirt.
description: An Irish colleen with two shawls, an apron, and a green plaid skirt.A smaller brown jacquard shawl hugs her neck, while  a large, brown, red and green wrapping shawl provides warmth. She wears a few  warm petticoats. In cold Ireland she needed black wool stockings and heavy leather shoes, if she were so fortunate (as many women hardly ever had shoes in their  whole lives in the Irish countryside. Her shirt and apron are white linen.
source: Costume composed and sewn by Carma. Modeled in fashion shows by Nancy Kensingerin her long braided hair. Photo by Brett Crandall.

caption: An Irish peat cutter walking home.
description: She is wearing a striped shawl over a woolen short-gown just to her upper hips, and has no bonnet or shoes. Her thick skirt has broad checkered stripes in dark green and black. She carries strips of peat in a handmade network of hemp to use for selling peat as fuel, It makes small home fires on a designated floor space of sand in the center of a room. There is a hole for smoke to escape at the peak of the roof above. And peat is also burned in little stoves for weavers in some bigger homes.
source: Back view of a woman drawn by Carma, after a front view in Lister, Costumes of Everyday Life, 1972.

caption: An Irish Wheel
description: Irish wheel in the dooryard to create spools for setting up a loom for weaving.
source: Royal S.

caption: Ann Elizabeth (Betsy) Webster wears black mourning jewelry. 1860s
description: For a period of mourning for the loss of her husband, Francis Webster, Ann wears a carved, jet broach, possibly made of less expensive black glass. It is pinned on a white, loosely knotted tie. Over a black dress, her shawl is lighter.
source: Detail of a portrait from Special collections at Sherrat library, Southern Utah University, Cedar City, Utah. Permission of Paula Mitchell.

caption: An old British grandmother in Sunday bonnet is seated outside to read her Bible in the good light of day.
description: In her Sunday bonnet and white apron, with a black shawl over her black skirt, this woman keeps her Sabbath. The ruching of white folded lawn around her face is very close and sets off a quality black bonnet with a little black ribbon bow on the very top.
source: Gertrude Jekyll, Old English Household Life: Some Account of Cottage Objects and Country Folk (New York, HarperCollins Distribution Services; Revised edition ,September 1975).

caption: An old Icelandic folk costume.
description: This costume on a mannequin in the Icelandic Folk Museum of Reykjavik, shows a jacketof teal-blue wool with leather insertions over the shoulder, and black fur collar and cuffs. The edgings down the front are silver embroidery on wool, with a multi-colored silk scarf tucked into the neck of a black wool bodice. In her silver-studded belt is a silver ceremonial household knife and sheath. The skirt is long, midnight blue with white embroidery above the hem, anda leather binding on the hem edge of the skirt. Her shoes are black leather. This model is not wearing the typicalIcelandic cap.
source: Photo by Betty Robinson at the National Icelandic Museum, Reykjavik, Iceland.

caption: An old Irish woman in a woolen cloak.
description: This woman is leaving a fine home with a paneled door, and has thrown her cloak over her shoulders with its hood covering her head. There is lining in the cloak, but we cannot determine its nature. This cloak was not cut in a circle, but was made with a strong yoke on which a long piece of wool was tightly gathered. Tiny buttons on the right side of the hood will close the hood under the chin. Her hand indicates a long-sleeved dress underneath. This is probably a woman of some means to have such fine outerwear. The cloak is likely red,dark browns,or green, the most popular colors for cloaks.
source: Irish book. CARMA CHECK BYU

caption: A Pembrokeshire Welsh girl is putting on separate yellow and red striped sleeves to cover her arms for warmth, and for added color.
description: Welsh women's common dresses were often added to with a sections of detached forearms. Contrasting fabrics were fashionable. (See black/white drawings of 0ther colored styles.)
source: Original in the National Gallery of Wales, modified by Ken Etheridge in Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century.

caption: A poor Welsh fisherman carries his coracle and one paddle to the water on his back. A coracle is very light-weight, woven of wickerwork and covered with a watertight substance.
description: This painting shows a Coracle man from the many waterways around the south coast of Wales. The artist,George Delamott, shows his worn-out wool pants, patched and re-patched over his knees, where he kneels in his coracle. One flap of a pocket is shown over his left hip. He wears a white shirt, a red vest and a very short blue jacket. His shoes are probably water-damaged leather. Without doubt he wears wool socks. He has short hair for convenience.
source: Watercolor by George Delamott, 1818. Nat'l Library of Wales. Permission

caption: A progressive Gwent girl reading out of a language book, educating herself to be able to teach others.
description: On her head is a warm red and yellow cap edged in white lace. The brim of her black top hat is curled upward on each side. Blue and White striped wool makes a front apron where she has abandoned her knitting of grey wool stockings. Her light blue scarf circles her neck over a chemise, and tucks into her skirt. The cheerful grass green skirt has red and white flowers, beneath which she would be wearing white or striped wool petticoats. A dark, rose-colored, square shawl with white borders folds into a triangle to lie from elbow to elbow. The chair is lightweight, as most of the Welsh people were of small-boned or dainty stature.
source: Original in the National Gallery of Wales, modified by Ken Etheridge in Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century.

caption: Modern reproduction of an apron from Blekinge Sweden, detail of fine appliqu.
description: Appliqu of sheer batiste faces the bottom edge of a novelty striped voile fabric. Above the complicated hand applique is another plain band of batiste to decorate and give more "body" to the apron.
source: Apron made by Carma for her own costume of Blekinge. The pattern indicates the broken ice on the seashore of southern Sweden near the city of Karlskrona, where the ancestors of Carmas husband originated.

caption: Apron of Blekinge, Sweden, has a band of decor at the hem made of sheer novelty cotton with applique of slightly heavier white muslin fabric.
description: The design on the hem represents the abundance of broken ice on the southern coast of Sweden in all the colder months of the year. This apron was worn over a bright red wool skirt and other linen and wool petticoats for the Bleckinge folk costume.
source: Lanshemslojdensarkiv, in 'BleckingeDractenby Ingrid Dahlin

caption: Arnold Abegg age 29 in a handlebar mustache and very neat curly hair.
description: The Abeggs were handsome, wealthy peoplein Switzerland and could afford finely tailored clothing. There is, around Arnold's neck a gold chain to hold his expensive pocket watch.   The LDS missionaries found the Abegg family in Zurich, When first hearing them, Arnold seriously went to pray in a private place--he was told by a voice that what the missionaries were teaching was completely true. All his Abegg family converted in 1854 and knew Karl G. Maeser's wealthy family in Germany. Arnold devoted himself to study prodigiously, learning many subjects, especially engineering. After 1875 the Abeggs were in USA and Arnold was a whirlwind in the Utah Territory, mining and contracting large projects, a flour mill and a District School. At age 40 a beautiful girl caught his eye and although she was 16, he married Louisa Matilda Elizabeth Haag with both their mothers present with them in the Logan Temple ceremony. Louisa and all their child outlived her husband. Eventually she remarried for just the last 16 years of her life in Colonia Juarez, Mexico, a Mormon Colony of believers. His descendents in Colonia Juarez, Mexico, were very handsome people when Carma met them at her age of 10, on a trip with her father for the LDS Church.
source: Internet biography of Arnold Abegg: http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=30112501

caption: A Scottish child wearing "His Father's Breeks" (Breeches).
description: An extremely poor fisherman's son has clothes too large for him as his daily wear. This Calotype shows he is barefoot with one suspender to hold up his father's trousers, rolled far up at the hems. A tam o'shanter of heavy wool with a center pom-pom is a slight protection from the cold winds Worn about 1845.
source: David Bruce, SunPictures,the Hill-Adamson Calotypes (London and New York, New York Graphic Society Ltd. , 1973)  RSC says public domain,

caption: A Scottish fisher lassie has a tucked up skirt and a creel of fish to sell.
description: In A Scottish fisher lassie has a tucked up skirt and a creel of fish to sell.The white striped apron is tucked into her yellow and black wide-striped skirt. She has also pinned the outer skirt up on each side over padded dark grey petticoats. The lassie wants to keep her beautiful, bright-colored outer skirt clean, as her darker petticoat underneath would sometimes be splattered with water. On her back is a heavy creel layered with straw and fresh fish she has purchased from the fishermen, and will now carry into town to sell them as her daily business. When this outfit was modeled with the creel in Carma's fashion shows, it always contained 20 lbs. of fresh fish packed on straw as the model walked through the audience. Carma's line of narration was, "If it doesn't smell like history, it isn't history!" A leather strap holds the creel across the girl's strong shoulders. Around long hair she has tied a white fringed neck shawl which helps keep her warm in the sea winds. She wears thick white wool stockings and clogs of wood because constant sea water would destroy leather soles. The model is Mairi McCloud.
source: This costume was made by Carma after designs in an early 1845 Calotype from Scotland.

caption: A striped cotton Danish day cap with wide ties to make a bow under the chin.
description: Around the face edge of the cap is a tiny, white zigzag trim in front. The wide front pieces usually just hanging were cut on the bias.A drawstring tie in the back adjusts the size of the cap for the head, younger or older.
source: Xerox given to Carma when her cameras were breaking down in the AalborgHistorical Museum, Jutland, Denmark

caption: A Swansea Shrimp man from the Southern coast of Wales.
description: This poor man is patched all over his outer clothes. He stands on the beach, barefoot, with his scooper-net for finding shrimp. His breeches are permanently cut short for his daily wading. A straw hat with a dark hatband over uncut hair keeps his head warm or dry in rain.
source: Watercolor by George Delamott, 1818 National Library of Wales.

caption: Authentic Swedish Folk Clothing on a dance group in modern Sweden celebrating Mid-Summer's Eve --when it never gets dark.
description: On May 21st, at the summer solstice, Scandinavians all celebrate with green wreaths on a Maypole. They dance singly or in couples around the pole, with an excellent buffet of food afterwards. This is a re-creation of very ancient religious practices of the Solstices. The women wear woolen skirts, bright colored aprons indicating different provinces and white linen shirts. They have various provincial designs for their caps. Bodices and sashes are often decorated in gold lace. As much silver jewelry as can be afforded is worn on both women's and men's shirts. If possible, all men wear pale leather or light colored breeches with knee stockings and woven garters. Men usually wear checkered or novelty striped long vests of elegant hand-woven wools with many silver buttons. The older the costume, the longer the vest, going back into the 1700s. At necklines of their shirts, men like to wear silver clasps for closure jewelry.
source: Photo found on the Internet under Sweden midsummers Eve.

caption: A well-dressed bride in Iceland.
description: An Icelandic wedding ensemble on a live model shows Icelands gorgeous embroidery in shades of gold around her black wool skirt. Smaller embroidery decorates her bodice. A round broach holds the sides of the bodice together over a white linen blouse. Her belt is made of many cast and engraved square links, and hangs with as many jewlry squares as she can afford, according to her wealth.   On her head is a shining gold crown surrounding the base of a tall, veil-covered structure -- a traditional form made of white papier mache~shaped in a large, forward-angled hook. The veil extends past her shoulders, exposing both her crown and long titian hair. All this metal appears to be gold for this particular bride. Much other jewelry for Icelandic costumes is of silver.  Shoes are always black leather, usually with black stockings.
source: Photo by Betty Robinson in Iceland.

caption: A Welsh family carting goods to market, while other villagers walk as usual.
description: The woman on the left is bringing woven fabrics in a head-basket to sell at market. A woman in the cart has a figured neckerchief over a betgwn and skirt, with a striped apron. The woman driving the cart beside her old father wears an exceedingly tall hat left from the 1700s. Both men on cart or horse wear lower-crowned straw hats.
source: Bliss J. Brimley, Book of Thomas Job, (American Bible Society, 1987)

caption: A Welsh girl from Cambria wears a local folk costume from the city of Gwent.
description: A Welsh girl's common red hair is topped with the traditional black hat, and she wears her flowered shawl over a dress of vertically striped orange, black and blue. A pink and red checked apron holds the little shawl points in place. Gray and black booties have tiny buttons on the inside of the ankles, and black elbow length gloves are fingerless.
source: Original in the National Gallery of Wales, modified by Ken Etheridge in Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century.

caption: A Welsh oyster woman with her mule and baskets of oysters.
description: From Llangwm, Pembrokeshire an oyster woman brings in baskets of fresh oysters from the coast to villages nearby, packed on the donkey with an extra creel on the woman's back. Her apron is made of two widths of checkered wool, and a bold plaid shawl is tucked into the apron band. A daycap with ruffles wrapped around the chin is warm in cold winds below her stovepipe hat. A sturdy, long-sleeved bed gown may extend to the hipline outside the skirt. Black wool stockings and black shoes walk many miles each day.
source: Gertrude Jekyll, Old English Household Life: Some Account of Cottage Objects and Country Folk (New York, Harper Collins Distribution Services; Revised edition ,September 1975).

caption: A wool" walking "wheel for spinning wool is brought outside to the dooryard inScottish good weather
description: A Scotswoman works outside in the sunshine rather than in her shadowy, tiny home built of rocks and thatch. The aged woman wears a wool plaid shawl over a woolen bodice. Her underclothing would be a linen chemise and petticoats of linen and wool over her under drawers. A large linen apron protects her skirts from some dirt, foods and soot. She is white-haired and almost bald, but has a cozy, padded, close- fitting bonnet to cover her head and ears in most weather.
source: T. Edgar Lyon Jr., John Lyon: the Life of a Pioneer Poet, (Provo, UT, Religious Studies Center, Brigham Young University, 1989) To see a walking wheel in action, go online to YouTube: Walking Wheel for Spinning.

caption: Crowns of baby caps, hand-made by cottage embroiderers from the countryside around Glasgow, Scotland, and sent to world markets for finishing.
description: These crowns were embroidered on fine muslin, and first marketed to home sewers in Glasgow. Soon they were shipped to markets throughout Europe and America.
source: Photo by Carma in the Manchester, England area at the Costume Galleries at Rusholm.

caption: Lace and eyelet embroidered baby blessing dress with center front opening and a conservative length.
description: This work of art was made by an expectant mother who intended it to be used by all her future child. In the LDS Church the baby is given a name and a blessing rather than a "christening," as babies are considered pure, and wholly incapable of any sins until years older.
source: Elaborate embroideries suggested by other baby gowns are illustrated on a very conservative length of gown. Drawn by Carma

caption: Baby dress enlarged for a toddler.
description: This baby dress shows how early Americans economized by enlarging a baby dress by adding length to the hem and sleeves, as well as triangular side sections with underarm gussets, sewing it from baby size to toddler size. They used closely matching woven fabric in fine white cotton. Some of the seam joinings may have then had some embroidery for pretty effects, especially in obvious cuffs and hem extension.
source: The enlarged original dress was diagrammed and modified by Carma with dots to identify the added parts of fabric. From American Folk Art Museum: The Ralph Esmerian Gift, American Radiance, Tanya Heinrich ed. (Seattle, Marquand Books Inc., 2001)

caption: Baby David Hyrum in Emma Smith's arms,1846, after his fathers martyrdom.
description: The baby asleep on Emma Smith's lap is a photograph of a daguerreotype, later made into a colored oil painting by the baby grown up, David, Hyrum himself. Here David is about 18 months old when he wore a dark blue dress with gold buttons. Emma's clothing was mourning black. With blue fabric similar to Joseph Smith's Nauvoo legion coat, Emma could have made her little boy a dress with military buttons as a memorial of his father. David H. became an excellent oil painter, and did this scene with the blue dress.
source: Photo given to Carma by the Community of Christ Church, Independence Missouri.

caption: A baby undershirt to be worn under a baby corset
description: On right, the sheer linen and dainty lace and embroidered insertion at the shoulder of the corset cover, placed on a photocopy machine to see the details of fern embroidery on mull linen, and then very small lace decoration around arms eyes. Fern embroidered trimming insertions and one-half inch knitted linen lace. The overlap in front is here closed with a straight pin just to give proportions. The center portions flip forward at the neckline, down over a small corset, to keep the growing baby's bones good and straight. That was the strange belief of some parents in the 1700s to 1800s. Right: shows the shoulders of the corset cover. This white sheer linen cambric item was made in Cincinnati, anywhere between 1790-1850. .This delicate shirt was fully restored with 140 denier fine lace-making thread by Carma
source: From the antiques collection of Winifred Bowers of New York City. Item is now in the Brigham Young University Fine Arts Historic Clothing Collection. Small shirt drawn by Carma.

caption: Back view of 1800s work shirt with gathered center. Made of beige and white striped cotton/linen.
description: This shirt is made mostly of plain rectangles cut to fit one half of the man's waistline measurement, or the full width of his shoulders plus 4 inches. Two large rectangles are the front or back, sewn together, or could be made from folding a long piece of fabric at shoulders. The shoulders have a horizontal slit for a neck opening, which is then cut slightly down in front in a shallow U to fit the forward thrust of the neck. This slit extends from the center point of the front and back out toward the top of the shoulder. The entire slit should be 4 inches larger than the size of the man's neck. This results in a larger neckline where the shirt is gathered in the center back, and on the fronts to each side of the placket opening. This allows for expansion of the chest. This slit (once gathered in) is covered on the inside with all seams tucked inside of a long, triangular gusset, called a "strap." Note that the back neckline is gathered only in a center spray, not all the way across the back, as so many supposedly 1800s shirts are incorrectly made today with a back yoke.  On the center front is an 8 inch long vertical slit opening of this pullover shirt. The slit is faced with a rectangle of fabric, making about 2 inches facing on each side and a bit more at the bottom of the slit. It is wise to sew this slit facing with a machine and with tiny-size stitches on the bottom 2 inches of the slit. After pressing, add judicious tiny stitching with finer thread, by hand, to secure the extremely small seam allowance on this bottom 2 inches. The entire shirt can look worn out and won't wash well if the center front facing gets torn or ragged.   On a work shirt of wool, which was often red, blue or possibly brown dull-striped fabric, an actual collar was only added at the neckline half the time. Usually, only a collar band was sewn on to secure the neck for a great many work shirts.
source: Striped shirt made for model Ron Reed with photo by Wayne Keyes

caption: Farmers in America and European countries used short barn coats for daily chores thoughout the year. They were made of heavy common tweed or another natural color of undyed wool.
description: A barn coat was usually a free-swinging, short jacket, just for hurridly slipping on by a male member of the family to go out and tend animals in a barn. Such coats were rarely lined, but often had patch pockets for a handkerchief and odds and ends. Or it could have bound pockets secured with the same wool, as seen here. In center back at the hem was extra room afforded by a box pleat or a stitched pleat over a slit. Worn by both boys and men, usually made from scrap wool sewn and even patched together at home.
source: Seen in museums and illustrations of farmers' wear in many countries. Drawn by Carma.

caption: Woman's beaded handbag or reticule.
description: Woman's beaded handbag or reticule. CDFig. ??This small purse was made by Hilda Rollins Ford, who, herself, made soft, child shoes.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum, #97, donated by a Provo member of DUP

caption: Betty Robinson's extended family in celebration costumes for "Icelandic Days" in Spanish Fork, Utah, ca. 2007.
description: Young parents and two sons are carefully dressed for the celebration in Utah. Note the wonderful Edwardian wallpaper in the old home Preserved in Spanich Fork.
source: Photo by Betty Robinson

caption: Black color shawl.
description: Detail of a black crocheted wool shawl with almost 4 inches of fringe.
source: From the Thomas Job trunk in Santaquin, Utah.

caption: A black fan from 1850s forward is made of bamboo sticks and Chinese-printed paper, and is used for mourning
description: a fan with bamboo sticks has black paper with Sang Dynasty Chinese characters printed on it. The Chinese exported such fans all over the world into different cultures. This middle-class fan was found with other mourning accessories which came from Norwegians in Spanish Fork Utah.
source: Items purchased at Cat's Cradle Antiques in downtown Provo, Utah. Given by Carma to the BYU Fine Arts Historic Clothing Collection

caption: Blekinge, Swedenpadded headgear to be worn beneath a linen headscarf.
description: A wide linen band crosses the hairline at the top of the face and is tied over the ears and behind the neck. A roll of padding is attached on the band at the top of the head. When a large linen headscarf is tightly pinned over the head, the scarf will lie flat at the hairline but immediately rise up and over the padding to emphasize the white linen shape around a lovely Swedish face.
source: Made by Carma after samples found in Sweden

caption: A chubby teen's blonde hair fashion in a French style with ringlets for 1848.
description: Hair with three ringlets on each side of the face. The center top hair is taken en masse straight back from the face and fastened with a decorative comb standing up in the back hair, which is fashioned into a pretty knot. She wears a tiny silk scarf around her neck tied with lace edges.
source: Drawing by Carma after the magazine "Le Moniteur de la Mode" 1848.

caption: Blue wool hunting shirt. Mid-1820s- 1880
description: Medium-thick flannel shirt made roomy and large enough to cover and other underwear shirts or even a sweater. Hunting was year round but especially done in the fall for winter supplies of food and furs to use.
source: Carma's young friend Glen was the model many years ago. Photo by Carma

caption: Bodice of cream wool barege dress, inside and outside.
description: This sheer wool dress is lined with cheap calico turned inside-out. The calico print does not show through. A front buttoning bodice would be helpful while nursing a baby. The lining on the front bodice is buttoned together separately from the outside fabric. The waistline has a set-in belt of the same sheer fabric (See total dress, above.)

caption: Baby bodice on a long Christening dress, with dense and elegant broiderie anglaise.
description: Baby robe bodice made in Canada. If for a baby girl, it would have the skirt waistline attached straight across the front, but for a boy the embroidered point is shown outside the waistband. This V-shaped piece could be made with a special baby in mind by the mother or relative, or could sometimes be purchased as "cottage made" by women who worked at home and sold through merchants. The rest of the dress fabric could be purchased separately for the completion of the baby robe. There would be edgings of hand embroidery or lace on sleeves and ruffled hemlines. In this illustration it appears that long lines of the embroidery are made to continue from the waistband all the way down the front of the long skirt to join more decors at the hemline.
source: Detail of photo from book about Fred G. Williams? But not the Nancy Clement's book

caption: a one-piece bodice enhancer.
description: This piece of added fullness in the bust line was thought necessary for some females who were not naturally endowed with "large enough" breasts. This enhancer could be tucked into the t op of a corset, even a meager corset, and the woman or girl would feel much more beautiful out in society.
source: C. Willett, and Phillis Cunnington, History Of Underclothes (Mineola, New York, Dover Publications Inc. 1951) Republished 1992.

caption: Bonnet made in France with a scalloped plain fabric brim and a snood for the rest of the head and hair.
description: A soft silky fabric is draped starting at the lower cheeks and tying on the flat bow on top the bonnet. There are rose buds under the brim. The same fabric makes a fairly long bavolet across the back neckline, with the same fabric in another color used for ties on the bonnet under the chin.
source: Drawn by Carma after a French fashion image in Le Moniteur de la Mode1861.

caption: Boots from Manchester, England,1840s
description: Medium high boots with uppers possibly of strong kangaroo skin and low heels. At the top front edge there is inserted a narrow panel of black elastic to make them easier to pull on. Top quality workmanship.
source: Jane Tozer and Sarah Leavitt, Fabric of Society ( Powys, Wales: Laura Ashley, 1993).

caption: Boy in a multiple buttoned coat. 1840
description: This pre-adolescent is dressed in fashionable coat with multiple rows of buttons with a narrow pants and a snug belt.
source: Drawn by Carma from an unknown source.

caption: Boy's flat shoes with silk ribbon ties, ca.: 1830s to 1880s
description: An amalgamation of common forms of dress shoes for boys. Could be any color of leather depending on the economic status of the boy. Such shoes could also be bought by the poor at second-hand clothes fairs and tied with heavy string.
source: Drawn by Carma; free use.

caption: Boy's trousers in heavy striped cotton above white stockings and best slip-on shoes. Ca.:1830s-1850s
description: In grey with cream stripes for summer, these heavy, cotton, broadfall trousers were easily washable, and could be smoothed out without ironing. Note: Costumers must remember there was no pressed line down center front or back of the legs of trousers until the beginning of the 1900s.Trousers were worn by youths with various colored cotton or silk knit stockings, and for special, dressy occasions, were likely worn with black square-toed flat shoes, as seen here.
source: Pattern cut and sewn by Carma for her fashion shows and teaching. Free use.

caption: Breeches illustration with close-up of knee plackets, ca:1700s to Mid-1800
description: These particular breeches show a narrow front opening with two buttons, called a "French fall." This is not a "broadfall" that extends widely from side to side. The French Fall is narrow. There is also a placket at the knees with 4 buttons to close the breech knee over high stockings. Breeches could be made of woven wool, of wool densely machine knitted, of leather, or of lined silk or heavy work cloth.
source: Watercolor and photo by Carma

caption: Breeches illustration with close-up of knee plackets, 1700s to Mid-1800.
description: These particular breeches show a narrow front opening with two buttons, called a "French fall." This is not a "broadfall" that extends widely from side to side. The French Fall is narrow. There is also a placket at the knees with 4 buttons to close the breech knee over high stockings. Breeches could be made of woven wool, of wool densely machine knitted, of leather, or of lined silk or heavy work cloth.
source: Watercolor and photo by Carma

caption: Brigham Young near the time of LDS migrations west, ca; mid-1840s.
description: An engraving of a daguerreotype of Brigham Young in earlier years when he was more slender, had thick hair and a clean-shaven face. Under his dark coat is a figured or moir vest, and a shirt with pleated front. His patterned kerchief tie is in a square knot with short tails, and the shirt collar folds over it. His hair, parted on the side, curves under below the collar line. Brigham, The Mormon Moses led the LDS people across plains and mountains to the Utah Territory, where they hoped to enjoy peace from eastern persecutions. He gained weight and grew a long beard during the last dozen years of his life. Young died quickly and in pain at 77 with symptoms of a ruptured appendix.
source: LDS Archives. Free use. Also online.

caption: British church bell ringer for hours of services,  or in a Village Center for time of day or night. 1800s
description: In a very long coat with a stand up collar, the bell-ringer wore his cardboard-based silk hat. He had to wear leather gloves to pull on the enormous ropes made of tow-linen shreds and horsehair for long strength.
source: Compton's Pictured Encyclopedia vol. 2, 1926.

caption: An average city worker on a British street, 1835
description: He wears an aged, double-breasted tail coat in navy, a high-buttoned vest of gold lightweight wool with standing collar (a design soon to disappear in the 1840s), peacock silk tie knotted with very little wrapping, and a stout black pilot cap. Dark gray stockings are with strong leather shoes that reach just to the anklebone. The height of these shoes dates from the later 1830s. He holds keys to many doors on the street where he oversees the safety of businesses.
source: Historical and reproduced clothing for Robert Putt in film, Little Dorrit. Photo by Snowdon.

caption: British country women washing outside in tubs.
description: Once a week the women get together in their oldest clothes, with their outer skirts tucked up into their waistbands. They assemble all their laundry tubs and baskets with benches. Some are scrubbing with hands on a washboard, and other clothes are lying over a stool or rack. The woman far left is carrying something in her basket, possibly food for their long day's work, and she has her baby's laundry in her apron. Neckerchiefs are on two women. Small day caps are different styles over their hair. All sleeves are rolled up for washing in soapsuds.
source: Public Domain

caption: British farmers reaping their harvest, 1800--1860s
description: Whole families of farm workers turned out with their reaping hooks to cut the "corn" (wheat, barley and oats). Men wielded scythes while women and child gathered up and tied the stooks, or piled up the hay. Here a man is served a glass of refreshment. Some country men still wore breeches and stockings into the 1830s and 1840s. A small felt hat is all this "cottager" can afford.
source: W. H. Pyne, artist in "Microcosm,"

caption: The Bottle,' 1847
description: A drunk British father wears a soiled frockcoat,  trying to jam a bottle into his pocket.  Worried mother pleading for money carries a barefoot toddler in her shawl. The shoeless daughter has only a headscarf and neckerchief over her short sleeved bedgown. Inside the shop, a little girl buys a bottle of gin to take home to her alcoholic parent.
source: George Cruikshank, detail from The Bottle , shows the scarcity of food or other family necessities for when the father drinks up his income.

caption: British fishermen hauling their nets while off their western coasts. 1830s
description: Men in thick, knitted sweaters over much underwear have tight, wool felt berets. One plain woolen cap has a front brim.
source: Carol Belanger Grafton, Ed., Trades and Occupations: A Pictorial Archive from Early Sources (Dover Pictorial Archive) Paperback  August 1, 1990

caption: British Innkeeper with table full of guests,  First half of 1800s.
description: This innkeeper with his neatly  cut hair supervises a table full of his guests.  Because he is in charge, he wears a small bouquet  pinned on the front of his vest. This practice was  much seen in Britain. His shirt has narrow sleeves,  and the vest collar seems to be turned up around  his neck as he goes indoors and out. His short  clothes (breeches) have tied garters at the knees  to hold up his stockings.  He is ever dutiful to fill the needs of the ladies and  gentlemen. The guests sit at table with hats on, as  some do not stay overnight. The man on the close end has low gaiters over his ankles.
source: William Johnstone White, edited by Pamela Clabborn, Working Class Costume from Sketches of Characters, (London, Dedalus Press for Victoria and Albert Museum, by Costume Society, c. o. Department of Textiles. 1977. )

caption: British women MOVE washing clothes by stamping bare feet in wooden tubs. Drawing? Scotch Washing by Isaac Cruikshank.
description: From the internet article under Scotch Washing? "Two buxom young women, lifting their petticoats high, trample laundry in tubs placed beside a Highland stream. Another brings a basket of linens to be washed, while a girl in the background spreads linen on the grass to dry. " It was always taking a chance for linen finishers to spread out bed sheets or linen yardage on the grasses over a day and a night to bleach and dry. Thieves could easily make off with many months of family members' weaving in a single moment in the dark.
source: Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division, Washington, D. C. 20540 USA

caption: British wool shearers with large clippers, 1700s-1800s
description: Some workers have a simple, square apron tied at the waist, and others do not. But all breeches have proper ties hanging untied at the knees because they are hardly concerned about grooming. All the men have indifferent haircuts, but are clean-shaven. Their sleeves are rolled up because of the heat of the mills in summer. Minimal vests cover their shirts, and two wear loose ties at their necks.
source: Chris Aspin, The Woolen Industry, booklet#81). Shire Publications Ltd., Cromwell House, Church St., Princes Risborough, Aylesbury, Bucks, HP179AJ, UK.

caption: Broadfall trousers including both straight hems and strapped-under variation on the hem. 1800-1860
description: Broadfall trousers were seldom very form-fitting in the seat. Most men wanted room to sit comfortably in spite of looking a little baggy in back, even in best clothing. The strapped-under hem has black elastic under the shoe.
source: Watercolor illustrations by Carma.

caption: A carpetbag made of real carpet is useful for many purposes, ca.: 1848.
description: This rather shabby man keeps his business or tools, or a few purchases in his bag, which is literally made of a piece of worn carpet. Other accessories include a walking stick and gaiters worn over his calves. His clothing is too dark and indistinct for description, but his top hat seems rather jaunty.
source: Reproduced authentic English clothing for Daniel Doyce from Little Dorrit. Permission from Lord Snowdon, photographer. Free use.

caption: Cartridge pleating: outside and inside views.
description: Gathered fabric of most clothing in the 1800s is done in "cartridge" or "organ pipe" pleating for smooth regularity of the fabric. The upper image shows the even outer surface.  The lower image shows the construction on the inside of the pleating. Four inches of skirt fabric is folded down inside and by hand run with carefully measured gather-stitches, simple in-and-out, leaving long the ends of the strong thread. Three rows of thread allows for final adjustment. The ends are secured after sufficient gathers are made to fit onto a bodice waistline edge. This is a couturier method so beautiful in cotton or wool, and seen still today all over Britain, Europe, and in Russian or Slavic folk clothing. Skirt stitching shows occasional flaws of hand gathering. The gathered skirt is stitched to the bodice edge with an attractive separation of self-piping--never contrasting piping colors.
source: Betty J. Mills, Calico Chronical, Texas Women and their Fashions ( Lubbock, Texas, Texas Tech Press 1985.) 0s --1915s.84

caption: Catherine is a daughter of Phillipe Cardon from the Piedmont in Italy. Her dress is adorned with a plaid neck bow and buttons.
description: Catherine wears a textured wool dress with small ball-buttons down the front. It seems to be decorated across the bodice in the square design of a yoke with dark silk trim. She has a tiny white collar, probably lace. A plaid ribbon bow under her chin is centered by a round brooch. The dropped-shoulder sleeves are typically narrower in the 1850s. As an older sister, Catherine has a serious look. Her center part separates hair pulled straight to the sides before falling in long waves down her back. Her earrings are two-part droplets.
source: Genevieve Porter Johnson and Edna Cardon Taylor,compilers, Cardons! Descendents of Philippe Cardon and Marthe Marie Tourn 1799-1886, (Provo, Utah, Stevenson's Genealogy Center, 1990) Permission from Larry C. Porter.

caption: Catholic priest calls on Swedish women waiting for confessional in early 1800s.
description: The priest is calling women in for their turn to confess sins and receive penance. Above his long buttoned black robe is a white ruff around his neck. He wears a black skullcap. A mother on the left is holding her baby. A quilted blanket covers her black skirt. Others have plaid shawls. The woman with a red scarf wears a fancy white apron.
source: : Loose picture from a long, lost postcard from Carma's collection

caption: Charles Coulson Rich is painted in a black, double-breasted suit of late 1830s.
description: In a color portrait, Rich wears a high-buttoned, black vest with a shawl collar. The coat lapels are gently rolled, with large, 1 inch buttons, and follow the 1930s fashion of padding the upper coat to slope from neck to shoulder. He probably has some gathering in the top of the sleeves to make them stand up a bit. His tie is an every-day, black silk in a horizontal bow with pointed ends. His shirt shows pleats as part of the center front yoke of his pull-over, white linen shirt. A button-on collar stands up, stiff with starch, and wraps from the front to the back, where it becomes narrow, only  inch high, allowing buttons and buttonholes. His shirt cuffs properly show at the end of his coat sleeves. Charles' hair has ample sideburns but nothing on the chin or jaw-line. With gentle waves, it comes down only to the top of his collar in back. Rich was an early and devout follower of Joseph Smith, Jr., and holds an open Book of Mormon.
source: Oil-painting in the Salt Lake City DUP museum, (artist unknown).

caption: Chemise for a high necked outer dress
description: A chemise was the basic slip worn beneath all other clothes except pantalettes. A Corset was worn over the chemise, as was a dress, laced vest or blouse. A chemise could be any length from mid-thigh to calf, and could be decorated with lace, tucks, and insets. It was sometimes highly decorated and gathered around the neck to make a pretty ruffle that showed above the neckline of a dress. The style above was cut from two pieces of fabric, front and back, and was wide enough not to need set-in sleeves. A chemise could be worn for day or night, and could have long sleeves in a cold climate.
source: Drawn by Carma from many European and American collections

caption: Women's under-drawers or pantalettes open front to back, with a tie waistline.
description: From front to back of waistband, the drawers were slit open. This was for convenience while the upper body was bound with corsets and other layers. Female menses were handled with cloth pads and bindings against the body.
source: Carmas drawing suggested by: Louis A. Godey, from Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840.) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections.

caption: Chemisette with collar. Very fancy lace cuffs on engageants, ca.: 1820s to 1860s.
description: A high-necked chemisette fits into a wide-necked dress for warmth or modesty. Such an accessory can be extremely plain for common use, or highly decorated with lace and tucks for the wealthy. Chemisettes often had tapes tied around the waistline to hold them in place under the dress. They gave a filled-in effect. Engageants rise from wrists only to the elbow, where they are held up by drawstrings, or possibly elastic after 1820. They are worn inside bell-shaped sleeves. These engageants have elaborate cuffs with rows of horizontal lace bordered with fluted edging lace.
source: Uncertain, but may be from: Pat Ernshaw, Identification of Lace (Shire Publications; 2nd edition, June 1, 1980). Image is old enough to be public domain.

caption: English clog: leather on a wooden sole for a child to wear while working in a mill. Used also in American mills. Very few working child had stockings. Early-1800S
description: A wooden sole has leather top, which is nailed to the wood with round brads. A strap is closed over the top of the foot with a button. The front and heel of the wooden sole have a metal edging underneath to slow down wear on the wooden base. child worked as many as 12 to 14 hours a day in the English mills, their clogs rattling loudly on the cobblestone streets walking to work in the dark mornings and home again in the dark. Some never saw the light of day, six days a week. Child labor conditions were worst of all in English Mills.
source: Drawn by Carma after Eunice Wilson, A History of Shoe Fashion, (New York, Theater Arts Books, 1969).

caption: Chin line beard and facial hair on unknown man. 1830s to 1860s.
description: It was not uncommon for men to wear a chinline beard, with or without a mustache. Fashion plates from England often show chinline beards with separate mustaches on men of wealth. In the countryside of the US, heavier chinline beards were common because shaving was more inconvenient. This man wears a double-breasted coat buttoned higher than usual with wide lapels and a velvet collar.
source: Online under beards 1840: www.pinterest.comricardoasamoustachesbeards-friendslp=true

caption: Cloaks of Caernarvon, Wales.
description: The left cloak has its hood lying flat while the hooded cloak on the center woman is pulled up over a tall hat. According to the books comments, the jacket on right is grey and dark blue stripes with tied-on sleeves over her forearms. On her white cap is a tall-crowned straw hat.
source: National Library of Wales, in Ken Etheridge, Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century. (Swansea, Wales? Cristopher Davies, Ltd. , 1977).

caption: : a coat-smock on a gardener is longer and has toggle buttons.
description: In a color image of a coat-smock on a gardener, CD Fig ?, a gray linen coat smock differs from regular smocks because it comes well past his knees over old wool pants. It also has wooden toggle buttons all the way down the front. Beautiful yellow embroidery and smocking stitches embellish the front and sleeves. His shirt is light colored with a gray and yellow flowered neckerchief. Outdoor workmen often dressed in rough shoes and worn-out top hats, as this one does.
source: Carma and Nancy B. Egbert sewed the body of the garment. Pieces were first embroidered by Carma and smocked by Elizabeth Peterson

caption: White and bright colored wool plaid shawl.
description: During the 1850s, Thomas Jobs wife, Elizabeth, was given this shawl produced in Wales from finest wool . Thomas Job went back and forth between Wales and cities in Utah during his life. in the Mmid-1800s. He was a talented school teacher, but also a necromancer and was ordered out of Salt Lake City by Brigham Young many times., who felt strongly that numerology and star-casting of fortunes was diabolical. Yet there were in Salt Lake and its environs enough paying customers for all sorts of horoscopes. Job always claimed he was a Mormon, and his first wife, Hannah, left him when she could no longer live around his spiritual divinations, which she saw were very powerful in controlling other people. Thomas then married another sweet woman named Elizabeth and for many more years went on teaching difficult school subjects in private schools, with winter sessions, in Utah and Idaho. Advancing in religious truth was what the greater body of Mormons wanted, yet supported academics in schools from the early days of Utah.
source: This Shawl was photographed by Carma when recording items from the Thomas Job Trunk from the , 1850s-60s.

caption: Combs made from animal horn for various uses in hair care.
description: The larger combs stand up in the back of the head to be seen above a bob of hair. The top comb has inset mother-of-pearl designs. The tiny top (right) comb is a louse comb, of which we have identical ones today to find and take out lice and nits from infested hair. The comb just below, if small enough, is the type used to comb mustaches, probably made of hardwood, as in ancient Egypt.   In America, combs were first made in Massachusetts, early-whittled out of horn, then polished by sand, and finally polished with a paste made of wood ashes. Women usually did this work themselves before the American Revolution. When the black population of the southern states saw brass combs they wanted to believe the peddlers line for making sales, that "brass tended to make curly hair straighter."
source: J.R. Dolan, The Yankee Peddlers of Early America, New York (Bramhall House, 1964

caption: Peasant woman's neckerchief
description: a peasant woman's neckerchief with a red border and a red and gray flowered center shows designs brought from European folk art. The center print is essentially red with black and white designs on it. It was used on men or women as a neckerchief. In pioneer travel, it was sometimes tied around the head to keep a woman's hair out of smoke from a bonfire while cooking on the open plains.
source: From Carmas collection; Photo by Carma

caption: Corduroy trouser back has an antiquated yoke at waistline showing a cinch buckle to adjust trousers.
description: Trousers often had a vent at the high waistline in back, as in CD Fig? Over the vent, a cinch with a buckle could be used to make the waistline tighter or looser. The seat of the trousers needed to be full for movement, and is somewhat gathered onto an antiquated back yoke. Such a yoke is a last remnant of the breech designs of the 1700s.
source: Sewn and photo by Carma

caption: Detail of a country fair in Scotland.
description: This painting of an outdoor country fair in Scotland shows common folk of great houses, soldiers and animals having a weekend time of buying, selling and socializing. Many of the young women have a red ribbon around their white day caps. Toward the right under the tent is a woman in a large white collar and a dark green bonnet. There are some black felt floppy hats on men. A Soldier wears a shiny helmet, and behind him a man in a brown felt hat is lifting a white canvas. A soldier drummer wears white breeches and high black boots. Above the drum is a white haired man in a black cap holding his stick aloft, and there is awoman in a red shawl with a golden scarf wrapped around her head. A white ox and a brown cow are crowded by dogs and child. On the lower right is a woman holding the shoulders of a young man telling him something importantto keep under his hat. At the left is a gentleman in a tan box coat with a pocket with flaps and a walking stick under his arm, putting green apples into a mesh bag. A woman wearing white is also adding apples. On right is a woman in a red shawl, while a man behind her in a drab brown coat is seated on a black horse. In the very center is a shadowy man in a large black hat, High in an upper window three youngsters peer out on the scene over a red tiled roof.
source: This detail is from the painting Pitlassie Fair by David Wilkiein the National Gallery of Scotland. enquiries@nationalgalleries.org See online Permission Ask RSC if online pix are free. Lorie sent email to ask whom to inquire of about printing this painting. Sept 26, 2017.

caption: Apron of cross-bared fine muslin with knitted lace insert and edging.
description: This old apron was rescued and brought to Carma to see if she could restore it. After careful cleaning and restoration of some snags in the knitted lace insertion and the crocheted fagot edge, it turned out to be a valuable remnant from earlier settlers in Utah Valley during 1849-1860.
source: It came as a muddy piece of cloth from an old farmhouse being torn down. Photo by Carma.

caption: A ''dandy" puts himself forth in his very best style, ca. 1830s into 40s.
description: This man is a dandy because of his especially contrived hair and clothing. His pomaded hair is parted smoothly in the middle, with sides of obviously designed puffs of curls. It is possible this man had a valet who dressed his side hair with a stove-heated curling iron. He has a bit of a British jaw-line beard and a small mustache. To direct more attention to his face and hair, he covers his shirt and collar with an all-over-designed cravat scarf. His shoulders are padded to slope up to his neck, and his coat lapels are M-cut.
source: From suggestions in many other costume books, this was drawn by Carma; free use.

caption: Daniel and Mary Snyder Wood in a Daguerreotype taken in 1840, Sydenham, Canada.
description: Daniel wears a high-buttoned vest of shiny silk, which is a bit out of fashion. His tie is white silk, wrapped once or twice around his neck with a small knot in front. A watch chain or cord drapes from his upper vest pocket to a lower position. He holds a book, likely a new edition of the Book of Mormon printed in England. His hairline is a deep widows peak on his forehead with longer, turned-under hair over his ears, and sideburns down to his collar. Mary's day cap is definitely an 1840 style with ruching on each side of the face and including flower bud decorations. All her hair is in a bun inside the cap. Her dress is covered by a capelet with a light-colored, ruffled edging. A bright plaid ribbon is tied around at her neck and spreads out to show it off. Over her arms is a pale shawl, perhaps a color to match part of the ribbon, These light colors are certainly not all white. This couple followed the Church through all the moves and persecutions of the Saints in America.
source: Gordon B. Hinckley, James Henry Moyle, (Salt Lake City, Deseret Book, 1951). Courtesy of Moyle family.

caption: 1840 Danish artists in the inn La Gensola, studying in Italy, meet in an Italian tavern for food and drink. Sculptor BertelThorvaldsen (sculpted "The Christus"in white Italian marble) is the man on right, with white hair.
description: Man in center front is in white shirt, separate crossed suspenders and high-waisted trouser back. Most men wear white for summer, some withdarker vest or light weight coat. A tall straw hat hangs on the wall.
source: Painting by Ditlev Conrad Blunck, Fredriksborg Museum of Art, Copenhagen, Denmark. Cant find museum with this name.This artist was associated with Denmark's Golden Age of Art--the first half of the 1800s.

caption: Danish boy's leather breeches, probably black or brown.
description: These leather breeches have five button openings at the knees and are lined with strong linen. Beneath the knee band is a tab protecting the legs or stockings from the buttons or possible buckles (difficult to see).  The front waistband opens with two vertical small buttons. The squarish flap center front opens the breeches in a "narrow fall, which is faced with matching leather. Two buttons on the waistband seam hold the fall in place. It is possible that open side seams provide vertical access to inside pockets of muslin on both sides of the breeches.
source: This is a photocopy given to Carma just at museum closing: time to give her help on display item #424 x 28. No more time to photograph in the Aalborg Museum in Hjorring, Jutland, Denmark.

caption: Danish cleaning woman from Upplans, 1860.
description: Although this is the New Rococo period this woman still wears her very old clothing, and expects nothing better. She still busies herself with a long handled scrubbing brush for floors in someone elses home.
source: Upplandsmuseet Fyristorg 2 753 10 Uppsala Tel: 018-169100  info@upplandsmuseet.se Lorie sent an email asking for name and email of person who gives permissions. Dec 6, 16

caption: Danish flannel petticoat.
description: Petticoat of grey flannel with scalloped hemline embroidered with red yarn so it would not fray .It would have been worn with other cotton or linen petticoats.
source: Purchased in a trunk full of ancestral clothing from a partly Danish Christiansen family 50 years ago in Orem, Utah.

caption: Danish Folk Costume from Amager.
description: The skirt of the woman from the island of Amager off the coast of Copenhagen was made of a springy, strong goat wool of red with tiny white vertical stripes of linen. A band of black is five inches above the hem with red linen tape on top of that for enhancement. It is hand-woven and influenced somewhat by Amager's earlier population of Dutch settlers from the Netherlands. Inside the hemline there is a facing of heavy silk which may have come from an older vest of geometric brocade. The bottom edge is bound in bias tape of black wool. Beneath the skirt was worn a heavy, gray wool flannel petticoat sewn to a brown linen waistband (seen elsewhere). The white blouse under the sleeved bodice is ruffled at neck and long cuffs, with black ribbon bows. The shawl which came with it (not shown) was a plain black, self-fringed shawl. The narrow front apron surrounded by black lace is for dress-up occasions but is blown over by strong breezes. This girl is wearing wood and leather clogs. The model is Grace Callister.
source: Photo by Carma.

caption: A man in Danish folk wear from the Island of Amager, just off the mainland of the capital city.
description: Since there had been, in the 1700s, an influx of Hollanders into the island, the common folk clothing acquired extra blousy pants like these worn over his soft black boots. His jacket is hip-length with decorative light orange braid on the edge and on his cuffs, with more decorative blue embroidered buttonholes, down the left side. On his right side is a row of round small silver buttons, which seem to be identical to the two rows of buttons on his matching vest. On the closing edge of the vest is more orange and light green striped fabric. No white shirt is seen but around his neck is a silk scarf tied in a square knot, in matching orange, light green and white. His hat is a shiny black topper.
source: By artist F. C. Lund, from a collection of outsized prints at the National Museum of art in Copenhagen. Published by Bilchers Forlag, Kolding, Denmark. Carma received print as a gift from the Museum.

caption: Danish girl's jacket of silk brocade with black cotton lining throughout.
description: For warmth, this black silk brocade jacket with bright flowers was worn over a folk costume bodice with much silver jewelry.
source: Photocopy from the files of the Aalborg Historical Museum, #13398 , Jutland, Denmark.

caption: A novelty cotton makes a Danish girl's cap with a minimal flowered print.
description: Over the crown of the head is a section of separate cloth which is gathered top and bottom, to shape the cap and make it cover her hair in back if she pulls it up on each side.There is a narrow cord around neck edge, as well as the drawstring inback to make it larger or smaller.
source: Xerox copy of image given to Carma from the Danish Historical Museum in Aalborg. It has a fine collection of historic clothing as well as beautifully painted furniture and sleighs.

caption: Danish immigrant couple who lived in Utah "under the Horseshoe Mountain."
description: Danish Woman in Spring City, Utah, wears a plaid cotton apron over her dress of small checks. She is spruced up with white on her cuffs and some sort of white decor at her neckline bedsides the day-cap she wears. Hanging on the side of her neckline is a strip of leather?with some decoration on it of totally unexplainable nature. Perhaps it was an award for her cooking or vegetables or flowers. No one who has seen this image can explain it at all. But she looks happy and proud of something! And her white-bearded husband looks very dignified in his face, though he is lounging in his best clothes with a double-breasted vest, and cares little where his legs go--if he could only hasten this photo business! There is a casually knotted sort of tie at his neck. They lived in an early town settled way south of Provo in a fertile valley. In the range above the settlement is the last remains of a volcano with only part of the interesting curve left of the volcano's cone---called by the locals "Horseshoe Mountain."
source: Danish Woman in Spring City, Utah, wears a plaid cotton apron over her dress of small checks. She is spruced up with white on her cuffs and some sort of white decor at her neckline bedsides the day-cap she wears. Hanging on the side of her neckline is a strip of leather?with some decoration on it of totally unexplainable nature. Perhaps it was an award for her cooking or vegetables or flowers. No one who has seen this image can explain it at all. But she looks happy and proud of something! And her white-bearded husband looks very dignified in his face, though he is lounging in his best clothes with a double-breasted vest, and cares little where his legs go--if he could only hasten this photo business! There is a casually knotted sort of tie at his neck. They lived in an early town settled way south of Provo in a fertile valley. In the range above the settlement is the last remains of a volcano with only part of the interesting curve left of the volcano's cone---called by the locals "Horseshoe Mountain."

caption: Danish Karen Pedersdatter and Son, fromBargeso, 1854, probably a large country estate.
description: The mother is wearing a very fashionable silk dress. Shoulder caps have horizontally pleated ribbons up to the shoulder seams. The bodice shows hints of ornate beading, difficult to see beneath the bow of her day cap. There is a tuck around the skirt above the full hemline. A lighter colored silk apron lies over her skirt. Karensday cap is adorned with an elegant amount of gauzy lace around Her face and tied with a ribbon bow so large it obscures most of her bodice. A fine, ruched lace collar lies around the neck. She wears no gloves and carries an important paper, as if she reading a letter from a loved one to her son.  Her twelve-year old blonde boy wears a fine double-breasted dress coat, with buttons and button holes the same on each side of the center opening. His vest is lighter-colored silk with five small buttons below a minimal tie.The trousers are dark, but likely not the same color as the coat, and also made of wool. We know he is from wealth, because his shoes remain shined while traveling in a clean conveyance through dirty streets or dusty country roads.
source: Margit Egdal, Frie Bonder-- A History of Farmers on North Fyn Island of Denmark, Library and Local Historic Archives for Otterup Kommune. Written in Danish. Permission unobtainable.

caption: Danish Mourning Cap from Alborg, outside and lining.
description: This mourning cap from, Denmark is white figured on black cotton lined with thin red red wool & padding. The lining with its black patch is padded with carded wool to add warmth. It might have had a band of narrow lace around the face and ribbons under the chin.
source: Carma purchased some costume pieces from a Danish family from Aalborg. In assessing other Danish designs in books, it is much more likely that this cap came originally from the little island of Armach, just outside of Copenhagen, and not from Alborg.

caption: Danish peasants in farm garb against neatly finished d wooden walls of their home, probably stained red.
description: This farmer in his casual felt hat wears a very large leather apron over his white shirt, jacket and dark work trousers. He either worked around cattle or shoed horses, and needed protection for his clothing. His wife, seated, has a dark wool skirt under her large white linen apron, and wears a warm and colorful [usually red] ]striped jacket over her blouse and chemise., Her relative or friend stands near in dark colored wool clothing which could be rich brown or blue, and her skirt hem is bound in a bright color of strong tape. She also wears a large white linen apron and a kerchief over her head and it is happy colors in some little figures. The wifes shoes are light toned, meaning they were carved of wood.
source: Hakan Liby(sp?), Kladerna = Common Clothing. find Scandia box in garage.

caption: Danish petticoat double waist band, two kinds of cotton: inner band with button holes for bodice of underwear.
description: This completely hand sewn grey flannel petticoat has evidence on the waistband that a linen or cotton under bodice was buttoned on to it for convenience in washing out perspiration regularly.( But the grey flannel would not have been washed that often, ) With only hearth heat in most common Danish homes, people had to dress comfortably in many layers.Note inner seam edges were scissor-snipped to make less raveling "pinked" edges without modern pinking shears.
source: Bought and photographed by Carma with a Danish skirt of red stripes from a pioneers descendant family in Utah.

caption: Danish petticoat in fine quality blue and white striped wool with elaborate pleating on hemline.
description: Roerslev, large island of West Fyn, on the North coast at the Local history archives, Denmark, displayed in the year 2000. There are double lines of stitching to secure these perfectly even pleats for a petticoat hemline. The petticoat is gathered onto a waistband with simple shirring, as seen at top right if image.
source: Photo by Carma.

caption: Danish costume, teen at her wall bed in her home.
description: This girl is in a Danish bedroom which has a short bed built into the wall with drapes to give privacy when many people used the same room. She wears a warm black jacket with her red wool skirt which has a hint of white linen stripe. She covers it with a serviceable heavy apron, hand woven with vertical stripes of black, beige, green, blue and white. Her white linen cap has lovely embroidered ruffles on each side of her cheeks. Around her neck is a silky scarf, a Scandinavian favorite, this one in black, blues, green and red. The cuffs of a white blouse are showing at her wrists. Black stockings are above silver buckles on her black shoes. She is folding clothing on the bed. Above her head is an elegantly block printed valance.
source: Found on the Internet under Danish folk costume.

caption: Danish woman dipping candles.
description: This woman wears a sturdy cotton-linen washable apron with black, white and red stripes, worn over a red wool skirt. Her sweater is red with a green bodice over it. A black printed or embroidered neck shawl is tucked into the bodice. Her daycap is white, tied under her chin with a white ribbon. Over it is a heavy striped cap with various colors of embroidery.
source: Danish costume from the Internet: candle dipper.

caption: Danish wooden shoes made of very hard wood with extra support rectangle before the arch that leads into a higher heel than usually seen on wooden shoes.
description: Ricky Svendsen of Provo, Utah went to Denmark to see where his ancestors came from. He talked to a farmer wearing these shoes well-carved and finished. They were such a handsome pair Ricky purchased them right off the good Danes feet and left him standing in is heavy wool sox. He was informed that the extra wooden extensions on the soles of the shoes were good for getting through muddy fields. The story of their acquisition was told to Carma as she was photographing the shoes.
source: Danish farmers shoes in the 1900s following age-old designs. Photo by Carma

caption: Dan Jones preaches to Welsh crowd.
description: Jones has jumped onto the stone hitching post [wall] in the town plaza of Swansea, Wales. It made a good pulpit from which to stand and preach from his Welsh translation of the Book of Mormon. His companion stands nearby in the mud holding Dan's top hat. In the right front corner is a blackened coal miner calling his friend to come and listen. He wears a filthy cap with a brim, and carries a bell to alert others of meal times. The wealthy lady on his right wears a deep brimmed, blue silk bonnet. In the left front corner, two ministers heckle Jones, both painted from daguerreotypes of the actualministers who did the heckling.. An oyster-woman in center has full creels on her donkey and her own back, which will be sold that day. She wears warm woolen clothing, a white daycap and a tall black hat for Welshwomen of that period. In the left background is another wealthy woman in light blue. Other towns-women wear red shawls, checkered wool aprons, and their own tall hats over daycaps. A little old farmer in center background has a cane, a low-crowned brown hat, and wears yellow, knee high, buttoned gaiters with his tweedy breeches. The above-ground engine works in the upper right operate the coal mine lifts. On the hillside above them stand the remains of the ancient Welsh castle in Swansea.
source: Painting by renowned Clarke Kelly Price, with accurate costume direction by Carma. Photo by Joseph R. Putman. This large painting hangs in the Provo, Utah Missionary Training Center, who accepted the gift from the Provo Sons of Utah Pioneers, who engaged and paid the artist.

caption: Danish David and Mette Marie Madsen Damsted wedding picture 1880.
description: David is wearing a warm, double-breasted coat over a wool vest with a shawl collar. His pants are country wide-legged, and shoes slightly square toed. Mette Marie has her hair braided in a crown, and wears a beautiful broach on a silk ribbon at her neckline. The bodice of the wool dress is extremely long and formfitting with many buttons, which was the style in the later 1800s. She has pleated cuffs with small frills at the wrists. Her wool skirt is pulled up in a bustle in the back. This couple joined the LDS Church in the 1850s, and were influential on the north shores of Fyn, in Denmark. They eventually moved to Ephraim, Utah, which became a center of Scandinavian converts.
source: Margit Egdal, David og Mette Marie iGudsegetland,(Odense, Denmark, Landbohistorisk Selskab, 2000) Email: kak@adr.dk

caption: Decorated Swedish headscarf over a red cloth cap
description: From the Swedish provinc e of Skane, here are white cotton, embroidered cut work and lace-edged, seen on a dark background. A small black ribbon makes a back bow secure.
source: Nordiska Museet, in Dahlin, Norway. Photo by Carma

caption: Decorative band around the hem of a Danish skirt, highlighted with red wool braid.
description: Danish goat hair and linen red skirtwith black wool hem band.
source: From the island of Amach, by the great city of Copenhagen. In Carma's collection Free

caption: Back of embroidered green folk costume cap from Denmark.
description: The back of the cap seen here is heavily embroidered with multi-colors and gold thread on green silk, with white lace showing around the front edge (unseen here). This cap has very narrow ribbon ties.
source: From a paper photocopy of a museum photo, given Carma in the Aalborg Historical Museum, item #8490 Dronninglund, Hjorring, Denmark. when the staff felt sorry for Carma photographing costumes, but they had to close the museum on time.

caption: Diagram of Welsh betgwn (bed gown).
description: This farm girls woolen betgwn only worn during the day's work, has set-in sleeves fitted to the elbow, ending in black silk cuffs.
