A broad neckline displays the chemise that often had decorative needlework. Center back waistline has folded-inward pleats and double buttons. The fabric is dark red flannel with black vertical stripes, shoulder to hemline and on skirt and bodice. Sleeves have horizontal stripes. White calico lines the gown throughout.
source: Ken Etheridge, Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century (Swansea, Wales, Christopher Davies Ltd. 1990)

caption: A tourist display house in Olmerdug, Denmark .A mannequin in a folk costume sits by a large table and bench with other farmhouse items.
description: A tourist display house in Olmerdug, Denmark shows a mannequin in a folk costume sitting by a large table and bench with other farmhouse items.  trunk of blankets and fabrics in the foreground. There are tablecloths,and possibly some clothing in the large trunk. Striped fabrics, from lightweight clothing textiles to heavier wools for bedding. Natural white wool is used with much red, tan, gray and black. The pale blue and white item on right appears to be a linen tablecloth. On the wall is a Victorian clock, clever wooden display shelves for china cups, paintings, etc.
source: In a picturesque house in Nordfyn, all kinds of weaving are arranged for viewers to see. Photo by Carma.

caption: Doing chores on a farm; companionship while milking and eating.
description: British farm workers layered clothing for chores as required by weather. The man may have warm wool under his shirt or linen smock in cool weather, plus a neckerchief, old woolen breeches and stockings.. The woman may have worn two chemises and multiple petticoats under her dress. Summer was still rainy, so clothing was seldom very lightweight.
source: From a contemporary watercolor by W. H. Pyne, Akerman's Edition of the "Microcosm," (Now published in New York, by Dover, (Published in New York, by Dover, since 1977) Previous publisher in 1970 gave permission to Carma to use drawings at no cost.

caption: In Cuneo, Italy, 1826, a boy named Domenico re-named himself Domenique Boudrero.
description: lost his only parent, his mother,Domenique had friends in Marseille. France, where he had moved to live [before his marriage]. They went to heckle some Mormon missionaries with rotten vegetables, but when he heard the preaching, Domenique forgot his pranks and really listened, He was baptized into the Church soon after. Returning to Italy he lived in the Angrongna Branch, and his name is recorded there. In 1869 the young father,Domenique, wears a simple coat in a medium tone color, and has quite shabby dark trousers. His shoes are square toed and very old. He has neatly cut hair with a broad mustache and short goatee in the center. He has his little daughter on his lap in a dark checkered dress gathered at the bodice waistline with long, narrow sleeves. She holds her tiny hat for the picture. The mother, Henriette Chatelain. wears a small felt hat with a twisted hatband of various colors, and her hair ispulled back in a bob. Her dark wool dress has white buttons up the front in a placket, and a very small white collar. The dark wool dress bodice is the same checkered fabric as her child's dresses. She holds a baby in a white dress with high-top black shoes. Two other daughters are on the left. The older stands with her left arm behind her father, with short-cut, slightly curly hair. She wears her horizontal pin below the high neckline. Her dress has the usual set-in waistband for the full skirt. Her little sister in front of her has an identical dress and holds a round straw hat with a small brim and a flowery ribbon around the crown. He found his wife among the Mormons and lived out his life with a family north of Salt Lake City in Cache Valley.
source: Cover picture of This photograph of Domenique and Henriette ChatelainBrodrero is the cover illustration on Mormon Historical Studies Fall 2000. Article by Michael Horner.

caption: Better dress shirt of fine linen
description: In this view we see the spray of gathers in the center back of the shirt, just where his collar band is sewn on. On the inside of the shirt at the shoulder we see a broad facing of the same linen, sewn in after the sleeves are inserted, and pressed toward the center neckline. This facing strengthens the shirt to endure constant wear, and uses strong but discreet stitches on the inside. All raw edges are carefully turned under and sewn down.   There is an under-arm gusset, a 7 inch square, which is attached by French-seams. The gusset allows a man extra ease to lift his arms above his head without straining the fabric. Under-arm gussets are in most men's shirts of the 1700s and 1800s. In the rectangular sleeve we can see another spray of gathering ONLY at the sleeve top. There is, no gathering all the way around, as there was in the 1700s.
source: Worn by docent, David Phippen at MCHA. He does not wear the essential vest for this photo, allowing us see the shirt construction. Photo by Carma

caption: A drunken man tries to climb a fence, losing both his liquor jug and his hat, ca.: 1847.
description: In this clothing detail of the 1847 W. S. Mount painting, Liquor Loss and Gain, we see the result of habitual drinking on an older man who loses the dearly loved stuff that has made him clumsy and careless. He wears a half-buttoned pull-on shirt, trousers torn at the knee and frayed at the hem but held up by beige suspenders, and clutches the brown and red vest he has shed. He wears no stockings in his square toed shoes. His hat might be felt or straw, and has a red bandanna stuffed inside as it falls. In his inebriation, he has obviously taken no care for his appearance in some time. Mounts opinion of drinking was expressed to a friend: .To come square to the point with you my dear friendI must tell you that liquor drinking is a nuisance.Drinking causes one to be stupid, and to lose ambition about business, and indifference about personal appearance.As for myself, I have drilled my will power so, for the past yearthat I can sit and look at bottles without any inclination to drink.  William Sydney Mount, Letter to James Baxter, April, 1857.  (Image and quotation from: http://www.aaqeastend.com/content/william-sydney-mount-american-genre-painter/ )
source: David Cassidy and Gail Shrott, Janice Gray Armstrong, Ed. William Sidney Mount, Works in the Collection of The Museum at Stony Brook. (The Museums at Stony Brook, Stony Brook N.Y. 1983). Also seen on the internet.

caption: This early missionary from Iceland was a companion to Elder Gudmunder from Reykjavk, capitol of Iceland
description: This unnamed companion to the first Icelandic missionary, Elder Gudmund Gudmunder, wears a haircut unusual for Europe. His beard and sideburns are completely shaved off, and his hair is parted over from the side and cut off bluntly. His dark tie is tucked under the edges of a plaid vest. The coat's lapels are very outdated for European fashion, being extremely wide from the 1830s because his country was somewhat isolated.
source: Frederick W. W. Howell. F.R.G.S, Icelandic PicturesDrawn with Pen and Pencil, (Flemming H. Revell Co., New York, no date) p. 101.Republished by Ulan Press (August 31, 2012).

caption: Edward Partridge, the first LDS Church Bishop, has well-groomed hair and clothing, 1840.
description: Edward Partridge wears a very fine coat and vest of the latest 1830s. The neck is padded up high in back as popular in the former decade, and his sleeve tops stand up with slight gathering. A frilled bosom decorates his shirt between vest lapels, and a stand-up collar lies against his jaw. His formal white tie is wrapped twice around his collar then tied with only a tiny knot.
source: Engraving, H. B. Hall & Sons, made in 1840 (the year of Edward's death) from a drawing by an unknown artist. Church History Library, Salt Lake City. Also online. Free use.

caption: Fan of dyed egret feathers on ivory sticks used in early Salt Lake City
description: These feathers could collapse with the fan but were seldom totally pressed together.
source: Lottie Claridge Young, a pioneer of 1853, carried this fan when she attended the Salt Lake Theater There were pretty boxes in some rich homes for holding delicate fans when not in use.. It is known that the Theater was often very hot during the summers in Salt Lake City. Donor, Elizabeth McCune. SLC DUP Museum #7066

caption: Quaker woman in an oil painting, ca. 1830s - 40s.
description: In an unadorned day cap of fine lawn, this honest face shines above her large cream silk shawl. Underneath is a black dress, possibly of fine wool.
source: Courtesy of Wayne County Historical Society, Lyons, New York. Photo by Carma

caption: Elegant men's mustaches and beards with various coats and cravats. Ca. 1838-40s.
description: Three men in a fashion plate wear small mustaches with two having continental jaw-line beards. The mature men all wear longer curls, but the teen has more close cropped hair. The man on left wears a tightly fitted frockcoat with a flared skirt. His shirt is completely obscured by a dark silk ascot. White pants are probably strapped under his feet because they are straight with no wrinkles. The seated man has a pale colored, satin, double breasted vest over a white shirt with a high, white, button-on cravat. His frock coat is unbuttoned. His trousers are tight and strapped under pointed-toe shoes. The teen-age boys frockcoat would be brightly colored with a short skirt to his thighs. His white pants meet black riding boots with pale yellow, turn-over tops. The man on right wears Cossack pants with fullness at the waistline, narrowing down fashionably at the ankles. His coat is a claw-hammer style that shows off his pants. Standing men wear shiny silk top hats.
source: From Victorian magazine, Ladies' Little Courier.

caption: Elegant shawl strictly for fashion decoration.
description: Shawl of sculptured blue/black velvet on sheer silk with separate silk fringe added. Donor unknown.
source: Community of Christ Museum, Independence, Missouri, Photo by Carma

caption: yellow cotton smocking and embroidery front and back of Gardener's gray linen coat-smock, seen above.
description: These details of elaborate embroidery are on a coat smock with a neck-to-hem opening between matching designed fronts, The back is similarly embroidered. A coat smock, like all work smocks, is strongly reinforced in the shoulders by long double-layer bands from neckline to sleeve insertion, with all seam allowances turned under inside and no raw seams. It closes with wooden toggle buttons.
source: Smocking done by Elizabeth Peterson of Provo. It was cut and sewn by Carma with some rushed assistance of Nancy B. Egbert. Embroidery was entirely done by Joane Browning. Worn in many historical fashion shows. Photo by Carma.

caption: Embroidered Swedish cutwork on a woman's blouse
description: Cutwork with handmade lace fillers embroidered on front of woman's blouse from Fars, Sweden.
source: FIND BOOK & PUBLISHING INFO

caption: Embroidery scissors for a work basket and and linen thread for knitting.
description: The bird shaped sissors were a favcorite for clipping threads of small embroideries, never for cutting out clothing fabric. The loosely spun and twisted was for weaving fairly coarse unbleached linen. If the fiber were from hemp, it could be woven also and made to be strong and servicable for work clothing. This was the best Norway could send Carma when she asked for "linen thread" many decades ago, and it was too loosely twisted for ssewing or embroidery. Linen thread for quality sewing is now available all over the world on wooden spools, often used for sewing in America or and other countries.
source: Items in Carma's possession.

caption: Emigrant gathering in Liverpool, British port of departure. 1860s
description: All kinds of baggage are gathered for going to America, wooden trunks, huge canvas bags, and great bundles of bedding are unoaded from hand carts and horse carts. Men are usually in breeches and tall woolen stockings but there is a view of trousers.Their coats are knee length and various shaped toppers mingle with caps like tam o' shanters or wooly caps. Tiny child all have head coverings and their mothers have small bonnents, none deep and fashionable. Their shawls are stripes or plaids, undoubtedly woolen.
source: Mary Bywater Cross Quilts & Women of the Mormon Migrations, Treasures of Transition. Permission given by Lindsey Leslie

caption: Emma Smith in her formal black velvet riding habit, ca.:1840s.
description: Emma was painted in watercolor by Sutcliffe Maudsley. Her habit is a long skirt and separate bodice with at least 45 tiny (probably silver) buttons sewn onto narrow tape decorations. She favors the military effect. Her jacket collar is turned up and lined with a Betsy Collar from an Empire-high blouse for riding. There are 1840-style epaulette sleeves over her long-narrow ones. The edges of the epaulettes even have buttons and tape on them. Her cuffs expose a white frill at the wrist. The left side of her skirt two feet longer at the hemline, which modestly shields her ankles while she is mounted side-saddle. She holds up some excess length, and we can glimpse only the front of her narrow, square-tipped shoe style. (It was considered a titillation of male desire if a man walked near an exposed, easily-touched ankle.) She wears white stockings and black leather slippers with some heel on them to secure the foot in a stirrup. She holds an ivory handled crop, one of two she owned (still in private collections). Her black silk bonnet was removed and placed on the table so the painter, could capture her profile. The bonnet has a fine, black, silk, lace veil to float behind her while she rides. The inside of the bonnet brim is a flattering shade of pale pink to reflect on her face. Her natural dark hair is pulled back in a high bob, with two sections of hair on the front sides are twisted into ringlets, bound together with small cords to hang in front of her ears with her bonnet on. When this painting is seen close up, as Carma has held it in her hands, it is possible to see sets of combs that keep Emma's hair smooth on each side of her head, each positioned forward at eyebrow height. When Emma appeared in her bonnet to pose for Sutcliffe Maudsley, one conjectures he complained he could not see her profile. His artistic strength was only to paint profile portraits, so he must have requested her to remove the bonnet. Also, the fictitious drape with gold fringe and cording at right is customarily added by the artist as "the drape of honor" in a portrait.
source: LDS Church Archives.

caption: All-over aprons in a detail of English ceramic tile production line of 1862.Teen in a white cap. Child labor assistant near her.
description: This little girl (center)wears an all-over apron like the older worker standing (left). Poor child were often denied schooling among British mill families Boys and girls had to earn low wages as assistants for their needy families, with adults also in underpaying jobs.
source: David Sekers, The Potteries, (Shire Publications #62 ___) Shire Publications Ltd., Cromwell House, Church St., Princes Risborough, Aylesbury, Bucks, HP179AJ, UK.

caption: An English boy wears a linen coat smock
description: The British put rain flaps over the shoulders of some smocks in especially rainy shires such as Cheshire, for protection. These large flaps could be unbuttoned in periods of better weather, but the smock was a welcome and useful layer of warmth and protection against chills and farm dirt on other clothing.
source: Gertrude Jekyll, Old English Household Life: Some Account of Cottage Objects and Country Folk (New York, HarperCollins Distribution Services; Revised edition, September 1975).

caption: English child play on a farm cart.
description: We can see these extremely old buildings with one window of diamond shaped leaded window panes, common medieval way to make windows for light indoors. The thatched roof is more than 100 years old ,and 2 dwellings share a hearth between. them .A girl in a small white bonnet wears a pink figured dress to her knees. The oldest wears blue with a rose and white large checkered apron. She has a white rabbit or little dog on her hap. A strong boy is dressed in an old felt hat and golden brown shirt and long trousers. He helps a girl climb up a drawing rod of the cart to be with the others. She has dark long hair and wears a reddish dress with a colored apron and a neck shawl of white with green cross bars. Her black shoes lace upon her ankles over grey stockings. Two more child are coming to play: the oldest in a white summer jacket over a brownish skirt just to her knees (never longer!), and her little sister is in pale blue and white stripes. Both wear straw hats for the welcome sun.
source: Painting by W. S. Coleman, Appleby Brothers Ltd, England.

caption: English farmer and his child feeding chickens, detail, 1820
description: A watercolor showing an English farmer relaxing from his labors with a white clay pipe and a heavy white linen smock. His breeches button down to the knees above pale blue stockings and to his black leather shoes. He has a red wool shirt underneath the smock, and a misshapen old top hat. All the little child around him wear aprons over their dresses. Three of the girls are in bonnets.
source: Painting by Robert Hills of Islington, England (1769- 1844). Original painting hangs in Nelson Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City, Missouri.

caption: English merchant in gaiters traveling toward the area of Ely Cathedral. 1810-40s
description: A man wears gaiters over his shoes with many buttons reaching up to his buttoned knee breeches. He carries a walking stick and rests a few moments against a mile marker. Breeches and gaiters were especially typical of British clothing of the period, but Americans gave them up for trousers sooner than Britain did.
source: William Johnstone White, edited by Pamela Clabborn, Working Class Costume from Sketches of Characters, (London, Daedalus Press for Victoria and Albert Museum, by Costume Society, c.o. Department of Textiles. 1977.)

caption: English Metropolitan police, Winter and Summer uniforms. 1840s
description: One policeman in a very tall "stove pipe" topper is standing in his all black cutaway frock coat holding a pair of gloves. His chin is shaved but he has mutton-chop whiskers. The summer uniform has a tailcoat and white trousers of wool or cotton twill. High-standing collars with braid give these officers dignity.
source: Egan, Police Staff Collection

caption: English police arrest a pickpocket, while boys laugh. An illustration by Cruikshank, in a book by Charles Dickens. 1840s-50s
description: There are three police in this picture. They all have black coats, light trousers and top hats. One carries a stick, one wheels the culprit in a wooden wheelbarrow, and the third follows to control the crowd. The little boys are having such fun watching, and the women are laughing.
source: by Cruikshank in an article by Robert Coles, "The Keen Eye of Charles Dickens," in Harvard Law School Bulletin, summer 1984.

caption: Shirt and Smock compared, with various fronts and collars worn for hundreds of years by working men.
description: The frSmocks were the most commonly worn clothing of the working class throughout Europe, Britain and America. The upper one is the coat smock front with 10 buttons. There is little embroidery on the collar. Shoulder added embroidered rain guards and there are buttoned flap pockets. Extremely dense smocking covers both front and back of the smock. A close-up of the gathers and two button cuffs is very interesting because smocking stitches do not continue all around the sleeve cuff.ont and back view of a coat smock sent from England
source: Source lost.

caption: The front and back view of a coat smock sent from England.
description: The frSmocks were the most commonly worn clothing of the working class throughout Europe, Britain and America. The upper one is the coat smock front with 10 buttons. There is little embroidery on the collar. Shoulder added embroidered rain guards and there are buttoned flap pockets. Extremely dense smocking covers both front and back of the smock. A close-up of the gathers and two button cuffs is very interesting because smocking stitches do not continue all around the sleeve cuff.ont and back view of a coat smock sent from England
source: Hereford City Museums in England sent this drawing to Carma.

caption: English woman in short gown with others, all knitting, 1837.
description: In a village with plentiful sheep and yarn, whole families sit and knit for a living. In the background is a man herding sheep while walking along and knitting. The woman in far background knits while she walks. Over the brown wool skirt the center woman wears a blue apron over a white linen short gown. Her felt hat tops a yellow headscarf. The men are in old-style knee britches with stockings and shoes. All wear felt hats. The old man in foreground is probably from generations of knitters.
source: English knitters with sheep herder on cover of a book about English sheep, 1837.

caption: English young women workers in coal mines wore padded trousers under their pinned up skirts.
description: This detail of only 2 of many uneducated women who had dreadful jobs in the 1800s sifting out coal dust from the smaller pieces of coal they were assigned to gather. They became blackened, even across their faces, at times. To offset this degradation they tried to retain some indication of femininity so wore little kerchiefs over their hair or tiny hats or bits of flowers . There is even a necklace over the old linen or cotton blouse on a girl, (on left). Their tough shoes required metal rims on thick soles and heels, or the shoes would be destroyed by underground railroad tracks and coal. Their wages were an all-time low for long, long hours in the mining industry, so important to Englands economy. The rich men who owned the mines cared nothing for working conditions of lower humans. They were exceedingly poor, with wages far too low.
source: Early image of a lineup of girls from the Costume Galleries in Rusholm, England, partially governed by City of Manchester Art Gallery.  . Photographed by Carma from a framed image on the wall at the Galleries of Rusholm.

caption: Erick Christian Henrichsen, born in JutlandProvince,Denmark, 1847, wears coat and trousers current there.
description: This young man in Danish clothing has a dense woolen coat with fairly roomy sleeves over a shirt and vest underneath. Probably he wears also knitted wool underwear for the cold times in Denmark. This is a roomy, more shapeless frock coat,a style sometimes worn in America in the late 1840s. His trousers have interesting silk or wool tape down the outside seam of each leg, to show some social status.  In Denmark the Henrichsens came with other Scandinavian converts to the Utah territory, where they set up a pottery making business and were very successful in it.
source: Courtesy of Ericks great-grandson Kirk Henrichsen, a fine arts oil painter in Utah.

caption: Ernest Anderson as a young adult convert in Utah Territory, is seen here in the 1870s, came from Sweden to Utah in the 1860s as a very young teen immigrant(with his brother) to look for work and sustenance.
description: In this image during the late 1870sErnest has earned a fine suit of clothes and learned to sculpture his natural waves of hair (with an unknown oil) in a very short haircut. His fine dark wool coat of ca. 1880 closes only with the top button. Brave enough to travel without knowing English, he and his brother had left their family on a farm in Augurum, near the port city ofKarlskronain, Blekinge Province ,Sweden. They dared to leave with LDS missionaries direction, and worked hard to bring their family over the ocean and to the Utah Territory (see parents elsewhere. Their father, Karl August Anderson was blonde and their mother, Fredricka Karlsdottor, was a stunning brunette.) When Ernst met lovely Millie May Neel, he was entranced with the Irish-Scottish girl. They married in the Salt Lake Temple. (See Millie May Neel as a little child elsewhere in this book).
source: The Neel-Parker Family, Margaret Iretta Parker Anderson , Maurine Parker Fuhreman (Copyright 1985, Maurine Parker Fuhriman,).

caption: Two mens' shoe styles from Europe 1800s
description: Shoes have buttons or an elastic side gusset to ease putting them on. One has a loop to pull the shoe on--likely on many others unseen.
source: Drawn by Carma after Eunice Wilson A History of Shoe Fashion, (London, Pitman Publishing Co. 1974 ).

caption: Fabric ladies' shoes of putty colored wool with linen lining and darker leather toe caps.
description: With lacings on the inner sides, these low heeled shoes are very practical for daily wear and easy to tie on.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Drawn by Margaret Weber.

caption: Better dress clothing on Ezra & Henrietta Williams, ca.: 1840s.
description: Ezra wears his dark hair neatly sculpted down around his ears with a goatee but no mustache. His black suit says that he is important as a well-trained Doctor. His shirt front is impeccable and probably starched in tucks, with collar standing up stiffly and starched cuffs apparent. His black cravat is tied in a barrel knot. His wide lapels have buttonholes almost up to the collar, and his vest of satin has many tiny buttons, not all buttoned. Well educated Henrietta Williams had recently turned 16 in this demure image. She wears a striped silk dress with narrow sleeves cut on the bias beneath V shaped caplets at the shoulders. Shirring across the shoulders is gathered into the V-shape bodice with a very full skirt below. A black velvet neck ribbon is crossed and held with a modish square broach, and a long watch-chain descends to her skirt. To one side of her smooth hair-do, she has tucked a white flower. After Dr. Lewis was called to treat this fragile young woman for some months, he found he wanted to have her forever. They saw each other occasionally with parents' discretion and he married her four years later.
source: Nancy Clement Williams, Meet Dr. Frederick Granger Williams and his wife Rebecca Swain Williams. Read their true story in the first introduction - After one hundred years! (Independence, Mo.: Zion's Printing & Publishing Company, 1951)

caption: Truant Discovered, ca.: 1840s.
description: This boy was caught skipping school by the truant officer on right. The boy attempted a disguise to escape detection by wearing a girl's scarf over his head and a dress over his checkered trousers. His mother pleads for leniency, as she stands in an outdoor bonnet and shawl.  His sister wears a bonnet and cloak with apron and boots The mothers bonnet has a short brim, and her shawl seems to be a patchwork of patterns, with fringe. The truant officer has long sideburns and a beard.
source: A wood engraving in an 1840s newspaper in the Missouri State Historical Society at University of Missouri, Columbia, Missouri. Free use.

caption: Poor boys' hats and clothes typical in America, worn at Mrs. McCormick's General Store, ca.: 1844.
description: Mrs. McCormick in her aqua spotted dress with rolled up summer sleeves and a white day cap is chasing off young hoodlums stealing from her general store. The boy on left wears a straw hat with a wide black ribbon and pewter-colored clothing, is taking advantage of an open display. The boy being thrust back wears beige trousers with a knee out, a rust colored cap thrust askew, suspenders and orange jacket. Behind him is an obnoxious, top-hatted, young show-off thumbing his nose at Mrs. McCormick's remonstrations. He wears a dark green jacket and flat shoes. Other boys are barefoot. The less aggressive lad on right has a shallow, cream, deerstalker cap and short jacket with worn-out elbows and lost buttons on his pullover shirt front. Papers are under his arm. Standing on far right side is a well-dressed woman holding a teething 1 year old in a red blousy cap. An older brother wears a white linen smock and little trousers, with a dark green pilot cap over his long hair. He carries his stick and hoop for chasing fun. His mother wears a deep 1840s straw bonnet with a simple brown ribbon above a peach, figured, little shawl. Her very dark grey shopping apron covers a flounced lavender skirt almost to the ground. The canary hanging outdoors in his cage is undoubtedly excited by the ruckus.
source: Oil painting by A. D. D. Browere, 1844, seen by Carma in New York State Historical Association, Cooperstown, New York.

caption: Beggar child, a detail from "The Bottle," ca.: 1840s.
description: George Cruikshank, artist and social critic, saw liquor as responsible for alcoholic parents depending on the begging of their child. Basically, the message is simple and overttemperance goes with full (middle-class) purses and neatly turned-out child. Drinking goes with ragged clothes, poverty, thin bodies and death.
source: George Cruikshank, 1847. Cruikshank illustrated all the novels of Charles Dickens, and appeared in many newspaper articles and advertisements. Free use.

caption: In a wagon train going west, a man on a horse wears a coat made from a white wool blanket with colored stripes, ca.: 1847-56.
description: Hand woven blankets in a wagon train were purposely heavy and dense. These with green, black and red stripes were made in Canada and North Dakota, where cold is a serious situation, and were often cut into simple, warm, unlined coats for men. Such a heavy "Blanket coat," pictured here, is worn by a Mormon pioneer at the Sweet Water River encampment.
source: Harold I. Hopkinson painted the pioneers at the Sweet Water River on the Great Plains. This detail also shows laundry drying on branches by the river's side. It is from Hopkinsons own book of paintings and narration of Mormon history. Permissions were given to Carma before Harold Hopkinsons death.

caption: Painting of Handcart Company by Danquart Weggeland.
description: Norwegian artist Weggeland painted the handcart period of the 1850s to 60s, although he actually joined the LDS Church after the handcart period ended. But he knew how his people dressed, which was not much different for travel among all of the Scandinavians. On the lower right is a boy beside a fire heating water. He wears a little felt cap for the cold morning and slip-on clogs with leather tops. Behind him is a man with a bugle and rifle who signals the company for their next move. The men wear wool shirts of red and gold, or white linen shirts with old traveling coats. The men have pillbox and brimmed felt hats. Most wear tall boots. The women have warm jackets over their bodices and blouses, many belted-in. They usually have sunbonnets with a "curtain" around the neck and shoulders to prevent sunburn, but some wear scarves folded into triangles and tied under the chin. Two Native Americans, far right, depart after a visit.  These handcarts are covered against the weather, but most had no covers other than a protective blanket, or a kind of canvas tarp. A few of these handcarts carry elderly people or toddlers. Usually, wagons carrying bulk items and leading milk cows accompanied the handcarts. We see smaller milk cans carried by the man in green trousers on left, and on the ground beside the boy in front.
source: Oil painting by Dan Weggeland, who painted the art work after the time of the hand-carters, but he knew the Scandinavian people well. MCHA

caption: Mormon Pioneers traveling westward wore useful, common, red wool shirts and every kind of old coat and hat, ca.:1847 to1870
description: This detail from a painting of a wagon train of Mormon pioneers gives a view of men conferring together. Three wear black coats, a center front boy has a light blue coat with a yellow straw hat, and others wear dark-toned shirts.  This artist, Carl Christian Anton Christensen, of the USA Railroad Times, never took part in a long wagon train when he came from Denmark, so we cannot rely on these imagined outfits for what would have been seen at an earlier time. However, traveling clothing of 20 years before had not changed much by the time of his own journey. Men still wore old top hats and various kinds of close caps and coats for protection. One woman here wears maroon dress with a white apron -- but women would never have worn white aprons for travel-- only in a settled home for entertaining! All traveling aprons would have been darker colors, checks or stripes of tough cloth to hide the soil of the trail.
source: C. C. A. Christensen painted a 175 foot scenic roll of major Church events in oil to express his love of LDS Church history. He joined his ten paintings and hauled the roll around the state in a wagon, giving lectures on Church History for small ticket prices during the colder months in Utah. He stayed home to farm in the summers. Each painting section is about 5 ft. square, with the outermost painting of the First Vision having been worn out and thrown away. Owned by the Museum of Art, Brigham Young University, Provo, Utah.

caption: Leather jacket made for Thomas T Bullock by his wife, Henrietta Rushton Bullock, for crossing the plains, while crossing the plains?, patterned after Native American styles, 1847.
description: A leather jacket, Native American style, was produced by Thomas loving and clever wife, Henrietta, for him to wear while leading Saints west. Made of well-tanned deerskin, it falls to hip-length with seven buttons down the front placket. Twelve-inch fringe extends from the shoulder yokes both front and back. Six inch fringe is down the outer seam of the sleeves. At the hemline is a double row of fringe of 3 and 8 inches long.  She also made the matching trousers, employing a narrow line of bright red calico from knees to ankles. There are small leather braids with tasseled ends also hanging from side seams on the hips area, possibly to tie on items he wanted close about himself. When his clever wife made a matching leather jacket, she spent long periods cutting much longer fringe for adornment. More information about the Bullock family accompanies the clothing in its display in Salt Lake City. Henrietta must have brought with her on the journey some excellent, strong scissors and tools to be able to work with leather as she traveled.  On November 20, 1841, the Bullocks were baptized members of the LDS Church in Staffordshire, England, and soon emigrated to Nauvoo. In England the American Indians were becoming glamourized in folk tales as the 1800s wore on.
source: Photo by Carma at Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Free use.

caption: In a blue wool frock coat, a young man speaks to MCHA docent Marilyn Bennion, who plays the part of a widow in her mourning clothes, ca.:1847.
description: In front of the last restored pioneer cabin of 1847 in Salt Lake City, a widow sells her home-made soap to a young man. She wears a very dark print of black and white in her dress, and a black apron with tiny white dots. This mourning dress has flanges over the shoulders which narrow to points in front and back. Her apron is a pinafore, with the triangular upper part pinned to the bodice of her dress with straight pins. The pins do not tear the dress because they go through the layers of the flanges. Her sleeves are shirred in many rows at the top, then flare out to be gathered into a self-fabric wrist band. As she has no wealth, this 1830s style was kept in her wardrobe for various mourning periods over decades. Her broad straw hat protects her from the sun while she is outside cuttings up her soap. The man, Ron Reid, wears a blue frockcoat we identify as being of the 1830s from its high standing collar and slight gathers at the sleeve tops. He has white stockings with black slippers. Brass buttons are at his cuffs and waist back.
source: Clothing made or assembled by Carma, Photo by Joseph R. Putnam; free use.

caption: The Duel Family Cabin, the first cabin built Salt Lake City, ca.: 1847
description: The husband wears a hand woven cotton/linen shirt. The blue checked fabric has a bias-cut double front yoke with two small wooden toggle buttons. The open collar is about 4 inches deep. 4 inch cuffs are rolled up to forearms. The sleeves have a small spray of gathers at the top of the shoulder.  His beige wool flannel trousers with a broadfall waistline are much distressed with mending and patching on knees and seat. His black hat is felt with a flat brim. He wears square toed black boots, calf high. A tall summer hat of straw hangs on the wall. The pregnant wife carried her baby across the plains to be born in the Valley after her arrival. She wears a white day cap and has a smocked yoke in front of her white cotton print dress. She has flat black slippers with white stockings. The back of her maternity dress has the usual bodice structure at the waistline. Her simple long sleeves are gathered into cuffs. Diapers of older babies are drying near the wall beside dried squash rings.
source: MCHA Cabin of 1847. All clothes are accurate reproductions made or assembled by Carma. Free use. Mans shirt fabric from Thistle Hill Hand Weavers.

caption: A pregnant pioneer woman crossing the plains with her two sons. Such clothing was worn during all 1800s.
description: The mother wears a high-yoked, gingham prairie dress or "wrapper." It has long sleeves with small cuffs, and opens down the front with buttons on the yoke and hooks below. This style of dress was worn throughout all the 1800s, but this woman is a pioneer, and could have crossed the plains in the late 1840s through 70s. She has a wide, woman's, straw hat tied on with black ribbons sewn on inside the hat. Her apron ties around at whatever level the growing baby allows.   Her older boy wears different fabrics for top and bottom, which button together in a poor boy's "skeleton suit." He has a soft, thick, cotton, pilot cap, and his little brother has a shapeless felt hat tied on with string. This is how a small boy looks in a pullover smock with fancy stitching in the center front at the neck opening. Any old cotton pieces make his little trousers.
source: Clothing and Photo by Carma; free use. The models are Nicole Riley and her own two boys.

caption: Three British handcart girls wait for their better-class families to get moving on a cool fall day, while dust blows into their hair. Ca.: 1857.
description: The oldest sister, standing, has a good, stout, straw hat with a grosgrain ribbon around it over a day cap of ruffled batiste. She wears a long sleeved white cotton chemise, and around her neck is a triangle-folded brown and cream plaid neckerchief. Her larger thick wool shawl is a large plaid, and her useful apron of tough drilling is striped in blue.  Her younger sister also wears a light straw hat over a red plaid head shawl. Her dress is a strong black cotton with small designs in straw color. A black flannel petticoat covers much of her red and black stockings. Lace edged pantalets below her hem.  Leaning on a woven creel containing blankets and immediate foods, their young friend in a tam o'shanter cuddles up in her long, black and pinkish striped shawl. A lighter chocolate fringed shawl is around her neck over a white apron and navy wool skirt. Her stockings are woolen knit in hand-dyed yarns of a goldish color.
source: Costumes assembled for fashion shows by Carma, worn by granddaughters Eliza and Kate, with friend Amy Robertson. Photo by Universal Photography of Orem, Utah, now long out of business. Free use.

caption: Osmund & Eliza Shaw in wedding clothes, ca.: 1849.
description: Osmond Broad Shaw and Eliza Gibson Wilding, of England, are wed in the most elaborate fashion they can afford. Osmund has a black coat with heavy silk-satin lapels, a yellow, single breasted vest, white shirt with tucked yoke, and a twice-wrapped cravat with a small front knot. His starched collar stands up. Neck-length red hair is combed back at the sides, accompanied by chin-length sideburns and a mustache. Pretty Eliza has a beautiful, bonnet ruched on the inside brim with coral silk, and trimmed with green cording and matching satin tie-ons. A single ostrich feather wraps over the crown. Elizas day cap has only modest ruffles against her cheeks. Her gray dress with bodice pleats and small jet buttons will last her for much wear after the wedding. A small broach of jasper-wear centers on the sheer neck ruffle. An excellent seamstress, Eliza surely made the dress herself. Her shawl is called a serpentine design, having alternating stripes of decoration. Three years after joining the Church of Jesus Christ LDS the couple emigrated to join the Saints in Zion. Across the American plains, Osmund drove a wagon full of furniture and precious bolts of English fabrics for Elizas work as seamstress and "stay-maker." Eliza walked all the way, wearing out 4 pairs of her father's fine shoes made for her trousseau.
source: Much worn photos of the two were enlarged and painted under the direction and clothing advice of their great granddaughter, Carma Anderson. The Artist was Ben Sowards. The portraits here have been combined and cropped to conserve space without losing detail.

caption: An engaged couple wears elegant wedding clothes in a Scottish calotype, ca.: Mid 1844s.
description: Mr. Gallie and Miss Munro stand unmoving for the calotypist showing their handsome clothing. He has a striking, silk, plaid vest, cut on the bias and double breasted under his snugly tailored frock coat. As is fashionable, he wears lighter trousers. He also has dark glasses (perhaps for fragile vision) and carries a fashionable walking stick. His jawline beard is trimmed to be narrow. Miss Munro, in a pale plaid silk, has all sorts of shirring, lace trimming, and a broach on the bodice of her long gown. Her stole seems to be a dark color with a light silk lining, pink or pale green being popular colors of this period. Her ringlets are made of her own hair with the help of her personal maid.
source: Calotypes, early photos using only the sun for lighting, are seen in many books and museums charting the history of photography. They were originated by David BruceandDavid Octavius Hill, ca.: 1840s. An excellent collection is in a volume by New York Graphic Society; Sun pictures; The Hill-Adamson calotypes(First Edition edition,1974).

caption: Portraits of an African-American abolitionist couple of 1843, NancyandWilliam Lawson.1843
description: Portraits of an African-American abolitionist couple of 1843, NancyandWilliam Lawson. Nancy wears a dark green wool dress with full lower sleeves and a low white collar of V-shaped, fagotted edge. A white modesty piece across her neckline has a ribbon woven through the top edge, and holds a little gold broach. A black ribbon around her neck has another tiny jewel where it crosses. Small caplets are at the top of her sleeves, and white cuffs show at the wrists. Lighter buttons for her dark dress are above the diagonal darts of the front bodice, and also on the caplets of her sleeves. Her day cap is definitely an 1840s a flat section on top and larger ruffles on the sides. The day cap has pale, sheer ribbons hanging. In the background is a large, painted "drape of honor" with silk cords.In every way their dress denotes great comfort and beauty. William wears a black dress coat, with a fairly high-necked vest. A gold chain around his neck for a flat watch seems to be tucked into an upper welt pocket on his vest. He wears very short curly hair and a neatly shaved and trimmed jaw-line beard from his side burns. He was called Reverend, as a courtesy title for his Millerite oratory supporting the Second Coming--expected in 1843 or 44. But he became entangled in The Great Disappointment. Professionally, Lawson was a used clothing dealer in Boston.
source: Portraitsby William Matthew Prior (1843).PERMISSIONS 86//  .Shelburne Museum,   Mailing address:  Shelburne Museum P.O. Box 10 Shelburne, VT 05482 Phone: (802) 985-3346 Email: curators@shelburnemuseum.org

caption: Woman in a plaid dress and man in a black suit of the 1840s to 50s.
description: A young woman gazes at a handsome, casually leaning man. She wears a fashionable silk plaid dress with a matching capelet. Ringlets fall from behind her ears. His coat has 1840s narrow sleeves, wider lapels, and a barely turned down shirt collar for greater comfort. A patterned cravat is tied with ends tucked beneath his white vest. A combed-back pouf of hair tops his head.
source: by Nathaniel C. Jacuith, Rinhart Collection, Ohio State University, Columbus, from The American Daguerreotype. Portrait c. 1848.

caption: Baby clothes worn by little Joseph Wilford, with mother, Phebe Carter Woodruff. Ca.: 1842.
description: Baby clothes for first born son of Phebe and Wilfred Woodruff, a 1-year-old. He holds a woolen yarn nosegay with knots to chew on for teething. He wears the usual dainty white dress with a red ribbon around the high waist over a full length petticoat. A necklace of tiny beads of coral around the baby's neck was supposed, in that era, to be a protection from disease. Thus there are hundreds of baby and child pictures in fine portraits or folk arts in America that include coral necklaces.  Phebe has a lovely, expensive day-cap with scalloped white needlework on sheer, over loops of satin ribbon. It is tied with a 2 inch wide silk ribbon. Her collar is a series of slight gathers of narrow lace circled on batiste about 4 inches wide on her small shoulders over the high-necked black dress. On her bosom is a white shell or ivory carved broach in a gold horizontal oval. With her arm around the baby we can see her ruby and gold ring, (photo elsewhere). The shawl on her lap is a soft, gold, merino, wool with "serpentine" flowers in lines across it and a bit of mixed red fringe barely included in the painting.  Coming from a family of means, she was not poor when Wilford Woodruff first encountered her in Kirtland as he walked into the town for the first time. He heard her cultivated voice singing through an open window and had a romantic premonition he should marry her, which he soon did. Wilford gave her the ring at their marriage.
source: This oil painting by Joseph Campbell is an excellent folk painting which does not flatter her looks, but does honor to mother and son. LDS Museum of Church History and Art in Salt Lake City.

caption: Alexander Hale Smith age 4, with his mother, Emma Hale Smith, in a mourning dress. Ca.: 1848.
description: Little Alexander wears a typically strong, pink, checkered dress over trousers of pale blue. He has a double ruffled collar and carries a little red leather wallet. Both he and his mother are in flat black slippers with white stockings.  Emma wears an out of date, black, mourning dress with voluminous sleeves and sleeve caps, worn for years without alteration because of so many successive deaths in the Smith family. The sleeve style is from 15 years previous. On her shoulders is an elegantly embroidered collar which could be smaller for the 1840s. Around her neck is a ribbon attached to the pocket watch in her front bodice pocket or waistband. A handkerchief shows she is still grieving for her husband, Joseph. Her hair is in a large bun surrounded by braids.
source: Sutcliff Maudsley painted Emma and Alexander as if outdoors by the corral, in a very folk-art style. This painting and the actual little red wallet of Alexander's, were last owned (to our knowledge) by a private collector ca. 2005. Permission to use was granted on a trade of information with Carma.

caption: Folk art of a woman in best bonnet, dress of printed stripes and a valuable shawl, observed by Native Americans. Ca.: 1844.
description: This extract from the folk art painting, Joseph Smith Preaching in the Nauvoo Grove, shows many levels of society gathered to hear The Prophet preach, including curious Native Americans next to the woman, who sits listening in her open carriage. The folk artist painted an indistinct crowd scene (shown elsewhere), with a few people standing out in detail. This is one. Featured figures were painted with attentive care by the original artist, even if the headdresses and faces were inaccurate.
source: LDS Church Archives. Extract drawn by Carma. Free use.

caption: Fancy cotton stockings, knitted in Hellum, Aalborg, Denmark.
description: We see clever horizontal perforations knitted into the stockings, as well as decorations at the top. These were for females, often younger girls. They would be held up with fancy colored tape tied around the leg as garters.
source: Aalborg Historical Museum,. ???? historiskmuseum@aalborg.dk Email to use pix of stockings: #13392 Email sent July 5, 17.

caption: American farmer cuts his straw with a multi-pronged cradle scythe. 1850-60s
description: This farmer, wearing a vest and shirt, breeches and boots, swings a cradle scythe into his lat crop of straw. The extra prongs gather the straw as it is cut to deposit it in a swath. At the end of the cutting stroke, a farmer tilts the cradle to drop the straw in a pile. A horse and wagon with farm helpers are also in background to carry the straw piles into a giant stack.
source: : Missouri Historical Review Oct. 2007 State Historical Society of Missouri, Columbia, Missouri

caption: Faroe Islands Costumes, Denmark
description: In many regions of Denmark, men wear red, double-breasted vests, with buttons from neck to lower waistline. The fronts are made of woven red wool, which is sometimes in stripes of black, red and white. This old man and youth wear white shirts with a narrow collar and a black tie beneath. Their hats are knitted and flopped over on top. Usually these knitted caps are red, but the older gentleman has fancy blue knitted designs on white. The breeches we cannot see are either black or white, with white knitted stockings and black shoes. Stockings are held up to their knees with strips of fancy woven garters, knotted and hanging at the sides. This type of costume is worn extensively by men in the different provinces. The woman at right wears a plain white kerchief over her head wears a lovely white shawl, probably embroidered in bright colors. Her apron over her black or red skirt is blue and white checkered, with ties wrapped forward to make a bow in front. It may be a Church holiday or day of independence.
source: internet address httpwww.bing.comimagessearchq= danish+folk+costumes+images &view=detailv2&qpvt=danish+ folk+costumes+images&id= 57F6EEBAB0A54B565E22214A700795AC9735B802 &selectedIndex=18&ccid= Vwx8suDF&simid=6080

caption: The Farrier who puts shoes on horses was a much needed man in the 1800s and for many centuries before.
description: A blacksmith who shapes and attaches horseshoes must wear a leather apron to protect from the heat and sparks of his forge and hammering. Usually the apron ties around both waist and neck, but this mans neck strap seems to have broken. Cleverly, he hooks one of the strap holes onto a vest button until he has time to repair it. His shirtsleeves are rolled up, but he still wears a proper vest and neck kerchief. Going without a vest and neckwear was tantamount to working in ones underwear, since the shirt was often a nightgown as well. In a hot forge he could do without a hat.
source: W. H. Pyne, "Microcosm." Free use.

caption: Fashion doll dressed in a short gown. 1700s to 1800s
description: A short gown is a thigh-length top worn over a chemise and skirt. A short working dress, it has no fastenings, but overlaps in the front, and is tied in place by an apron or sash. It may be of many types of fabric, and have long or short sleeves. This doll from Britain, has a striped short gown, painted face, heavy novelty wool clothing, and is carrying wool for spinning. From Platt Hall, Manchester, England drawn by Carma
source: Drawing by Carma from the early 1800s

caption: Four men's hats of felt and knit.
description: Four men's hats of felt and knit are seen in CD Fig# ?.A long, black wool, knitted Phrygian cap with red and gold horizontal stripes, is much seen in folk paintings. It would be worn with the top flopped over. The black pilot cap of fine wool twill was made by Jeannette Woolf for her re-enactor husband, John. The gray wool felt hat is unfinished and retains a soft point on the crown. A beige, wool felt hat is shown with the beginnings of shaping on a brim. Both felt hats, left unfinished, were cheaply made for the very poor to buy.
source: Assembled by Carma. Photo by Joseph R. Putnam

caption: Fingerless gloves made of a tiny crochet reach only to the wrist bone.
description: Fingerless gloves made of a tiny crochet reach only to the wrist bone. In CD Fig ? ,modern Chinese-made gloves, typical of the 1800s in Europe and America, are modeled next to a silk taffeta skirt in a large plaid from the 1850 to1868.
source: Carmas collection, modeled by Carol Anderson- Anderson

caption: Gloves: fingerless, crocheted, modern reproduction of historic design.
description: a row of solid dots around the wrist to make a charming border, with only simple decors on the back of the hand. This was a boon to those who wanted to appear beautifully dressed in public, but had aging, spotted or reddened hands.
source: From Carmas collection of reproductions for her historic fashion shows

caption: Smock on little boy on a Finnish candy box.
description: The smock goes over trousers which come just below his knees and shows red stockings. Smocks were used all over the western world on males of all ages in the 1800s. Could be worn anywhere in Scandinavia.
source: This image comes from a tiny Finnish candy box from decades ago.

caption: Fisher Lassies dressed for cold Scottish winds on the coastline.
description: They have white warm scarves around their windy hair, bright colored stripes on layers of petticoats covered byblack wool coats without their arms inside. They have to handle heavy creels hanging on their back shoulders full of many pounds of fish bought directly from the fishing boats. Hauling the fish to market in town is each girl's heavy job, trudging in their black shoes and stockings.
source: David Bruce, Sun Pictures: The Hill-Adamson Calotypes(New York Graphic Society Ltd. Greenwich, Connecticut; 1st edition 1974

caption: Flat shoes were worn by all women, but this has an improvement of a tightening buckle strap.
description: Lightweight leather flat shoe with tiny buckle cinch and squared toes.
source: Drawn by Carma

caption: Flat slipper of colored, soft, child leather or silk satin. Little loops sewn inside the top edge carry narrow ribbons criss-crossing on up the lower calf.
description: This delicate slipper was worn for best by young women and girls over opaque pale silk or cotton stockings. Sometimes the females wore linen pantalets almost to the ankles, but such leg coverings became fairly lost under larger and longer skirts for women in the 1850s.
source: Laced up ribbons drawn by Carma after Eunice Wilson, A History of Shoe Fashions (London, Pitman Publishing Co, 1974).

caption: Flower garland attached to a comb for a very formal occasion such as a dinner or ball.
description: "Artificials" were often made when women got together socially to sew or create decorations for their clothing. They called flowers "artificials" in their journals and made them from many different scraps of silk, with sewing and fine wires often holding flowers tightly at the base. Some were quite realistic, as these roses, and some were quite simple, depending on a woman's skill. Such items could be purchased in larger stores. This particular comb has a wide extension beside the teeth to hold the garland out on each side of the head so the flowers could hang evenly behind her ears. This is for those of higher social status.
source: Louis A.Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840).Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections.

caption: Folk betgwn in red striped wool with dark green apron.
description: A flowered kerchief covers her neck. The tall black felt hat is worn over a ruffled white daycap with lappets. Forearms are Warmed by black gloves.
source: Original in the National Gallery of Wales, modified by Ken Etheridge in Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century.

caption: Folk skirt of red wool in a province of Sweden.
description: Cartridge pleating reproduced with a cotton waistband in this skirt from Bleckinge, sewn in cartridge pleats: four strong threads knotted as gathered in and then a red cotton waistband is sewn on by hand.
source: Made byCarma.

caption: Franklin D. Richards, an early apostle of the LDS Church, wears best coat, vest and tie. Ca.: 1853.
description: Franklin is wearing 1849 clothing with a small M-cut on his collar where it meets the lapel. His coat is very fine lightweight worsted which can be tailored very precisely. His vest may have a rounded shawl collar, and has properly smaller buttons than those on his double breasted coat. The front yoke of his shirt shows flat pleats with two tiny pearl studs, and his collar is partly turned down. A dark colored tie is a plain bow knot. He has more hair than his famous brothers, and long sideburns, neatly clipped. The Richards family were of wealthy stock in the Eastern United States, many of the younger members converted to the LDS Church. Franklin lived until 1899 with three generations of relatives around him as Mormon leaders.
source: Fredrick Piercy engravings, 1852. All Richards brothers' portraits by Piercy are courtesy of Maurine Ward from article, "Mormon Historical Studies" by L. Matthew Chatterly. Free use.

caption: Scottish garb worn recently by aged Frederick Buchanan, a valiant LDS convert born in Scotland.
description: Buchanan's plaid is of his family's clan, and he also wears a moderate leather sporran in front with leather tassels. His black belt has a pewter buckle. Red tapes are used as knotted garters under his stockings which are folded over at the knees. A warm blue wool tam o'shanter keeps his balding head comfortable. His T-shirt is hardly folk clothing!
source: Because of Buchanan's great sense of humor, he sent Carma this picture of his strong crooked staff to match his great age. His clothing is accurate except for the T-shirt.

caption: Frederick Granger Williams in late 1830s clothing.
description: This early painting shows Williams with a well-shaven face and moderate sideburns. His high-padded collar and gathered sleeves indicate that the painting was done in the 1830s, before his conversion. His tie is a 5 ft. long and 5 inches wide of white lightweight silk wrapped many times around his neck, holding up his starched collar. Tie ends are folded over each other in front and tucked into his vest. He became a counselor in the First Presidency of the LDS Church in 1833.  Williams was originally a ship pilot for Commodore Perry on Lake Erie in the Great Lakes. Missionaries found him, and he and his wife joined the LDS Church. Deeply involved in its growth, Williams was generous with all his financial means to the Prophet Joseph Smith and his work, helping to pay off the Kirtland Temple construction so desperately needed. He was much loved by Joseph Smith for his generosity allowing the Saints to advance spiritually in that glorious temple. Williams 'partial training as a doctor was very much needed in that group of Mormon people. After Ohio, he continued learning at every opportunity while serving patients and saving many lives. He loved the gospel and was a devout preacher in his missionary work.
source: This painting by an unknown artist is owned today by the F.G. Williams family of Provo, Utah. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: Fredricka Karlsdotter, in the 1860s, a girl of high social status from the Kalmar coast in Sweden.
description: This well coifed young woman was raised with much grace and education and talent. She wears a beautiful crown of braids from her long hair. She has good sized drop earrings of silver, and her brooch could be carved flowers from coral. A clean white collar and bow are at her neckline. Fredricka's dress seems to be a light-weight wool with gathers reaching forward from the far-back shoulder seams, and buttons on the front placket. She lived near Kalmar where humbly-born Karl August Anderson was working. Through his attention s to her she discovered and joined the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. from the young man She fell in love with, sweet, handsome Karl, and they married before embarking on a ship to America.. Fredrika lived to an old age in southern Utah.
source: Family photo in possession of Carma and Richard L. Anderson.

caption: A black leather shoe with pointed toe has a small stacked leather French heel for woman of some wealth.
description: This shoe would be worn over fine opaque silk stockings with a modified folk costume or European international style dress. This photocopy of a much worn-out shoe is from the Historical Museum of Alborg, Hjorring, Denmark.
source: Source unknown.

caption: A comfortable family at home, Friendly behavior of Mr. Bucket. 1840s
description: Two gentlemen are seated by a home hearth, smoking very long pipes in comfort, Their artist(exaggerated) narrow trousers are strapped under the shoes, and a third man by the table has a little child on each knee, with his coat buttoned up to the shawl collar. His dark, encompassing silk scarf is tucked in to his vest. All the men have considerable sideburns. The father on the right has extra-full side burns. Both child have all-over aprons on striped dresses, and we can see one "Mary Jane" strapped black shoe. The Hostess stands in her shoulder shawl over a short sleeved dress, with a large white apron tied around her waist. Her day cap with ample ruffles ties under her chin by narrow ribbons. The length of her full skirt is only 4 inches off the floor. She is knitting a stocking during her entrance. In front is a little boy with a very short haircut, slim trousers and a waistcoat only down to his belt. His waistcoat is older-style English, with sleeves in it. He sits on a short stool trying to play a small flute.
source: George Cruikshank illustrated this ink a drawing for Charles Dickens.

caption: English merchant in gaiters traveling toward the area of Ely Cathedral
description: A man wears gaiters over his shoes with many buttons reaching up to his buttoned knee breeches. He carries a walking stick and rests a few moments against a mile marker. Breeches and gaiters were especially typical of British clothing of the period, but Americans gave them up for trousers sooner than Britain did.
source: William Johnstone White, edited by Pamela Clabborn, Working Class Costume from Sketches of Characters, (London, Daedalus Press for Victoria and Albert Museum, by Costume Society, c.o. Department of Textiles. 1977.)

caption: Gardener with his child, 1840 to 1860.
description: This American gardener wears heavy shoes and long trousers to protect his legs. Various shirts and sweaters warm his torso, with a kerchief tied around his neck. His coat is shapeless and shabby over a long apron which covers from chest to his shins. A single-billed cloth cap has a tied-up flap over chopped of hair. He smiles below his mustache. A gardener could wear anything he had, but saved his best clothes for Sunday Church. In one hand is a wooden rake with wooden pegs for tines, and a large watering a can in the other. His little girl holds a potted plant to help. She wears a full-sleeved dress and an all-over apron tied in back.
source: SOURCE has been lost.

caption: George A. Smith in Nauvoo wears coat with matching trousers, 1844,
description: Under a drape of honor" in this painting, George A. Smith in Nauvoo wears a dark coat and trousers, which was not yet termed a suit. But his finest piece of apparel is his enormous, stiff hat on the chair beside him. Made of micro-split straw, it gives an elegant texture and boasts a wide ribbon around the crown. This full-length profile portrait was by Maudsley, who painted every detail of portraits in high quality folk art style, and almost always in profile.
source: Sutcliffe Maudsley, gouache on paper, 1844, owned by Church Archives and seen online.

caption: German blacksmiths
description: wear leather aprons and tight caps. Their shirtsleeves are rolled up in the heat.
source: Source lost.

caption: A German boy in America holding a bundled baby.
description: A country boy holds his little sister who is in a special bundling wrap. It is a piece of stiffened quilted fabric reaching from behind the baby's head, down and over her feet, and returning in front to the baby's chest, It ties around the baby by ribbons in at least three positions. The boy wears a Tyrolean felt hat with the usual feather and flowers in the band. His shoulders have lederhosen straps over his linen shirt.
source: German festival advertisement in Utah, long lost.

caption: German immigrant boy of a well-off family could wear a fine suit with decoration of frogging cords on his jacket. 1840s-50s
description: With a small plume in his pudding felt hat, this boy held a pair of gloves and wore flat-heeled fancy slippers over cotton stockings. He also had an expensive plethora of buttons down the sides of his trousers. Usually their mothers could make their best clothes for Church.
source: by Carma after the painter Klepper, in Europaische Modenzeitung,A German fashion magazine of the past.

caption: German immigrant girl very comfortable in a short shoulder shawl and matching summer dress. 1850s-1860s
description: Pretty double ruffles on a girls shawl matches her summer dress. This ensemble with wide sleeves allows white, puffed, batiste engageants to extend to her forearms from underneath the flaring sleeves.. Broiderie anglaise is tightly ruched around the girls face, releasing her dark ringlets.
source: Drawn by Carma; style from ideas in Der Bazaar, an obsolete German fashion magazine. 1861

caption: German LDS immigrants to Salt Lake City, UT, waiting for admission to America through Castle Garden, New York. Late 1840s to 1890s
description: Most men wear caps or hats. Women wear a head scarf or a fitted embroidered cap from a province of Germany. The little girl in front wears a flat hat over her braided hair. Most women have shawls, some of which assist in carrying their babies. The man standing on the platform in the checkered shirt and over-the-knee boots is one of the adjudicators with officers behind him checking papers. Little boys and girls wear many different kinds of hats. A young woman seated on the platform has on wooden shoes, with possibly colored woolen stockings.
source: This 1800s ink print was purchased in an antique store in Salt Lake City, Utah. A label on the suitcase pictured in center front identifies the immigrant as going to "Salt Lake."

caption: Gingham work dress of beige and red, ca.: 1840s.
description: This gingham work dress is an exact reproduction of an original from the 1840s that has dropped shoulders seams, comfortably narrow, bias cut sleeves and a front bodice opening with hooks. On the left side of the bodice, with the stripes precisely matched, is a sturdy, deep, bound, pocket to hold spectacles. The apron is heavy beige cotton with irregular, tiny, black stripes. Her red petticoat, showing beneath her lifted hem, shows quilting of the wide hem to provide fullness. Over the dark mannequin's head she wears a tied neck shawl plus a very cheap straw hat. This dress has been shown in an LDS film about Jane Manning James, and has been modeled in Carma's numerous fashion shows by Fiona Smith, of London England. It was Sewn by Carma in exact copy of a semi-destroyed dress which had a spectacles pocket in it. Carma obtained cheap $1 per yard plaid gingham made in India, exactly as residents in Mormon Nauvoo, Illinois, would have obtained such cheap cotton fabrics from the same place, exported from India to the western world.
source: Sewn and Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: A little girl takes lunch to her father during the farm's haying time.
description: #?, a small girl takes lunch to her father during the farm's haying time. She wears a wool plaid dress with short sleeves and white pantalets. Her all-over apron is curved up the back to one button at the neckline. A wide-brimmed straw hat is always welcome to a farm girl. Her father with a hand-made wooden hay rake wears only one suspender. Because suspenders were not joined in center-back as modern suspenders are, one suspender could break and be set aside for repair while the other could still hold up the trousers for the day.
source: The girl is Lana Higbee. Father model is Ron Reed, Clothing by Carma. Photo by Wayne Keys

caption: Shoes: Ribbon-laced slipper and ankle high girls or womans bootee with a small stacked heel. 1830s-60s
description: This slipper has a distinctly right-foot sole of later1840s. Only one little childney-shaped layer of cow hide (top) is glued on as the slipper' heel. Bootees were made in many variations of leather with buttons, inset elastic, or fancy ribbon rosettes in front. Bootees might have embroidered edges or contrasting bindings to highlight pretty buttons. A low 1 inch hard leather heel added interest.
source: Drawn by Carma from suggestions by Eunice Wilson, A History of Shoe Fashion, (New York.) Theater Arts Books, 1969). Free use.

caption: Girls dress and pantalets. Little Julia Murdock Smith was adopted as a baby with her twin brother by the Joseph Smith, Jr. family, ca.: 1830s.
description: Julia Murdock Smith is shown here with loving Emma Smith at about age 7 or 8. Julia wears a dress called the French "infant" [say ahn-fahn] style with gathers across the chest, a set-in waistband, and another secure band at the top of the gathers at the shoulder area. She has short, puffed sleeves and four tucks on the hemline for lengthening as she grows. Her white pantalets are edged with Ayrshire embroidery, and her stockings should be white, commercial, cotton knit in her one-strap shoes. Her mother, Emma's, dress has bouffant sleeves at the top and diagonal pleating across the corsage of the bodice. The solid blue and flowered stripes alternate in a beautiful example of 1835 fabric. On April 30, 1831, Emma Smith lost her own premature baby twins in death. The same night, Julia Murdock died giving birth to twins. Following all this grief, John Murdock gave his twins to Joseph and Emma, who wanted to adopt them. The Murdock twins were a balm to Joseph and Emmas broken hearts and John was assured of his childs loving care.
source: This painting by Lynde Madsen Mott was completed with Carma's advice just in time to be used as the cover picture on a biography of Julia by a descendent, John Murdock, in the 1990s.

caption: Little girls white dress of fine muslin with much tucking, ca.: 1840s
description: A cool white dress for summer made in the 1840s with elaborately tucked skirt and inserted lace in sleeves and once around the skirt. This is all in fine hand stitching. Although called a "christening dress. it is actually large enough for a 3-4 year old in pioneer times.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Drawn by Margaret Weber.

caption: Girl in yellow dress with closely pleated sleeves in upper arm wears golden chain jewelry, and holds her doll. Ca.: 1839.
description: This girl of wealth holds her hand-carved wooden doll. She has a slight v-shaped waistline, and sleeves with poufs and wide cuffs. Her long pantalets have tucks and edge lace over black slippers. The flat-woven carpet with wild designs was much in fashion in the early1800s.
source: Artist John Brewster of Connecticut was quite uninformed on fashion rules. As a folk artist, he did not paint her face young enough for her to be playing with dolls, and he makes her skirt much too long for an young girl. Seen in American Heritage April 1960.

caption: Gold miner husband is welcomed home, ca.: 1849-55.
description: Because gold mining was dangerous, the emotion at welcoming home a beloved husband and father from California is very high. The returning husband is wearing a red wool shirt common among all working men of the time. His leather hat, stick and bedroll are dropped on the ground behind. For his son's safe return, the old father gives thanks to God. He wears a dark coat, light trousers and has a crutch. His generous straw hat has a curled brim with a black ribbon around the crown. The happy wife wears a white summer dress with black apron, white stockings and black slippers. Her mother and sister have brown and blue dresses. The older mother's, all-over apron is of print cotton, and she wears a day cap. Two small child crowd around, the girl in a dark print dress and her bonnet falling off. We can barely see the narrow brim of the boy's hat.
source: Painting by Everett L Millard, loaned to The Forty-Niners (Seen in Old West Time-Life Series)1974 and 1980. (Carma unable to locate owner.)

caption: German Grandma Else Marie Jacobsen & two granddaughters. 1840 on
description: Though this is an 1876 picture, it is doubtful that Grandma Jacobsen would be wearing anything different than in earlier years. Many Europeans, as this middle-class German women, did not wear caps on their heads at all times. They were comfortable with a simple small shawl or kerchief over the hair most of their lives. She has a large dark apron as well as a dark skirt, but they would never be of the same fabric. She is wearing her apron in typical Scandinavian style of wrapping the strings around the back and tying them in front. With her are two grandchild, Mary and Amalia Mortensen. It is documented that Mary grew up and joined the Mormons, and probably her little sister did too. But Grandma never joined the Church. Little Mary is seen in a plaid dress of sturdy cotton with four buttons down the front of the bodice and a sheer white apron which has little ruffled straps over the shoulders. Her hair is smoothly pulled back, and she seems to be wearing a very small cap. By 1876 her boots are laced high on her ankles over best white stockings. The baby girl has to have a bib and wears a dress of a different plaid than her sister.
source: This picture of ancestors is courtesy of Maurine Ward, a past editor of the Ensign magazine, Salt lake City, Utah.

caption: Grey wool cape on a wall peg for Lucy Mack Smith, 1830sand 1840s.
description: Mother Lucy Smith's cape hangs on a wall peg in a historic display. On the collar is a banding of pearl grey wool around grey velveteen. The velveteen also outlines the pretty shape of the arm slits where hands and arms can reach through without losing the warmth of the cape. A grey, silky, inside lining has tiny grey checks.
source: Displayed in the Manchester Township, New York home of the Joseph Smith, Sr. Family Historic Site. In this image, the corner of a spinning wheel is temporarily crowded near the cape. Design, sewing, and Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: Gudmunder Gudmundsson
description: Gudmunder Gudmundsson, goldsmith from Iceland in Denmark and his wife (in later years) Marie Garff
source: No source

caption: Sewing diagram of the inside around the waist on each side of the center back seam and up to the waistline gusset.
description: Inside of waistband shows inside seams of trousers, muslin pockets hanging down, and two buttons inside the back to fasten onto separate suspenders. In center back waistline is a bias cut triangle, a single layer of cloth, roll-hemmed, to let out or cinch in by means of a tiny belt sewn onto the outside. These trousers could be taken in for a more slender man only by the side seams at the top, and down to the lower hip.
source: Watercolor sewing diagram by Carma

caption: Jewelry made of loved-one's hair include a ring and the back of a locket containing a small cutting of hair.
description: Jewelry made of loved-one's hair include a ring and the back of a locket containing a small cutting of hair. A black silk tape is worn around the neck holding a hollow gold droplet attached with rings. There is a curl of hair behind thin glass within the gold droplet. Also seen here is a lover's hair tightly woven into an elaborate braid for a finger ring. The ends are tightly held together with a gold fastener.
source: Cat's Cradle Antiques in Provo, Utah allowed Carma to photograph these items

description: CD Hannah Pitt Kington, a female preacher in the Primitive Methodist Church in Herefordshire, could well have dressed in ministerial black. The hanging ribbon lappets from her cap were not excessive in religious opinions of the times. Pinned to hang on the side of her skirt for both jewelry and practicality: a few miniature tools for snipping, cutting a quill pen, and so forth.
source: Historic and reproduced clothing for Kathy Staff in Little Dorrit. Photo by Snowdon

caption: A Harmonist Utopian group lived together in Missouri and shared all their labors. 1800s
description: The Harmonists were of German origins in America. The men wear the same tall crowned felt hats with brims about 3.5 inches wide. Their vests are high buttoned at the neck with small rounded collars. One elderly man wears a coat, probably without tails. Their trousers are often medium to dark. The woodcut makes trousers appear striped, but they are solid colors. The women wear roomy, comfortable dresses without tight bodices, and the length is generally down to their shoes. Females' hats have wide brims that curve down at the sides. Low crowns have no flower decorations, but only simple bands of cloth around them. Aprons are all a light color. Small collars could be worn or not over bodices that open down the front. A young girl in center wears braids down her back, but other females wear a snood or a bob.
source: This is a woodcut print of Missouri Harmonists. Article by Carol Piper Hemming, "Temples Stand," Missouri Historical Review, October 1990.

caption: A hat factory shows various stages in producing felt hats. Mid 1800s
description: In hat manufacture, wool felt had to be mixed with some amount of animal fur to make better textured hats. (There were also simple, all-wool, shapeless, brimless hats made for the poor.) In the center vat, over a fire, the men mix the wool with fur in water so the damp slurry can be shaped on wooden molds. The man on right is pressing the felt against the wooden mold with a wooden tool. The men wear canvas aprons to protect their clothes, and sleeves are rolled high to protect from dyes. The men on left are finishing hats by brushing those that are already shaped and dried. Some nicer hats were bound on the brims with narrow grosgrain ribbon. Carma has been through all the operations explained in this very hattery preserved in Danbury, Connecticut. Hats were made this way from 1600s on.
source: : Hat manufacture in Danbury, CN, is a woodcut seen in Carol Belanger Grafton, Ed., Trades and Occupations: A Pictorial Archive from Early Sources (Dover Pictorial Archive, August 1, 1990).

caption: Heber C. Kimball in excellent wool gift cloak over his shabby suit. Ca.: 1843.
description: Heber was a humble potter who could not afford to dress well. When Joseph sent him to England to open a mission, he was horrified to have to face many well dressed, educated English people: but he felt called by God and was determined to go. A former friend, Lyman Johnson, met him on the streets of early Nauvoo, and, learning of his intense desire to go, took the fine cloak off his own back, and put it on Heber.
