Johnson, himself, was faltering in the LDS Church at that time, but was so impressed with Kimballs strong faith, he donated his own best cloak to Kimball to encourage him! Such clothing would be absolutely necessary to cross the Atlantic and brave the winds and rains of Britain. This cloak most likely had an expensive rain caplet over the shoulders, valuable for Heber's years in Britain, with much walking outdoors to preach.
source: Orson F. Whitney, The Life of Heber C. Kimball (Salt Lake City, Stevens and Wallace, Inc. 1945.) Drawn by Carma; free use.

caption: Hugh Miller, here a gravestone cutter, is a brawny young man, probably a red-head, wearing his white work sleeves rolled up and an old wool vest and trousers.
description: Multi-talented Hugh Miller is carving a gravestone with chisel and stone hammer. His heavy woolen broadfall work trousers were likely lined with durable muslin, and are high-waisted. Hughs high cut vest is much wrinkled and mostly unbuttoned. His hair looks like a typical redheads curls. Short whiskers reach to the corner of his mouth and under his chin. Hugh was actually a geologist, stonemason, paleontologist, folklorist, artist and writer born in Cromarty, Scotland. Though an editor in Edinburgh at the time of this calotype, he chose to have his common work clothing photographed by Hills and Adamson. Though a self-taught and much admired geologist, Hugh finally moved to Edinburgh where he became editor of The Witness to express his deep Christianity. Fearing that his increasing migraines and psychotic episodes might cause him to harm wife or child, he committed suicide in 1857. Scotland mourned his passing.
source: Taken by David BruceandDavid Octavius Hill, original creators of caloypes of 1840s. Also seen online.

caption: Drawing of Hyrum Smith in Nauvoo, 1844, by Sutcliffe Maudsley.
description: Hyrum was a fairly narrow-headed, tall man in the 1840s. Although the body is primitive in art, the head is carefully drawn, with the hair style clear. He is dressed in a coat with fashionable buttonhole strips on each lapel-- which were never buttoned all the way up, but were simply the fashion for coats. Buttons and buttonholes on the same side meant it could be buttoned closed in either direction, right or left. The cuffs were narrow on comfortably slim sleeves. From the 1830s on, there was reduced fullness on the tops of mens coats sleeves, but still a bit of gathering, here. All the men of the family were unusually tall for that generation, with Hyrum being about 2 inches taller than his brother Joseph, who was over 6 ft. tall.
source: by Sutcliffe Maudsley. This image from BYU Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Iceland Fisherman standing.
description: This fisherman in a small boat has considerable hair and beard; and it helps keep him warm. He stands in his fishing boat and must turn up his pants as far as possible to keep dry. He may be fortunate enough to have rubber boots, or they may be oiled leather. Above his roomy pants with suspenders is a heavy striped wool shirt. His loose jacket and ample muffler help warm him. His leather cap appears to have no brim. In the distance of rocky Iceland is a church steeple in the village.
source: Frederick W. W. Howell. F.R.G.S, Icelandic PicturesDrawn with Pen and Pencil, (Flemming H. Revell Co., New York, no date) p. 101.Republished by Ulan Press (August 31, 2012).

caption: Icelandicdescendents in 2015 wearing reproduced folk costumes.
description: The seyoung women dress for the annual Icelandic founding celebration of Spanish Fork, Utah. One girl has elegant lace in the V-necked yoke of her blouse. The other has a plain high neck and "snid" sleeves, narrow at the top and full at the wrists. Girl on right has a long-tasseled cap called a "skatufa." Silver or gold chains lace the bodices together over lovely scrolled hooks. Matching jewelry belts adorn the waistlines.
source: Photo in The Sentinel Newspaper, Spanish Fork, Utah, 2015

caption: Icelandic folk costumes
description: No description
source: From internet, altered by Lorie.

caption: Icelandic modern models, one with an ancestral Paisley shawl, and the other with a black wool shawl.
description: These beautiful women are wearing typical silk plaid aprons over long, black wool skirts. Both wear the Scotufa: a black velvet cap with silver binding at the top of a long, black, silk tassel.
source: From Icelandic postcards brought to CarmainUtah by friends.

caption: Icelandic washer women by hot volcanic water.
description: Icelandic washer women by hot volcanic water. Usual length of skirts and petticoats is above the ankles and only slightly full. Each wears a neckerchief or small light shawl around her neck, pinned securely. Their sleeves must be rolled up to their elbows to keep dry.After hand-wringing, the clean laundry goes into the wooden tub for the trip, to dry closer to home.
source: Wandering Through Iceland, byFrederick W. W. Howell (author), Icelandic Pictures Drawn With Pen And Pencil, (The Religious Tract Society; 1st ed. 1893). Reprint by Nabu Press; Primary Source ed. (September 6, 2013)

caption: Icelandic two-thumbed mitten & sheepskin shoe.
description: Icelandic wool yarn was strong and springy. This mitten was cleverly made with a thumb on each side so it could be reversed during fishing when one side became soewhat wet. Home-made sheep-skin shoes, called"pampooties," are the simplest possible piece of leather, reinforced inside by cording. They were dryable overnight by the fireside
source: Frederick W. W. Howell. F.R.G.S, Icelandic PicturesDrawn with Pen and Pencil, (Flemming H. Revell Co., New York, no date) p. 101.Republished by Ulan Press (August 31, 2012).

caption: From Iceland, a woman's folk costume usually has a skotufa tassel headdress
description: This drawing shows a small Icelandic black velvet cap with a Skotufa tassel emerging in center. The tassel is decorated at the top with a silver cylinder, if possible. Since women often had lighter colored hair, the black tassel was a good contrast.  Horn was one of the few materials available on site in Iceland which are appropriate for eating utensils, men's buttons, combs, and sometimes even small bowls. This antique spoon has a highly carved handle.
source: Frederick W. W. Howell. F.R.G.S, Icelandic PicturesDrawn with Pen and Pencil, (Flemming H. Revell Co., New York, no date). Republished by Ulan Press, August 31, 2012.

caption: Immigrants sailing in steerage with double bunks. On the right is a dance underway in the aisle
description: A packet boat from Bremerhaven, Germany to New York. A double bunk was large enough to have whole families sleeping  together. On left is a guitarist singing to allay boredom for those who were sick and could not go on deck. If they were well, some folks got up  to dance to any music. At first there was inadequate prevention of sick people boarding ships. The situation grew out of hand until people died  rapidly on what became "plague ships. Many immigrant ships were frustrating to captains and crews because there was much fighting,  drunkenness and filth below decks. However, ships carrying the Mormons from Britain were so well organized within the first hour that there  was calm and organization with singing every night, and enjoyment, and worship on the Sabbath with meetings on deck. This greatly impressed  captains and crews. One captain proclaimed after his first crossing with Mormons "I will happily take any group of Mormon Immigrants across  the ocean in preference to others, because these religious people are very clean, and help each other."
source: Mary Cable, "Damned Plague Ships and Swimming Coffins," (American Heritage Magazine, August1960).Public Domain image.

caption: Infant or toddler Boy dress for Joseph Smith III, ca.:1834
description: High-quality cotton is dotted with tiny rosebuds of orange and red on beige background. This is the typical infant style of dress with a set-in waistband and gathers across the chest. There is a straight grain binding of the same fabric across the neckline and over the shoulders. Very short, puffed sleeves are gathered-in at the lower edge by a narrow facing. Both boys and girls wore dresses until age 4 or 5 to make potty functions easier.
source: Dress for Joseph Smith III, was made by Lynde Madsen Mott to use in an oil painting. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: British innkeeper with table full of guests, first half of 1800s.
description: This innkeeper with his neatly cut hair supervises a table full of his guests. Because he is in charge, he wears a small (very British) bouquet pinned on n the front of his vest. His shirt has narrow sleeves, and the vest collar seems to be turned up around his neck as he goes indoors and out. His short clothes (breeches) have tied garters at the knees to hold up his stockings.  He is ever dutiful to fill the needs of the ladies and gentlemen. The guests sit at table with hats on, as some do not stay overnight. The man on the close end has low gaiters over his ankles. Guests are dressed in styles of 1810-20s.
source: William Johnstone White, edited by Pamela Clabborn, Working Class Costume from Sketches of Characters, (London, Dedalus Press for Victoria and Albert Museum, by Costume Society, c. o. Department of Textiles. 1977.)

caption: This Irish countryman is in his everyday work clothes, gathering Blackthorne sticks.
description: Under a smashed flat cap of tweed over short hair chopped off, this craftsman is wearing his old cutaway coat, which slanted back from a shorter front opening, rounding to 12 longer in the back tails. This style of coat almost died out in the 1800s. The coat is lined, and made of thick Irish wool, closed with only one button at the neck. Wrinkled from constant wear, his vest is high buttoned over a barely seen light linen shirt. Patched breeches are buttoned just below the knees His stockings are wooly and sloppy, not held up by knotted garters. He has sturdy, wide leather shoes that tie in front.  . Here are a good many straight Blackthorn sticks to fashion into Shillelaghs, mens personal cudgels or walking sticks carried in many troubled regions in Ireland for physical defense or offense with enemies. Blackthorn wood is first coated with lard or butter, then placed well inside a chimney to cure for many days. This gives the shillelagh a black, shiny appearance. It can be used as a weapon as well as a walking support, especially with a rounded head in the upper handle. Decades ago this original image of a jovial Oirishman was popular and used in all sorts of traditional printing and postcards.
source: Public domain image

caption: A quantity of good Irish wool is required to make such an elegant cloak.
description: This Irish cloak could have been made in gray or red wool. It has a broad collar over the attachment of the voluminous hood. In bitter cold, the hood is pulled up, which keeps the neck warm. Inside the hood is silk lining or the collar which can rise around the neck. Such a large hood could have covered a hat. The woman has her hair properly covered in a white or dark day-cap.
source: Anne O'Dowd, curator of the National Museum of Ireland Permission.

caption: Irish grandma wearing a bed-gown and shawl and gathering firewood.
description: This old woman wears a big linen apron over her black wool skirt. Her bed-gown is likely red wool, and embroidered on the cuffs, rather than hemmed. Over her shoulders is a dark plaid shawl with fringe and folded in a triangle. Her firewood is wrapped in a thick blanket. Around her head is a smaller light-colored shawl with fringe over a ruched white day cap. Her shoes are various grades of leather. A clutch of twisted roots is in her left hand.
source: Anne O'Dowd AT BYU PERMISSIONS

caption: A western Irishman wears a frieze swallowtail coat, corduroy breeches, and a farmer's old top hat.
description: Walking on muddy streets to his farm, this man wears thick woolen stockings and heeled shoes. He has breeches and a double-breasted cutaway coat of blue or gray wool, and carries a rope for one of his animals. A silk neckerchief is simply tied around his shirt collar. Long hair iscomfortable and common in the countrytowns.
source: Anne O'Dowd Permission

caption: Irish street bagpipe player.
description: Most people believe that the Scotts invented the bagpipe, but that is incorrect. There were bagpipes in Ireland before there ever were in Scotland. This small man has a foot on a resting place on his cane as he serenades the neighborhood. He wears a heavy wool black coat and trousers that are splashed with mud, as are his laced-up shoes from the rainy earthen streets. His hat is old warm felt. He enjoys his job a great deal, especially when he is tipped with a little money. Usually the Irish bagpipes have a dark colored plaid on the bags (seen under his arm).
source: Cover of book of Irish Songs, published in Dublin.

caption: Reproduced WorkingSmock of light brown Irish linen for an English Yorkshire Gardner,
description: Gardenerplayed by docent, who actually was the son of a professional Yorkshire gardener from England. The Pioneer Profiles costumed actors performed for about 25 years after the opening of the Museum of Church History and Art in the 1980s. on West Temple St. Recent uses have been changing.
source: Designed by Carma with smocking accomplished by Nancy West before Carma sewed parts of smock together. Made for Salt Lake City MCHA.

caption: Andrew Jackson is painted in later years with his unique double-lens spectacles. One set of lenses is before his eyes, and a second set can swing forward over the first.
description: Jacksons side lens could swing forward on a tiny hinge to cover the permanent lens. Possibly this was so he could see well in most situations with the forward lens, but swing over the second lens for closeup work, such as reading. It would be a clever convenience for someone who didnt want to frequently change spectacles for different purposes. Another consultant says that such an arrangement was sometimes used in which the side lens was smoked to conveniently shade sunlight.
source: Found on Google Art Project, File: James Tooley, Jr. - Portrait of Andrew Jackson (1840). Free use.

caption: Jedediah M. Grant with multicolored plaid vest, ca.:1840s.
description: His flamboyant vest collar has simple lapels. His black silk tie buttons together in the back. Only the tips of the turned down shirt collar are visible below a scant chin line beard. With his hair brushed to one side, it is cut at the upper ears. Jedediah (1816 1856) was a fiery preacher and Apostle of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, and father of later President Heber J. Grant. He died of pneumonia at only 40 years old, tragically leaving his wife, Rachel Ridgeway Ivins Grant to raise their son of nine days old.
source: A composite of two online pictures were combined to get the desired facial portrait and one of his flamboyant vests. Both are found with search term: Jedediah M. Grant images. Free use.

caption: Jewelry purse: open, and rolled up to tie in a ball.
description: Made of various fabrics: all calicos or heavier figured silk. In smaller compartments many things could be carried: money, jewelry, medicine, hair pins, etc.
source: Drawn by Carma from many she has seen, at historic villages and homes in the New England states

caption: John Lyon of Scotland. Steel engraving by Frederick H. Piercy.
description: John is neatly coifed and dressed in the European fashion of the Mid- 800s.   Born in Glasgow in 1803 in extreme poverty, it took him until age 25 to learn to read. After that he quickly made up for lost time , and became a teacher. He loved the beauty of words and developed into the greatest poet of many in the LDS church in the 1800s.
source: Frontispiece of the biography John Lyon by His Grandson, T. Edgar Lyon Jr Permission given verbally by telephone to Carma for any pictures.

caption: John Paul Cardon from the Piedmont of Italy has a short beard and moustache.
description: John Pauls hair is shorter than Jeans, with a dark short beard and moustache, but no sideburns. His tie is a fairly modern knot and tucked down into his vest. Wide, notched lapels show the style of 1860. His vest also could have notched lapels.
source: Genevieve Porter Johnson and Edna Cardon Taylor,compilers, Cardons! Descendents of Philippe Cardon and Marthe Marie Tourn 1799-1886, (Provo, Utah, Stevenson's Genealogy Center, 1990) Permission from Larry C. Porter.

caption: Joseph Smith, Jr. and a little girl picking flowers. ca.: 1842
description: This little girl wears a pink dress with white pantalets below. Her soft sunbonnet tied beneath her chin has fallen back off her braided hair. Mercy Fielding Thompson's daughter was so downcast after her father, Robert, died in Nauvoo. Joseph Smith took her for a country ride in a buggy to cheer her. Spying some wildflowers, he stopped, jumped down and picked her a personal bouquet.
source: Detail of an oil painting courtesy of Liz Lemon Swindle. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: Joseph Smith Jr. mannequin seated at a historic table and chair of his time period, ca.: 1845.
description: Joseph Smith at a table, writing. This excellent mannequin was made by LDS Displays long ago. Carma designed his clothing: the first representation, ever, of the Prophet Joseph Smith wearing LINEN, which was appropriate and much used in the hot, humid weather of the Midwest. He is seated at an Empire style table made at the time of his birth, 1806. His frock coat is of pumpkin-colored linen with a pleated opening in the center back skirt. A tiny white piping surrounds all edges of his coat but the hemline. Pocket flaps over his hips are sewn into the waistline seam and are also piped in white. Buttons in the front tabs are medium sized while those on the coat cuffs are small. Two buttons at the back waistline pleats are large. All made to look like correct white bone for that period. This design was made from a white linen frock coat which was an 1845 antique Carma bought in the Northeast USA (shown elsewhere). Smith's trousers are cotton/linen of narrow, equal stripes of beige and soft green. They have bottom straps, buttoned under the shoe sole, that hold trousers neatly down on the leg. A vest of mottled beige linen with a shawl collar covers his fine white linen shirt. Small black and gold designs grace the silky cravat which wraps around his standing collar to button in the back. His boots have proper square toes.
source: The LDS Historic Sites Exhibits made this accurate mannequin and originally put it in Joseph Smiths Vermont Birthplace Site. However, the clothing was totally incorrect. Later they enlarged the site and asked Carma to make new and better clothes. She dressed him entirely in linen for the hot sticky weather of the Midwest, seated at a Nauvoo table with assorted papers he owned and used. Never before had he been shown wearing proper linen for an Illinois summer. Years later, when this exhibit was exchanged for another, it was all transported to Salt Lake City and warehoused. In the 1980s, Carma desired some of the clothing for display, and the Church gave her the entire mannequin, plus the use of Church furniture. It was placed behind glass in the 2005 Joseph Smith 200th Birthday Exhibit in the Joseph Smith Building on BYU Campus. Carma made all this clothing and used her own 1840s books to display on the table. The exhibit extended to 6 months, allowing 33,000 people to view this scene of 11 dressed mannequins over a summer and into winter. It joined with displays showing men, women and child of Joseph's entire lifetime (1805-1844).  Clothing and hair designed by Carma, and clothing made by Carma. All the white piping on the coat was finished by her granddaughter Rachel Hamblin, a 15 year old assistant in Vermont. Free use.

caption: Prophet Joseph Smith and Council of Twelve Apostles, 1844, in a fictional grouping painted later.
description: Several styles of coats, ties and trousers are shown, though not sharply clear. The heads seem to have been painted in last copying different original sources, and so are somewhat out of proportion for most bodies. As always in 1800s images, the feet are shown as tiny, which was considered only proper for important or fashionable people. Both Joseph and his brother Hyrum were assassinated June 27, 1845, From left: Hyrum Smith, Willard Richards, Secretary, at the table, Joseph Smith standing and preaching, Orson Pratt, Parley P. Pratt, Orson Hyde, Heber C. Kimball, and Brigham Young. The men are wearing their best black coats with mostly black ties except Orson Hyde who wears a dark blue and grey-tan trousers. Honored with a white tie are Joseph, his secretary, Willard, and his brother, Hyrum.
source: LDS Church Archives and online. Date when painting was created is unknown.

caption: Joseph Smith Jr.'s warm cloak was of spun wool blended with goat hair on the outside and "bear cloth" lining on the inside. 1840s
description: Joseph Smith Jr.'s warm, blue cloak was water-resistant owing to the goat hair blend. Goat hair cloth is very springy and swells when wet to become waterproof. This photo is only part of the original, which had a broad rain collar over the shoulders and a blue velvet collar at the neck. We see a beautifully-shaped velvet guard over each arm-slit, with tiny blue velvet buttons added for decoration. The neckline is closed with two metal buttons and a chain between. It was made by Smith's favorite Nauvoo tailor, Colonel Bills of the Nauvoo Legion, who gave it to beloved Joseph as a gift.The lining of "bear cloth" is a 1inch thick shag of faded wool woven into a dense fur-like fabric, which would prove enormously warm. Carma handled the cloak and pulled open the yarns of the lining. There she found that it was not originally brown, but bright green in the early construction of the cloak.The cloak was handed back to the Bills family after Josephs death. They wore it for at least another generation during which the outside fabric was torn and heavily mended in different colors of thread. Someone in the tailor's family could have taken off the wide upper rain collar and used it for a little childs coat.
source: The tailor's descendants gave this cloak to the Museum of Church History and Art. Photo by Carma at a modern exhibition. Free use.

caption: Joseph and Hyrum Smith wear best clothes in The Two Martyrs, ca, 1844
description: A well-known lithograph was made to honor the two martyrs of Mormon leadership, Joseph and Hyrum Smith. This image shows their very different body types, but not true heights. These big men were depicted conventionally with tiny feet to indicate their refinement, and all their hair was smoothly coifed, even to Hyrum's characteristically long sideburns. They both wore light, strapped-under trousers with darker tail coats, and sleeve cuffs turned down formally. It is barely discernible that Hyrum is also wearing a light, if not white, vest, as is Joseph. This artist made the Prophet taller than his older brother, which was not true to their actual heights, but was meant to emphasize Josephs No.1 importance. Hyrum was actually 2 to 2  inches taller than Joseph, and was lean and lanky with a narrower forehead.
source: The Two Martyrs, Joseph & Hyrum Smith, an engraving from England after their deaths. Library of Congress: lithograph by Sarny & Major, 1847.)

caption: Detail of Joseph Smith and Brigham Young in, flat-brimmed top hats. Ca.:1843
description: CD fig : In a collage based on a painting Joseph Smith talks with Brigham young, both wearing broad-brimmed top hats. Carma has manipulated the painting, replacing some of the background busyness to better display the hats.
source: Collage by Carma from a forgotten artist. Free use.

caption: John Smith wears matching suit pieces, the new mode. This style ca.: 1846 to mid-1860
description: In this daguerreotype, the uncle of Joseph Smith Jr. wore very dark trousers with a matching coat, this suit was a new fashion in mens clothing. An old vest of the l830s is buttoned up very high, but shows the silk of his tie. His frock coat is completely skirted, and his shoulders are free of padding, making them narrow at the sleeve tops. Above a starched, turned-down collar and a bow tie, Smith still had considerable gray hair cut below his earlobes (portrait of face and hairstyle is elsewhere in this document). Even with the best of clothes in the mid-1800s, it was impossible to keep shined shoes because of muddy or dusty roads of hard beaten earth everywhere people could walk. This gentle man lived a very reverent and spiritual life to his death. Smith was tall and lanky all his life, which caused unusual difficulties for photographers. They always used photo stands to hold the necks of subjects steady for the full required time of exposing the image. But the man had to find enough books to stack behind John in order to get his stand high enough to grip the back of Johns neck. The stand is seen behind Johns calves, humorously resting on top of the stacked books. Still, the slight blur of his hands indicates a little movement. The necessity of remaining perfectly motionless for up to 90 seconds is why most old photos show unsmiling faces. After his brother, Joseph Smith Sr. died in Nauvoo, John became Patriarch to the entire Church. Later, in Salt Lake City, John was called by Brigham Young to be president of the first large Salt Lake Stake. A stake is a collection of 5 to 15 congregations, or wards.
source: Online picture from Covey-Richards Family History Website, The Dearies., http://www.thedearies.com/2012/04/john-smith.html.

caption: Karl August Anderson, portrait of early 1860,a few years after his marriage in Sweden to Fredricka.
description: This young man had blondish hair with a short beard on the jaw-line, and sideburns shaved off. His collar and black tie were short for the 1860s, with a very narrow tie. A simple pleated placket buttons his shirt front opening of a short opening placket. THe shirt is alwats a pull-over from the 1800s. His coat is wool, fashionable but not heavy, with buttonholes on the lapels. There is obvious top-stitching on edges. He could afford no jewelry on his shirt because he worked very hard building roads, and was fortunate to build one near his future wife, Fredricka. She listened when Karl became acquainted with her and he taught her the Restored Gospel of Jesus Christ. To the horror and astonishment of her wealthy family, she insisted on leaving Sweden. The young couple were married as soon as she had her baggage ready. and they left for Western America with thousands of other LDS converts.  Karl was born and converted to the LDS Church in Karlskrone, Blekinge, the smallest province on the southern tip of Sweden. Missionaries helped his whole family to emigrate to Utah. Karl is the second great grandfather of Carma's husband, Richard L. Anderson.
source: Family photos held by Carma and Richard L. Anderson.

caption: Two examples of borders for printed shawls on white wool challis or kashmir wool--always in many colors, not black and white.
description: When real woven paisley shawls from India and Paisley Scotland were going out of fashion, Edinburg, Scotland and London, England, and even France, began printing paisley designs on light weight white wool. This produced a shawl that would still be marketable, and cheaper. There was a new generation of buyers, with some sentiment for the complicated former designs, so the printers lengthened by decades the new market for paisley shawls.
source: Design motifs from 'Les Cachemires de l'Inde,' Musee des Inateurs de Fabrique 1837, Clabburn, for making real tapestry shawls; but later shawls referred to such designs for printing, not weaving., FREE

caption: Katherine Horrocks Shawl from Scotland
description: No description
source: Unknown

caption: Toddler's dress pattern and dress, 1840s to 60s.
description: This simple dress was at the International Museum of Photography in the George Eastman House. Carma measured this dress to see how the pattern was made, and has drawn where a facing with drawstrings will gather the neckline and sleeves. Note how the front neckline is cut slightly deeper, and how the finished dress will look. Tucks were often put in at the hemline to lengthen the dress later for a growing boy or girl, as we see here. The dress would be found in the western world made of white lawn, or slightly heavier, good, white muslin, more likely than in silk for baby's constant washing.
source: International Museum of Photography in the George Eastman House, Rochester, New York. Drawn by Carma. Free use.

caption: Child in a blue dress with dog. ca.: 1848
description: A four-year-old child of wealth stands holding a small whip and a toy, with a table knife on the floor. Little boys and girls in this era wore identical clothing and, often, hair styles, so the gender of the child is uncertain. However, the whip and the strong color may indicate a boy. Fancy red stockings with black diamonds descend to black bootees. White ruffled pantalets are gathered under the knees.  Parents loved bare shoulders on little child because they were so beautiful and kissable, so almost all childs dresses have wide necklines with bare shoulders. Within the wide-neckline is a coral necklace "to protect health," with matching small bracelet A blue satin bonnet with ostrich plumes is thrown carelessly on the floor in this wealthy home. A large beloved dog fills the other half of the portrait.
source: This painting from 1848 by famous William Matthew Prior hangs in the New York State Historical Association in Cooperstown, New York.

caption: Joseph Smith III as a young boy, 1842.
description: The adolescent oldest son of Joseph Smith Jr. is painted in a short tunic with many small buttons from shoulder to the waist. Emma Smith liked to put white, large-collared shirts on her sons, stylish in the 1830s. There is a glimpse of white shirt cuffs as well. He wears straight-leg trousers. Short cut hair is brushed forward on the sides, as was his father's. He stands on highly figured carpet holding a book. An ornate, imaginary window is painted in position behind him, which did not exist in any of the city homes of Nauvoo environs.
source: Gouache on paper by Sutcliffe Maudsley, Seen in Steven Buhl's Sutcliffe Maudsley: Nauvoo Profilist, and LDS Church Archives.

caption: child of dire poverty, 1830s, 1840s and later.
description: Some child of these decades had no means of support at all. They were either orphans, or their parents had vanished into drink, crime, or jail. In some places there were work houses set up to feed the destitute minimal food and give them a place to sleep in exchange for slave labor and horrifying conditions. Such are the child in the novel, Oliver Twist, by Charles Dickens. Such are the child in this daguereotype captured by police as theives, male prostitutes or theiving assistants to older persons. They are about to be jailed for their crimes. Society did not seem to find any way to reform them. But how else could they eat? How else could they survive with a semblance of freedom? Their clothing, all in complete rags, still kept them warmer than nakedness. Note that even such young miscrants try to cling to typical fashion by wearing coats, vests, and even cravats above worn out, torn and threadbare trousers or breeches. One has a cap. Two of them are barefoot. The smallest boy is wearing an unidentifyable rag in leiu of a coat to hold in a fragment of warmth. His shoes are many sizes too large, but at least his feet are covered.
source: Found online under 1840 boys clothing images.

caption: Toddler boys or girls red velveteen jacket with deep lace cuffs, ca.: 1840.
description: This toddlers jacket still has its original buttons of silvery metal. Over a little boys short trousers and white stockings, It would have been an engaging piece of clothing, or equally would have kept a little girl warmer, worn over her dress. The jacket was evidently hand washed (the only form of cleaning in 1800s) and the red dye has tinted the lace cuffs pink. It lies on a typical black and white woven coverlet of geometric design.
source: A woman missionary donated and placed this jacket for display on a bed in a historic home in Nauvoo, Illinois. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: A watercolor of two young child with their dog, 1845.
description: A sister on left and a toddler brother on right each hold a pink ribbon attached to their pretty King Charles spaniel.  The little boy in a wicker chair wears a red dotted dress and a white all-over apron and has a necklace of coral beads "for good health." He holds a toy in one hand. Below his striped stockings we see a one little lace-up bootee; he has kicked off the other one.  His older sister has a beautiful, dark blue, silk dress with fringe on the shirred sleeves. Around her wide neckline is a band of the same dress fabric. She has simply center-parted long hair, with barely-seen looped braids behind her ears. She has a fine, long, black necklace and white pantalets with a lace inset near the hem. So common was the desire to admire soft baby skin, both child have bare shoulders. For the wealthy, family pets were regularly painted with child.
source: Painting by Matthew Prior, 1845, seen in Old Sturbridge Village, Sturbridge, Massachusetts

caption: Little girl dress of 1840s Nauvoo, Illinois.
description: A little girl in a dotted red dress wears a bonnet of printed white cotton. Her dress has pleats over the shoulders to narrow the dress from her older sister, and the hem was taken up as much as possible. As she grows, the dress can be enlarged as needed but is temporarily too long. Her gray stockings are worn with flat black slippers. She is seen in a country store setting with a sack of potatoes and other produce around her, which is the stage for a historic fashion show decades ago.
source: Stage store arranged and clothes sewn by Carma in Edgemont area of Provo, Utah. Modeled by Katherine Hamblin (now Baxter). Free use.

caption: Young Matilda Price's fancy sky blue dress is worn with longer cotton pantalets, ca.: 1840.
description: A V-shaped bodice has tucks that reach over Matilda's shoulders to her front waistline point, and more that decorate the edges of her short sleeves. She plays in trimmed pantalets, white stockings, and little black slippers with ankle straps. Her hair is simply cut to be tucked behind her ears, and her wooden doll is nicely dressed. This all indicates an affluent family. (See her slightly older brother in a plaid dress under boys clothes).  The Prices became Mormons in the 1840s or 50s, and brought the watercolors (artist not recorded) with the family to Utah from Birmingham, England.
source: Salt Lake City DUP. Museum Watercolors by unknown artist. Photo by Carma; free use

caption: Girl's calico dress, apron, and pantalets. 1840s
description: During the 1840s there were many cotton textiles with black, purple or other dark backgrounds highlighting bright flowers or figures. This little girls cheery print is a summer dress with a cover-all apron that curves upward in the back to fasten with a single button at the bound neckline. The white cotton pantalets have tucks above the hem for enhancement and to lengthen with growth.  The girl's lovely, blond hair is simply parted in the middle and hangs down freely all around. In this 1840s style, her mother may have rolled damp ends of hair around strips of cotton "rags" overnight to curl it while it dried
source: Sewn by Carma. Photo by Wayne Kees. Free use.

caption: This adolescent girl wears a sprigged calico dress in shades of earth colors, ca.: 1840s style.
description: Though painted in 1850, this is a dress style which began in the 1840s featuring gathering from the seams on the back of the shoulders extending down across the bodice and into the front waistline point. It appears as a ''fan-shaped" bodice. Narrow sleeves are cut on the bias, and self-fabric cuffs are at the wrists. The gathered skirt has layers of petticoats to stand out full. Her brunette hair has specially curled ringlets all the way around.
source: Seen at Princeton University Art Museum, Balkan Collection.

caption: Home-made dresses on young sisters, 1840s,
description: Two girls between 8 and 10 wear matching clothing: blue cotton dresses gathered in at the waistline with belts. Diagonal tucks in the sleeves appear almost as cap sleeves over elbow-length sleeves. Sleeves and neckline have a little trim of lace. Long pantalets of white and pale blue are trimmed with a bit of lace, and reach down to black, square-toed booties that lace up the inside. Center parted hair is drawn back into either a braid or a small bob. Each carries a small basket or bouquet of flowers.
source: child of the Young Republic in American Heritage April 1960.

caption: Young Arthur John Price wears a plaid dress, as typical of boys age 3-6 in the mid-1800s. Short pantalets are beneath. ca.: 1840
description: Young Arthur John Price wears a plaid dress, as typical of boys about 3-6 years old in the 1800s. His gender is also indicated by short, cut-off hair. Arthur has a toy hoop and stick and wears good shoes, lace-edged pantalets, and white ankle stockings. This indicates an affluent family, (See his sister Matilda in a girls dress of pale blue).
source: From Birmingham, England, seen in Salt Lake City MCHA. Photo by Carma; free use

caption: Finer dresses of 1845 in folk-art painting of Anna Gould Crane and granddaughter, Janette Young.
description: Janette wears a yellow, calico print dress with tiny red sprigs, and has simple tubes for pantalets. Her little chemisette barely shows at the neckline of her wrap-over bodice. Curls fall over her shoulders onto her bodice. White stockings and flat black shoes are greatly exaggerated as elegantly (and inhumanly) small.  Grandmother Anna has a perfectly smooth, white, neck shawl pinned over the shoulders of her black, full- skirted dress. In folk-art style, her head is over-large, with a very meager day cap. One foot showing is the size of a finger.  This painting has a faux frame painted around the edge of the stretched canvas.
source: Oil on canvas by Sheldon Peck, Aurora, Illinois. Seen in book, American Radiance: The Ralph Esmerian Gift to the American Folk Art Museum. (New York, Harry N. Abrams, Inc. 2001)

caption: Girl in a flounced blue dress of 1840s seen on a tinted Postcard.
description: Flounced blue dress on a girl of 1840s from a tinted Postcard. A young girl wears a pale blue dress with a flounced skirt. Three pleats on her shoulder seams are anchored in a V at her waistline. She seems to have bell sleeves with matching engageants below. Her straight hair, parted in the middle, is fastened in back with a large black bow. Originally a sepia toned daguerreotype, this image looks more realistic with tinting.
source: A loose tinted postcard with no artist listed, Purchased at J. Paul Getty Museum, printed by Chronicle Books, 1200 Getty Center Dr., Los Angeles, CA 90049.

caption: Adolescent girl carrying her basket-purse, standing beside her bonnet, ca.: 1848-58.
description: A pre-teen with smooth hair wears a fancy silk day dress. It is of brown and white checks with an overhanging peplum and a small white lace collar. One inch wide brown ribbons edged in white reach from the middle of her shoulders down to the peplum, where they form a border. Narrow sleeves are cut on the bias and flare out over her forearms with two lines of ribbon for decoration. Narrow engageants are pure white batiste to the wrists. She wears a short string of (possibly) gold beads, and tiny, ball earrings. Her yellow straw bonnet with wide white ribbons lies on a table beside her. It has ruching on the brim's edge. Her unique purse is a tiny, footed, basket-shape with two loop handles.
source: A loose tinted postcard with no artist listed, Purchased at J. Paul Getty Museum, printed by Chronicle Books, 1200 Getty Center Dr., Los Angeles, CA 90049.

caption: A wealthy girl giving money to a poor girl, 1847.
description: The poor girl has an old shawl and apron and sits on the ground outside a church. Her small cap is certainly not warm enough, and nothing covers her neck.  The wealthy girl wears a lovely large hat with flowers and ruffles inside the brim and a wide silk ribbon over the crown and under her chin. A satin cape with slit sleeves was likely quilted inside, and is bound in colored trim with added braid. Her skirt is a diagonally cut plaid with two rows of braid above the hem. Four layers of lace ruffles decorate the bottom of her pantalets. Tiny, flat, square-toed shoes are barely seen.
source: Detail from a fashion plate that first appeared in a Feb 1847 edition of the Parisian magazineLe Follet, which was published weekly from 1829 to 1892, and influenced styles in Europe, Britain, and North America. Many Le Follet magazines were published weekly from 1829 to 1892. The magazines have been added to Google Books, a repository of public domain documents. Free use.

caption: Connected bodice and drawers for little child of 3 - 4, ca.: 1830 to 1850.
description: Best cotton muslin makes underwear for a fast-growing toddler or little child of either gender. Top and bottoms are connected with buttons, and a drop-down flap in back would be quite convenient for using any type of potty chair. Pretty tucks and lace decorate the hems.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840.) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Fashion Doll of 1840s with porcelain head.
description: This pink silk dress has petticoats beneath, and a jacket edged with pink, dyed linen lace. Her bonnet is woven of rosy pink ribbons. The sleeves are elbow length, but the porcelain arms were probably broken off by the John Taylor child.
source: The doll resides in the John Taylor home restored in Nauvoo, Illinois. Photo by Vikki L. Boyak Clarke. Free use.

caption: Child pioneers in a fashion show at BYU for a convention of the Costume Society of America, winter and summer clothing.
description: The boy in a wide-brimmed straw hat is keeping warm in a Rob Roy plaid wool shirt and a brown woven muffler. He wears black shoes and black trousers.  The barefoot girl of summer wears an old, ragged, long-sleeved, red dress that is too short and covered with a shabby, all-over apron with a drawstring neckline. She has a sky blue sun bonnet with a small, ruffled brim.
source: Designed and sewn by Carma. Photo by BYU Professor Mary Farahnakian. Free use.

caption: Frederick Granger Williams Smith as a young boy in his Sunday clothes, ca.: 1840s.
description: Fredrick, son of Joseph and Emma Smith, was named for one of Joseph's dearest friends, and is about 8 years old here. He wears a skirted brown coat with brass buttons, and trousers of a rich blue in this small gouache on paper. He holds a small religious tract or school paper. Glass in the windows is in panes much larger than available in Nauvoo at the time, for any price. Fringed draperies are included to add dignity, as in Baroque art: the "Drape of Honor."  Joseph and Emma had eleven child, only five of whom lived to adulthood. Portraits of their child would have been highly treasured.
source: By Sutcliffe Maudsley a talented but largely untrained folk artist, who left Mormons a rich cache of identities in his Nauvoo paintings. Courtesy of Community of Christ Historical Museum, Independence, Missouri.

caption: School age boy shows his sister how he whittles a stick, ca.: 1840s-60s.
description: The boy without a hat has hair down to his collar, a white shirt with a soft bow tie, and a dark coat. His shirt sleeves show at the wrists. His trousers are a pale shade of wool or linen. The little girl has a straw bonnet which barely shades her, but has wide ribbon ties. Her short-sleeved dress is brightly striped. She has black flat shoes and white stockings, while his shoes lace and tie.
source: S G Goodrich, artist of 1800s, seen in Growing up in RURAL New England, by Tamara K. Hareven.

caption: School boy's two-piece outfit 1840s-60s.
description: Through the 1840s-60s, school-age boys of middle-class means often wore a jacket similar to a younger boy's dress with shortened trousers of the same fabric. This illustration shows the dress-like jacket with a belt, which changes the silhouette. Black trim outlines the buttoned placket in front, as well as the belt, cuffs, and sides of the pants. Any kind of checkered cotton, wool, or linsey-woolsey might be used in this design. Many dark buttons emphasize the trim and make the outfit more expensive.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840.) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections. Free use.

caption: Many kinds of child's clothing are shown in this newspaper picture of 1840s.
description: "Escape of the Pet Bird" was a tragedy to the child in this illustration. The boys wear typical shirts and suspenders, and one in a high-buttoned jacket and striped pants. The little boy standing in a wide, plaid, skeleton suit and small-brimmed hat is crying. The older girls wear full-curtained sunbonnets and darker dresses. One of them carries a stuffed doll.  The boy holding the empty bird-cage watches the escaping bird with alarm. He and the standing boy have rather long wavy hair. On the ground are a little wagon, straw hat, broom and barrel in front of a barking dog.
source: From the Breckenridge Papers, including 1800s newspapers, Missouri Historical Society at Columbia, Missouri. Free use.

caption: Sailor boy holding ship's ratlines is scrimshawed on a whale's tooth, ca.:1840.
description: The sailor boy wears large V neck white collar which must be squared in back as the typical sailor collar. Upper sleeve Seam is off the shoulder as was usual for all shirts of the time, but has some gathering. There is no cuff, and the sleeve is rolled up to the forearm. He wears no cap in the stiff sea winds.
source: Mystic Seaport, Massachusetts, photo from Guide to Museum Villages, by M. R. Alegre.

caption: Toddler shoes could be worn by boys or girls, ca.: most of 1800s
description: Toddlers shoes of soft childskin or dense woolen Denmark satin were simple square or round-toed, square-vamped best shoes held on by buttoned straps across the instep.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Drawn by Margaret Weber.

caption: Girls lace-up shoe, 1840s, from Vienna, Austria
description: Soft suede leather lined in child with ankle bands in a very small dotted print. Cord lacing is in holes center front, with multi-looped rosette at bottom of lacing. Thin leather soles with extra layer for heel. Similar shoes all over Europe, Britain and America.
source: Drawn by Carma after Margo Lister, Costumes of Everyday Life. Free use.

caption: Girl's dressy shoes of mixed fabric in dull green, ca.:1840s-70s.
description: Probably a mixture of woven silk and wool make up the outside of the strap-and-button shoes. Layered and lined in linen with slightly squared toes. The button to close the strap is positioned on the top of the foot, not the side.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum, drawn by Margaret Weber. Free use.

caption: Pioneer boys boots for travel and work. Mid 1800s.
description: For a young pioneer, undyed leather was shaped by pounding over special iron forms. Only one seam was sewn up the back. Very strong boots have loops for pull on, with roomy square toes and the extra-low heels of the 1800s.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Drawn by Margaret Weber. Free use

caption: Traveling knife grinder, 1820 to 1880
description: Working outside while traveling in any weather, this traveling knife-grinder wears a short jacket open to his shirt, and long patched trousers. He covers his head in the same hat year round. He could be a European or American working at a mobile grinding wheel with a bucket of dripping water to cool the metal against the stone. Such men continued the practice well into the 1900s.
source: Carol Belanger Grafton, Ed. Trades and Occupations: A Pictorial Archive from Early Sources(Dover Pictorial Archive)Paperback  August 1, 1990

caption: Knitted stockings in a pattern from Blekinge, Sweden.
description: These blue wool knee stockings were knitted with red and white designs up the outside leg. And then a young woman at BYU, Miss Wray, also embroidered the separate lines of large red flowers on each side of the design. WE can see that the red designs extend down onto the top of the foot. The Stockings were lain out on a large ornamental rock of a Provo garden, with flowers similar to those seen in Sweden.
source: Amannequin imagewearing the regional costume of Karlskrona,in the Blekinge Folk Museum of Sweden, Photo by Carma.

caption: A strong laboring man wields a sledge hammer to break up stones of foundations. Most of 1800s.
description: This town laborer is illustrated in a flat brimmed wool cap on his straggly hair. As he works, the only protection for his trousers is a heavy piece of cloth that hangs in front from his waistline belt nearly to his ankles. The belt end is twisted out of the way. He wears a pullover shirt of wool or tow linen with a front neck placket and rolled up sleeves.
source: : From Margot Lister, Costumes of everyday life: An illustrated history of working clothes, (London, Barrie & Jenkins, 1972).

caption: Laboring man with rough clothing and a pickaxe. 1700s to 1900s.
description: Town laborers, whether in England or new cities of America had extremely hard work to do, often with a pick-axe. This man wears an underwear shirt with two buttons showing. Over that is a heavy, blue and white wool checkered shirt closed with buttons almost down to his waistline. A stout belt buckle for his heavy woolen breeches shows at waist. The breeches reach below his knees where vertically ribbed stockings cover his legs up to his "short clothes." He wears thick laced boots with very low heels, but soft leather stands above the boots to reach up around his stockings. Boots have leather strips or heavy cord for shoelaces. This provides some ankle protection as he dislodges rocks to make smoother roads. He wears a deep round cap with a soft brim of green wool tweed with a tassel on top.
source: Margot Lister, Costumes of everyday life; An Illustrated History of Working Clothes, (London, Barrie &Jenkins, 1972)

caption: Laboring man of Britain or America with rough clothing and a pickaxe. 1700s to 1900s.
description: Town laborers, whether in England or cities of America, had extremely hard work to do, often with a pick-axe. This man wears an underwear shirt with two buttons showing. Over that is a heavy, blue and white, wool checkered shirt closed with buttons almost to his waistline. A stout belt buckle for his heavy woolen breeches barely shows. The breeches reach below his knees where vertically ribbed stockings cover his legs up to his "short clothes." He wears thick, laced boots with very low heels, but soft leather stands above the boots to protect up around his stockings. Boots have leather strips or heavy cord for shoelaces. This provides some ankle protection as he dislodges rocks to make smoother roads. He wears a deep round cap with a soft brim of green wool tweed with a tassel on top.
source: Margot Lister, Costumes of everyday life; An illustrated history of working clothes,(London, Barrie & Jenkins, February 24, 1972). Slightly modified by Lorie Davis

caption: Photo of a lace shawl corner section.
description: This corner of an incomplete Honiton lace shawl from England is comprised of mainly leaves and tiny flowers on the edge. The central designs are lozenges, ferns and flowers with some curved banding.
source: Originally donated to Carma's Costume Institute of Utah, by Mary Jean Pritt; then given to BYU Fine Arts Historical Clothing Collection

caption: A lady's fan with white painted wood sticks from the 1850s,
description: On the half circle of paper is a chromolithograph which has been printed in color or printed in line designs to be water- colored by a lady herself. "Chromos" were broadly available in America, Britain and Europe in the1800s. Sometimes the spokes were made of Asian sandalwood which had a pleasant aroma when new.
source: Similar fans are still available today in any Asian import house, and still used for costumes

caption: Lady from potteries in dress
description: unknown
source: unknown

caption: Three reticules worn throughout the 1800s are lain out straight, some with tassels.
description: Such purses were worn throughout Europe and America. They had rings in the center to close a central opening, but the rings could slide from one end to the other depending on which side of the purse contained the lady's wants. The ends of the reticule would hang down from the center, where the lady held on to it. Top-Olive green plush embroidered with pink and green. Center-Crocheted green silk with end tufts. Bottom-Crocheted dark brown silk with silver beads and long tassels
source: Ken Etheridge, Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century.(Swansea, Wales: Cristopher Davies, Ltd., 1977).

caption: Shawl 1860
description: Shawls, also designs by Lambert from Musee des Dessinateurs, Clabburn

caption: Large Handkerchief or small shawl bundles made by the poor in England for traveling in the 1800s.
description: This is similar to what the Japanese have done for hundreds of years for traveling--and probably most of the rest of the world in different periods, These are from common working people in Britain, with an also an umbrella for constant chances of rain if they are going some distance, taking food and drink in a handled basket.
source: Gertrude Jekyll, Old English Household Life, Some Account of Cottage Object and Country Folk (B. T. Batsford Ltd., Lundon and Sydney, 1933)

caption: Large Scottish shawls for a lady and gentleman, 1846.
description: In this 1846 drawing a man is wrapped horizontally in his shawl around his body, which has a dark line on all edges but self-fringe on each end. The woman's shawl is a huge square with dramatic dark lines cris-crossing each other and self-fringe on all edges. She carries a dainty parasol and has many ribbons on the left side tying on her tiny white bonnet. Her shoes are not visible but his black leather square-toed boots have a lighter colored buttoning fabric from their foot width up to his high ankles. The maleblack shiny topper is very small brimmed.
source: Stewart Maxwell and Robin Hutchison, Scottish Costume 1550 - 1850, (London, Adam & Charles Black, Pub. 1958.)

caption: Leaving Old England from the western harbor of Liverpool. 1850
description: All ages of emigrants are leaving England, many of whom are from other parts of Britain and Europe. The man hanging on the lower edge of the ship is reaching for one more basket of supplies being tendered by a loved one. He wears a pilot cap, as many others do, although we also see top hats, sailor hats and other caps on men and boys. A grandmother in a large cloak and a country cap holds a baby. Another father with a neck scarf holds a small child on his shoulder. Even a man balancing on the rail and holding a ships rope hoists a large child so she can see and remember the goodbye scene. The man standing on the ropes in the shiny top hat wears a fine vest and coat and more of the light colored trousers of the mid-1800s. There seems to be only one woman and two girls who are not wearing some sort of headgear.
source: Illustrated London News Picture Library, about 1850.

caption: Mens fancy linen nightshirt with ruffled collar and neck opening. All 1800s
description: Nightshirt in linen or cotton had a back yoke with gathers below for fullness. Sleeve tops are gathered, and ovious gussets at the armpits allow for full movement during sleep. A nightshirt could be as long as the wearer wished.
source: www.pinterest.com/pin/238972323960823113/

caption: Liverpool departure with highlighted figures of immigrants drawn by Carma
description: The upper part of this illustration shows a sailing ship bringing hundreds of overbooked immigrants to America from across the Atlantic. In good weather, people much preferred to be out on deck. We see all kinds of people in a great variety of clothing coming to America. The man on front right waves his hat to loved ones he may never see again. The lower half of the picture picks out and enlarges people from the crowd above. On left, a child stands upon luggage while keeping his arms around his father, who wears a workers smock with rain-guards buttoned onto the shoulders. The man wears a battered felt hat and gaiters over his shoes. Next is a woman in a large shawl over her head and dress. She wears many petticoats for fullness. A precious bundle of memorable possessions is in her hands, and a colored scarf fills her neckline. In center, a country man in breeches and gaiters guides a little girl with a shawl around her waist. He wears a stout, old, felt hat with an overcoat and neckerchief. Next are two little girls, one in a bonnet and all-over apron, and another with long, unbound hair. Beside them is a little boy climbing on a wicker case. On far right, a Scotsman wears a plaid tam o'shanter and a short unbuttoned jacket. Behind him is an older man in a worn top hat and an overcoat with large lapels. He is with a young woman whose full, long hair lies on her fluffy wool shawl
source: Departure from Liverpool (Salem, Massachusetts, National Historic Site Maritime Museum). Lower illustrations by Carma.

caption: Woman's reticule with two lobes and tassels. Sliding rings allow opening in center.
description: This reticule is a long, tubular, netted purse with beading and embroidery, that can hold many items in both large ends. A slit in the top center allows opening with 2 metal rings holding the lobes closed .It is carried by the middle section. Either ring can be pushed to the side to open a lobe. This embroidery is multi-colored. It holds more than a narrow reticule, including a little coin purse containing money.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840. )Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections.

caption: Lumberjack stands beside a tree larger in diameter than he is tall. Red woolen shirts were preferred for outdoor work. 1840-1870s
description: In the mid-1800s, a lumberjack stands beside a tree larger in diameter than he is tall. Red woolen shirts were preferred for outdoor work. His black felt hat helps keep sawdust out of his hair and neck.
source: Detail of "Logging in the Minnesota Forests" by Franz Holzhuber, in American Heritage Magazine, June, 1965.

caption: A lumberjack and supervisor in woolen shirts direct logging in the US Minnesota forests. Mid 1800s
description: A lumberjack and supervisor in woolen shirts direct logging in the US Minnesota forests. The boss is wearing a typical red wool shirt with a white shirt beneath. He wears tan wool breeches and high boots as he holds a red flag to signal workers in the forest. The man in front wears a heavy, blue, wool, double-breasted jacket. Both have brown or black felt hats and natural, medium length beards.
source: Detail of "Logging in Minnesota" by Franz Holzhuber, in American Heritage, June, 1965.

caption: "Maidens garlands" in some Christian Churches of southern England feature white gloves as well as paper flowers.
description: Maidens' deaths were specially remembered with assembled flower garlands on circular hoops to represent the girls who had never really tasted the joys of full life. Since gloves were much in fashion for long decades, little white gloves were often hanging with the flowers representing the purity of the girls.
source: Unknown

caption: An illustration of man's folk wear from the flat lands of Denmark, Zeeland, where we see a windmill is the background to grind grain by economical "wind power."
description: Very large colored illustration for a man's folk wear in his black wool breeches and calf-high leather boots. His very short jacket is a pleasant Danish green and he has a typical red and yellow striped vest, lavishly adorned with silver (or pewter) buttons on both jacket and vest. His habitual tobacco for his short pipe ever present indoors or out in the 1800s. The style of his cap is found all over Europe and the Lowlands, , being a soft wool crown and a short brim.
source: By artist F. C. Lund, from a collection of outsized prints at the National Museum of art in Copenhagen. Published by Bilchers Forlag, Kolding, Denmark. Carma received print as a gift from the Museum.

caption: Man's part goat-hair brown cloak, appears to have a newer replaced velvet collar on the original cloak, ca. -1820s-80.
description: A man's brown cloak, partly of goat-hair, probably has a newer, replaced, velvet collar. This cloak was much worn, and had been donated to the Ontario County Historical Society, New York. The wool fabric had goat hair spun into the yarn, which made it more waterproof. When moisture drops on it, the goat hair swells and becomes water repellant. However, goat hair in fabric does not allow perfect retention of the dyed color. Three wooden toggle buttons close the cloak from neck to waist.
source: Ontario County Historical Society, Canandaigua, NY. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: Mannequin in Iceland wearing a folk costume, without a Scotufa.
description: Icelandic black velvet jacket with collar and with silver lacing and much embroidery, A maroon silk scarf makes a head-wrap.
source: Photo in the National Museum, Rejkiavik, Iceland. This photo by Betty Robinson, Spanish Fork, Utah.

caption: Mannequin of a Norwegian bride in special crown and wedding bib. 1860 Vest-Adgar Brudebunad
description: This bride is wearing her Bunad (folk ensemble) of a fine black wool skirt with red and black bands around the hem, and a white linen blouse covered by a black wool or velvet jacket. On her bridal bib, over the jacket, are many inherited pieces of jewelry in glittering silver. Photography makes the silver look gold. There is silver fringe around her bib in two places, and round spoons of silver all over her crown. They reflect the light in the way intended for the bride/ This is a medium size bridal crown--, with some being even larger-- hasthe brides hair covered in back with a black silk scarf. The apron is the finest linen with special hemstitching. Jewelry clips hang at the waistline on each side of the apron. The city of KristiandsandinSouthern Norway has many public exhibits of folk clothing. This is a photo from a postcard.
source: Fotomagasinet, Kristensand.

caption: Man's unlined, red, wool cape with black buttons and darker red tape around edges. Ca. 1820-1840.
description: A Man's cape would have provided both warmth and fashion. It has 10 black buttons but no buttonholes. To look dapper, it was probably thrown over the shoulders. (Or possibly the owner may have died before the buttonholes were made, and it was kept as it was for sentimental reasons. Its present owners have no data on it.)
source: Ontario County Historical Society Museum in Canandaigua, New York, near Palmyra. The museum contains precious antique items of clothing and artifacts. Outside of Palmyra is the home of Joseph Smith Sr. and Lucy Mack Smith, parents of the Prophet, whose farm is located north of the town, and is partly in Manchester Township. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: Marie Cardon, the youngest daughter of Phillipe Cardon of Italy, wears a voluminous dress of fine fabric.
description: Marie wears large sleeves that taper down toward the wrists and made of heavy silk or fine wool. There are tiny buttons down the bodice front and into the skirt. The fullness of her skirt is supported by multiple petticoats. Marie has a tiny white collar with a brooch. She may wear curved combs helping to hold her plentiful, hair securely back from the face. A ribbon tied on top adorns her waist-length hair.
source: Genevieve Porter Johnson and Edna Cardon Taylor,compilers, Cardons! Descendents of Philippe Cardon and Marthe Marie Tourn 1799-1886, (Provo, Utah, Stevenson's Genealogy Center, 1990) Permission from Larry C. Porter.

caption: Market people in front of Edenboroughs John Knox House of the 1500s, in of Scotland.
description: Detail of Market people in front of Edenboroughs John Knox House of the 1500s, in Scotland, CD Fig ?,On this famous street in Edenborough, we see women with baskets going to market with their child. Women's colorful clothes of orange and yellow look like bed-gowns and skirts, and their wide baskets are for selling goods in the open market. A background woman has a bright red shawl. Different women have white or colored caps and some wear neckerchiefs. A short dress is usual for girls, such as the barefoot one at the left. Down the stairs comes another child in a black striped dress with a white neckerchief and black stockings. The man to the left in the group may be wearing a Black Watch plaid kilt and a large blue tam o'shanter. The man on the far right has a dark gray tailcoat with light pants under a mashed felt hat or tam.
source: Alan McNie, Scotland Then &Now in Colour, (Jedburgh, Scotland, Cascade Publishing Company, January 1, 1990) permission Address: Cascade Publishing Co RowandeneBelses, Jedburgh TD8 6UR Phone: 01835 870205

caption: A married woman in folk clothing in Denmark.
description: A young married woman from Salling, Jutland, is moving her wool or linen winding wheel to a position near the bright little window. She is wearing the white fine linen cap which indicates her place of origin with a brightly colored red sweater and the same color in a small shawl of large plaid, red, white, and green. The front ends of it are tucked under her green and black, cross-barred, long apron. Her woven red and grey skirt of very tiny stripes is not much gathered and she is slim.
source: By artist F. C. Lund, from a collection of outsized prints at the National Museum of art in Copenhagen. Published by Bilchers Forlag, Kolding, Denmark. Carma received print as a gift from the Museum.

caption: Marriner W. and Sarah A. Merrill, Canadians, in clothing like that of Britain. 1840s to1860
description: Marriner is wearing a very short top hat, a black bow tie and a vest buttoned up rather high on his chest. Sarah wears a poke bonnet over her naturally very curly hair. The bonnet's brim is shallow and decorated with little artificial flowers on the inside with wide ribbons on each side, popular in the 1840s decade. Her sleeves are narrow and her dress has a high turned over collar, all in the same fabric, a glossy silk with miniature flowers. Merriner was born in 1835 in Sackville, New Brunswick, Canada, and was baptized a Mormon in 1852. He married Sarah A. Atkinson in1853. He served a Mission to Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, and was ordained an LDS Apostle in 1889. He died in 1906, in Utah.
source: Unknown

caption: Mary Langhorn Nuttall, from Cumbria, England 1840s.
description: This dark eyed English woman wears a best black dress with a day cap of probably white silk satin without ruffles of fabric by the cheeks in the 1840s. This is a special narrow cap which does not seem to rise in covering her bobbed hair in back. There are silk ribbon folds en masse, stitched on each side of the face edge, above a wide embroidered collar typical of 1840s fashion in Lancaster. She did not did not leave for America with her husband, William, until 1852. Her oil portrait on canvas, probably without the frame, was brought with her husband's so the unknown artist was living in England. A pale orange silk neckerchief is for just a spot of flattering color. Her small jet broach is at the high crossing of the scarf points.
source: Oil portraits seen in Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Photo by Carma Also on Internet: https: //www. geni. com/people/William-Nuttall/6000000001402404357

caption: Mary Miranda White Rhodes wears her best, decorative, silk dress and carries a small accordion. Bow and jewelry are applied in gold-leaf. ca.: 1840
description: Mary Miranda White Rhodes wears her best decorative silk dress and carries a small accordion. Bow and jewelry are applied in gold-leaf. Mary wears a dress with V-shaped ruching and pleating over the shoulders to the center front bodice, which match the epaulettes and cuffs. Her tiny white collar has a ribbon with red and white jewels in a broach.. Her hair is thin but is determinedly curled into ringlets. Her partially seen skirt is very full. The gold and jewels are overlain in actual gold-leaf and bright paint. She also has a gold-leaf watch chain and two rings, one with a red jewel setting. This technique to make the most elegant features realistic is rather unusual.
source: Ancestor of W. Mike Nielson. Free use

caption: McDonald's progenitors in their prime of life. Watercolor paintings by an excellent artist. Very wealthy Scottish-English.
description: McDonald progenitors in their prime of life. Watercolor paintings by an excellent artist show wealthy Scottish-English couple. His fine suit is black with a vest of black and red double-striped silk with a shawl collar. His shirt shows two pearl buttons in a pleated yoke. The standing collar against his jaw line is at least twice wrapped with a figured silk tie in a short bow. The tie could be as long as 57 inches. His hair is very dark brown and cut at the top of his ears, with sideburns continuing into short, clipped mutton-chops and no beard. He has striking blue eyes. His wife is a pretty brunette with curls high on the sides of her cheeks, and center parted hair. She has dainty eyebrows and dark blue eyes. Possibly she wears a little rouge on her mouth. The day cap is frilly lace from brows to chin and very tiny peach rosebuds added to the lace. Pale peach silk lappets hang from each side of the day cap and are not tied. Her dress was a dark lavender with three strips of silk tape over the shoulders down to the bodice waist. We cannot tell what kind of sleeves are in this dress, but a small lace collar is centered by a tiny gold broach. The oval frames are original in gold leaf, but they were later centered in most elaborately carved and punctured layers of elegant mat boards in soft colors, with large mahogany wood frames.
source: In private possession of descendants in Provo, Utah.

caption: Common work clothing from painting, Dance of the Haymakers by William Sidney Mount, ca.:1845.
description: Full view of the clothing of a young laborer, enjoying his time-off to dance to violin music played among the Mount family and their workers. He wears pin-striped broadfall trousers that have 5 small buttons up from the ankles, which could open over large boots. Here he dances in supple oxford shoes and a very light-weight coat of reddish cotton or wool lined in cheap silk. His tucked in pullover shirt has a completely unbuttoned placket. (Shirt openings for all classes in that era did NOT open to the waist or the hem, as today, but only to 3 to 4 buttons from the neck.) Fairly short hair is covered by a horizontally striped, knitted cap of navy and red. He has a chin line beard.
source: William Sidney Mount, a prolific painter of rural America. Original in Suffolk Museum at Stonybrook, New York. Often seen in full and in part online.

caption: An overall example of mens better clothing of the mid-1800s.
description: The frock coat, which could be in a variety of colors, has a skirt sewn on at the waist and fairly slim sleeves. It is double breasted with a dark silk braid around the collar and front opening. His trousers are pale and striped, and his silk vest has small dots and a shawl collar. Though the tucked yoke on his shirt front is obvious, we cannot see a tie or collar under his short beard. Many styles of ties and cravats might be worn. He sports a jaunty, low, top hat which flares at the top edge, probably of gray or white wool. Narrow low boots are below his trousers. A popular weekend tote of 1800 to 1925 was a leather valise with one handle and a stout lock on top. Carma still has her father's valise which went in and out and around America and Europe.
source: Drawn by Carma using ideas from printed figures elsewhere, plus her own family luggage. Free use.

caption: Mans unlined linen frock coat for summer in 1840s.
description: Made of dense white linen with white cord piping and bone buttons. The collar and sides of the chest had a double layer of linen for facing. Pockets in the back skirt were of strong cotton muslin, unseen under the pleats at each side of the back skirt opening, where there were decorative buttons. Cuffs also had 2 small, bone buttons.
source: Antique purchased in modern Massachusetts by Carma. Photo by Joseph R. Putnam; free use.

caption: Cooks in a primitive mining camp of 1849, one with a flour-sack hat.
description: Their pull-over shirts have cut-off or rolled up sleeves in the heat of the cooking area. Loose trousers are flour-dusted from baking. Man on left has a beaten -up straw hat. The cook on right has made himself a protective hat of a clean and folded flour sack with part of the upside-down label seen at the top.
source: Daguerreotype portrait from Rinhart Collection, Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio.

caption: Husking Dance: Best dress of the working class, 1840s.
description: After a husking bee to shuck a bountiful crop of corn for drying as animal feed, there is a dance in a country house with a central hearth. When the work of the day is finished, the cider barrel is opened and the party begins. The furniture is moved away, hats and bonnets are taken off, and all ages celebrate. Musicians in the background are playing various viols. The gentlemen wear mostly light trousers, though one man has colored trousers with a stripe of ribbon down the side seam, indicating best clothing. He wears a light colored coat. The vigorous line dancing shows women in very full skirts and often little jackets over their dresses with a peplum over the skirt. The jackets button up the front. The sleeves have tiny puffs at the top which indicates 1840s.
source: From Compton's Pictured Encyclopedia 1936,printed in USA. Scan by Carma; free use.

caption: Drawing of a naturalist in a smock as he collects herbs in his cylindrical carry-all, ca.: 1840s-50s.
description: This scientist with long sideburns is outdoors a great deal in his straw hat with a line of ribbon around the crown. His neckerchief can keeps him warm or wipe his brow when weather is hot. The smock is both coat and raincoat over other clothes. He does his collecting primarily in warm weather, then takes herbs home to categorize and dry for study and medicine. His tough trousers are strapped under his flat shoes to keep them in place as he tramps through all terrain. His shoes have sturdy toe caps to prolong wear.
source: From the cover of a modern notebook of paper. No source given.

caption: Common hats and shirts on Raftsmen Playing Cards as they travel the Missouri River in 1847.
description: This close-up detail shows man seated on floor and the man standing in the middle wearing large straw hats with curled brims and rounded crowns. The man in the red shirt has a fine, wide, curled brim on a beige felt with a squared crown; the man poling behind him wears a small felt hat, rather squashed. Two other men in front have a knitted cap and a battered, black, broad-brim with a rounded crown, purposely dented on the sides. Their shirts and pants are common and worn, but in many colors, some with suspenders. One pair of pants seems to be an early Levi jean rolled up at the cuff. Only one man wears a vest, proving these men to be very common and casual.
source: The artist, George Caleb Bingham, lived on the river since childhood and painted much of its shifting emphasis on the history of the nation, He reveled in the mixture of various ethnicities found along this gigantic feature of Americas cultural geography. George Caleb Bingham, American, 1811-1879, Raftsmen Playing Cards, 1847, oil on canvas; 28 1/16 x 38 1/16 inches, Saint Louis Art Museum, Bequest of Ezra H. Linley by exchange 50:1934. Found frequently online.

caption: Poor man in shabby clothes and canvas gaiters of 1830s to 1850s
description: Moleskin buff breeches are much worn, and an unbuttoned, cotton, striped vest hangs just below the cutaway edge of his old, 1830s coat. This coat is tailed and double-breasted, with cheaper buttons made of fabric-covered wooden disks. At his neck is a wrapped a smudgey-white muslin kerchief. He wears coarse, canvas gaiters on his lower legs held together by inexpensive buttons. Even poor people tried to wear a decent assembly of clothing, however worn-out or unclean.
source: Historical and reproduced clothing for actor Max Wall in Little Dorrit. Permission from Lord Snowdon, photographer.

caption: Apothecary in apron working with his scales. 1840s.
description: This druggist wears small round spectacles to see exactly what he is doing or to read his formula books. His coat is well fitted in the body with narrow sleeves. A pale cravat is knotted around his neck. His apron loops around his neck and is tied in back. It was probably a starched white cotton twill to appear neat and protect his clothing. As a balding man, he brushes his hair forward.
source: Grafton-Carol Belanger Grafton, Ed., Trades and Occupations: A Pictorial Archive from Early Sources (Dover Pictorial Archive)Paperback August 1, 1990, illustration 761. This excellent book of common people doing everything is fabulous! 10 images from this book are free for use.

caption: A Carpenter in his leather apron poses in front of last remaining pioneer cabin in Salt Lake City, Utah, on West Temple Street near the MCHA, ca.: 1847.
description: A worn-out straw hat shields a carpenter as he works outside with a plane to smooth a cutting board. His trousers are a hand-woven cotton-woolsey. Note the four buttons on the trousers ankles that expand the leg if he chooses to wear boots instead of shoes. The simple work shirt is of strong cotton, accented by a small silky tie. All items made and distressed by Carma.
source: In an early MCHA display in Salt Lake City.

caption: Blacksmith at the Pioneer Cabin in Salt Lake City, MCHA. ca.:1847 and on.
description: Both the blacksmiths brimmed cap and apron are made of cowhide for protection. A blacksmith must wear a split-legged leather apron with strong leather ties for his waist and around separate thighs and knees. His tough clothing beneath the apron is thus protected from fire and hammer sparks. He also wears slouchy blucher boots with square toes.
source: This Pioneer Profile character served as a demonstrator at the LDS Churchs cabin on West Temple Street. Docent, Douglas Merrill, was completely dressed in hand-sewn leather, including his cap. Carma created correct patterns to fit each of the 18 volunteer docents and mostly sewed them by hand, herself. Photo by Joseph R. Putnam; free use.

caption: Dressing gown of 1840s worn by Alec Guinness in the BBC film, Little Dorrit.
