description: The robe is much worn but still hanging together. With a drab velvet collar, it is made of figured velvet that has been stressed to appear as if it has been worn for decades. A rope ties his waist. He wears a pale vest and a neckerchief under his robe.
source: From the film Little Dorrit; photo cards by Permission of Lord Snowdon, photographer. FREE

caption: LDS Church Presidency of 1847, Utah, shows similar coat styles of the decade.
description: The three leaders wear their best dark coats and almost matching trousers. Left to right: Heber C. Kimball, First Councilor to Brigham Young, was given gifts he was unable to buy, the gold chain and watch which was gifted by an admirer, which he used ever after. Brigham Young is still slim and clean shaven, striding around the whole Utah Territory to supervise colonization. Willard Richards, Second Councilor, was completely reliable in every assignment, and was the only one who could afford nicer fabrics in his tailoring. Here he wears fancy M-cut lapels and a dressy white tie.  Kimball is probably taller than Brighams 5 ft. 9 inch. Willard may be an inch shorter than Brigham. British converts were much smaller people as a rule, the poorest ones quite small from malnutrition, especially in cities.
source: LDS Archives.

caption: Mans overcoat with quilted lining to waist. Ca.: 1840s.
description: This well-dressed man wears a fitted overcoat that covers his frock coat and light-colored, worsted wool trousers. The coats inner lining on the upper half and both lapels is of quilted satin inside, but no quilting is in the sleeves. Lighter braiding trims his sleeve cuffs. His frockcoat is double-breasted with metal buttons, and his top hat is particularly tall and shiny over clusters of curly hair. A trimmed beard rises to circle his mouth in a modish moustache. The poor mans toes are crammed into tiny, pointed shoes which indicate refinement in illustrations. Coat quilting also seen in The Mode in Costume, R. Turner Wilcox, which shows a Victorian English informal dress double-breasted dinner coat with quilted black satin lapels and collar.
source: Illustration from 1800s in Kybalova, Ludmila, Olga Herbenova, and Milena Lamarova. Das Grosse Bilderlexicon der Mode. (Prague: Bertelsmann Lexicon, 1966). Free use.

caption: Standup collar of white linen dress shirt, ca.: 1830s to 40s.
description: Mens collars were always separate from dress shirts so men could put on a fresh collar as needed. They were typically worn buttoned to the shirts collar band with five tiny strategic buttons. The collar itself had buttonholes to receive those buttons (two can be seen below and to each side of the collar center). The one-inch wide cutout in the front center allows room for the chin when the collar stands up against the mans jawbones. To make allowance for the mans head to look upward, the top edge of the collar always slants far down toward the back of the neck, where it buttons together at only 3/4 inch high. It is made of 2 outside layers of fine linen, with a partial third, inner layer, between them. Multiple layers hold a quantity of starch to keep the collar standing. All edges on this collar are hand top-stitched for ease in ironing. Neckties of many feet long were wrapped three times around the stand-up collar, ending in a knot or a bow in front.
source: Construction and Photo by Carma, who sewed this collar as a copy of one in the Salt Lake City DUP Museum, attributed to Joseph Smith; free use.

caption: Mens corsets were worn during the early 1800s when tight clothing and wasp-waists were in fashion for men
description: During periods when tight fitting coats and trousers or breeches were the height of fashion (see above illustration), men with a little more waistline than popular might have worn corsets such as these. They were worn over underdrawers, and beneath coats, vests and trousers. Note that stockings were pulled up over the under drawers to hide the strap beneath the foot. It was well known that the Prince Regent, later King George III was so fond of eating, he was very overweight. His corsets were famous for creaking as he moved about, bent or sat.
source: Illustration from the University of Virginia collection. Seen online at: http://exhibits.hsl.virginia.edu/clothes/mens_corset/Public

caption: Men's hats, stock ties, and handkerchief
description: Men's top hats, stock ties, and handkerchief are seen in CD Fig ?A black top-hat is of shiny knit silk fabric over a hard cardboard frame, and therefore the edge of the brim must be bound in grosgrain ribbon. A flat ribbon is around the base of the crown. Carma bought this hat on Hope St. in an antique store of Hanley, Staffordshire, England because that is the town and street where her great grandfather lived for three years after marriage.   A gray top hat is cheap felt which more easily cracks because it has less fur mixed in the wool felt. Inside the hat is a white silk lining stamped with the Scottish maker's name, Hanover Street, Edinburgh. Stock ties are a paisley-printed black on blue, and a dotted silk handkerchief. The blue and black silk ties both button conveniently in back of collar. Plain black was worn in the meager circumstances of poor farmers, as well as high quality black silk worn on men in leadership positions.
source: Assembled or made by Carma. Photo by Joseph R. Putnam

caption: Various hats on a British crowd of people on the street; very similar to American clothing. Ca.: 1840s to 50s.
description: British and Americans wore many styles of hats. On the back left we see a man in a super-tall topper. Another man has a lower topper and a cloak with a wool rain cape layer over his shoulders. On his arm he carries a string of onions with the tips braided together. The next man is probably a Scottish or Irish immigrant with a large tam o'shanter, and a belt around his heavy wool shirt. Next is a man with a high crowned hat pressed forward, carrying a shovel across his shoulder and a lunch basket. Next is a man in a lower crowned hat with a parcel strapped over his shoulder. The next man wears a large checkered muffler around his neck under a short jacket. The man with a pipe is leaning forward. On front row, left, is a young girl, probably a maid servant doing her morning shopping. Her short light shawl keeps her warm in case of an ever-possible drizzle. She wears a minimal bonnet reaching forward from her face. In plaid, fashionable trousers is a man with a bundle on a strap, a shiny, medium-high topper, and an umbrella. The little boy carries a live puppy in his arm, and wears a small plaid tam o'shanter. The next man is prosperous enough to eat too well. He has a light colored vest beneath his tailcoat, a very shiny low-crowned topper, and a round bundle in his left hand. The last little man wears a vertical striped coat with old-fashioned full-topped sleeves. Behind him is a youth in a sailor suit with many stripes on his collar and a flat sailor cap.
source: Original image has been lost, but emphasizing lines have been sketched in by Carma for clarification. Free use.

caption: A fine commercial straw top hat aged and prepared by Carma for a docent to wear at the last Pioneer Cabin from 1847 preserved in Salt Lake City.
description: Brims on straw top hats were usually wider than those on felt toppers. The docent who wore this hat had too little hair to look correct for the period, so a strip from a wig was secured inside the headband (not seen). He also wore a brown linen smock for his work as a gardener from England, and told visitors that his father had been a gardener on a large estate in Yorkshire.
source: This hat is preserved in the Salt Lake City Museum of Church History and Art. Photo by Carma; free use

caption: Gray felt topper and its storage case. A very narrow grosgrain ribbon circled the hat at the base of the crown, with a tiny buckle on the side.
description: This gray topper was much worn and handed down over many decades by men in rural parts of the state of New York. It rests on top of its storage case of metal, which is lined and covered in wallpaper of the 1830s-1850s.
source: Inhabitants of the area around Palmyra, New York donated this to the Ontario County Historical Society. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: Large straw hats on American soldiers from 1775 on in hot climates. Here shown in the Mexican Campaign with Jefferson Davis, 1846.
description: An unusually wide brim that turns up on the edge makes a hat that deflects a lot of sun and heat.
source: Ink illustration from a long-lost book, scan by Carma. Free Use.

caption: Two hats from the outdoor audience at a huge LDS conference in Nauvoo, Illinois. An extract illustration from the large folk painting, Joseph Smith Preaching in the Nauvoo Grove, 1844 (seen elsewhere).
description: These young men wear an old felt hat and a home-made, wool, pilot cap with a blousy top. They were originally painted in color. Many of the British poor were at meetings like this, along with some wealthy families among the Latter-day Saints, and a number of Native Americans. Most attendees were converted to the LDS Church by missionaries and came to Nauvoo to meet the Prophet and hear his preaching.in the 1840s.
source: The Folk Painting, Joseph Smith Preaching in the Nauvoo Grove, has been exhibited in Salt Lake City, Utah at the MCHA. Extraction drawn by Carma. Free use.

caption: Mens simple nightshirt and nightcap were standard night wear. All 1800s
description: Though of cool and lightweight linen, a simple nightshirt kept a body dry and temperate beneath the covers. A nightcap held in body heat on cold nights when there was little or no fire to warm the room. Elastic on the back headband held the cap in place. Among the poorer class, day shirts often stood double duty as nightshirts.
source: Model and gown from www.historicalemporium.com

caption: Frontier calico Shirt for a man, ca.: 1840-1890.
description: Some pioneers crossing the plains preferred to use bright calico prints, any cheap print they could pay or barter for, to make men's work shirts. This shirt, instead of triangular straps across the shoulder top seams, has a split in the cloth and a straight band on both outside and inside to strengthen the shoulders.  Sometimes there is a little gathering in the shirt-front cloth at shoulder and neck. We see that instead of a facing in the center front slit, we have added a wide placket band for a number of covered buttons. This band adds front fullness to the shirt via two pleats at the bottom of the band. A man could wear the shirt out or tucked in. Some poor men with little or no underwear in the 1840s, simply used the long shirts tucked in and around their thighs as an under-covering.  This calico shirt shows the marks of a good seamstress. There is top-stitching around the front placket, collar and cuffs, as well as top stitching for the shoulder "straps."  The bottom side splits of the shirt were hand rolled with very close stitches for strength to survive many washings, as well as men jamming the shirt hems inside their pants. A tiny gusset, barely seen in the illustration, strengthens the top of the side split. French seams were employed wherever possible for added strength, and to avoid open seams which would fray.  Women crossing the plains often sewed such cotton shirts by hand while traveling in wagons, and could trade them with the Indians, who loved such colorful garments!
source: Drawn by Carma. Free use.

caption: Hand-made oxford shoes to be worn by "1800s costumed docents, men or women, at the Salt Lake City Museum of Church History and Art (MCHA).
description: Dennis Rowley, a fine custom maker of shoes and boots, produced more than 16 pairs of different footwear for the volunteer "Pioneer Profiles" docents at the museum in Salt Lake City.* Shown only during 1970s -2000. These oxfords were made with only 2 holes for lacing up with small strong cords. Both men and women wore them with 1840s period clothing which Carma saw in real period shoes during research in Eastern USA. The lengthened and squared toes on shoes for men and women were found in all working shoes of the day, both simple oxfords in leather, ankle-high bootees, taller work boots, as well as flat, slipper-type shoes.
source: Photo by Wayne Keys. Free use.

caption: Men's or teen boys' strong boot-shoes with side gussets of elastic, ca.:1840s onward.
description: Men's boot-shoes have ankle section of elastic to make them easy to pull on. A loop of leather was added to the center back seam, top edge, to help pull the heel on snugly. (A similar shoe was made for women with a leather stacked heel and a rosette of cords added on the vamp  shown elsewhere.)In time, these elastic side sections did wear out and become loose and wobbly. Nevertheless, Men used this style in leathers and fabrics until modified in the 1900s. Some boot-shoes were also laced up in the center front to fit better, even with their elastic sides.
source: Image in Eunice Wilson, A History of Shoe Fashion, (New York. Theater Arts Books, 1969). Drawn by Carma after an original painting of men's boots by Jorgen Peter Block. Free use.

caption: Boots from England, possibly of kangaroo leather, mid-1840s.
description: Low heeled, square-toed boots for finer wear. These have a triangle of black elastic at the front top edges to make them easier to pull on. Each boot has seams in the leather from sole to upper edge on the outside and inside of the boot. There is no other sectioning of the leather. They are lined in fine childskin.
source: The Costume Galleries, Rusholm. near Manchester, England.

caption: A farmers low-heeled boot for daily wear. 1840s to 50s.
description: Informal work boot in the simple style of two pieces of upper leather and pull-on loops for a boot jack. All boots of this era have squared toes.
source: drawn by Carma after Eunice Wilson, A History of Shoe Fashion, (New York. Theater Arts Books, 1969). Free use.

caption: Two styles of mens better boots, Wellington and Hessian. 1810s to 1850s and later.
description: Wellington boots were worn and made popular by Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington. This novel "Wellington" boot became a staple of hunting and outdoor wear for the British aristocracy in the early 1800s. Almost knee high, Wellington boots are of soft leather with large turn-over top that has a leather cord in a casing for tightening on the upper calf. It would hold out rain and mud in battle. Hessian boots are tall with a center dip and tassel, and were named for German mercenaries. All boots of these decades have squared toes.
source: drawn by Carma after Eunice Wilson, A History of Shoe Fashion, (New York. Theater Arts Books, 1969). Free use.

caption: Worn-out boot soles, outside and inside, show wooden pegs that attached the thick leather layers to the upper boot, ca.: 1857.
description: These soles of short boots were excavated from the known route of the Handcart Companies that crossed the plains to reach the Valley of the Great Salt Lake. The leather soles would have been thicker than the leather of the upper portions, so the soles survived with some of the connecting pegs. American shoemakers of the early1800s had no machines to penetrate heavy leather, so the work had to be completely done by hand, making holes with a special sharp auger.
source: From a special pioneer display in Allen Hall, a small, BYU off-campus building. Photos by Carma, ca. 1970. Free use.

caption: Shoe and boot lasts in Nauvoos Riser Shoe Shop, showing shapes of wood over which a cobbler would form square-toed shoes of leather, ca 1842-1848.
description: In the Nauvoo Riser Shoe Shop, support forms are on the left, while shoe and boot lasts for the feet are on the right. A customer fitted his or her foot against the lasts and chose one about the same size. Then both right and left shoes or boots were made in the same shape. There was not yet a separate last for right and left feet, and not always an adjustment for narrow or wide feet. All shoes were of leather chosen by the customer, and made with square-toes. For a boot, a leg section was attached to a correctly shaped shoe, but measured ahead of time in length and circumference to fit the customers calf and desired style. Every tool was available for custom shoe making, with a few examples of completed items.
source: For a boot, a leg section was attached to a correctly shaped shoe, but measured ahead of time in length and circumference to fit the customers calf and desired style. Every tool was available for custom shoe making, with a few examples of completed items.

caption: Two front views of broadfall trousers of Hyrum Smith, worn at his martyrdom. Left, trousers buttoned closed. Right, sides unbuttoned and folded forward.
description: Hyrum Smiths wool trousers with broadfall opening on both sides. They are lined with muslin on the waistband and inner pockets The dyed-bone buttons have faded from black to brown through repeated washings. Left image seems to have a front opening, but that is a deep wrinkle over a center seam. Right image shows the sides unbuttoned and the front fall folded down. White muslin pockets are sewn onto the sides of the waistband section. Below the waistline on each side are two diagonal welt pocket openings bound with the dark trouser fabric. A hand could be put deep into the muslin pocket on either side. The same fabric is used for facing on the inside of the trouser front fall. The center waistband buttons are closed during wear. Two inches from center are other buttons that fasten up the front fall. These trousers are totally and perfectly hand sewn, and measure longer than those of Joseph Smith's because Hyrum was about 2 inches taller than his brother.
source: From the collection of Eldred G. Smith, last General Patriarch of the Church, and Hyrum's descendent, who gave these to the LDS Church history department's small collection of church leaders clothing. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: Dressy trousers of cream corduroy with a French fall opening, ca.: 1847.
description: These trousers are made with a front fall but not a broadfall opening. This is a French fall which is much narrower to the center seam. Because the fall is so central, it requires two additional buttons below the belt to secure it against gapping open when the man sits down. This lightweight corduroy is completely lined in bleached muslin with extra stiffening around the fall, which has only three buttons across the top. The buttons are made of white bone for a wealthy man who has best, light-colored, summer trousers which are strapped under his shoes. The back waist band is higher than the front, and has a gusset and strap in the center back seam which can be loosened or tightened to fit the wearer.
source: Salt Lake City Pioneer Profiles at the 1847 Cabin, near MCHA. Volunteer docents modeled historical clothing for up to 25 years, a demonstration which has been discontinued. Sewn and photos by Carma. FREE

caption: Carpenter trousers made from hand-woven, gold blanket have button-on suspenders. Style of 1847.
description: Carpenter trousers of gold, hand-spun and hand woven wool. (Note variations of weft yarns in the weaving.) In center back of waistline is a fan shaped insert of the same material with carefully covered seams to lace up with a cord for adjusting waistline fit. Trousers back waistline is always higher than the broadfall front for man or boy's ease in leaning over, and the seat is cut to be a little baggy for comfort during hard work. Suspenders were always separate bands of cloth or leather with leather ends, and sometimes a few inches of elastic in back (if made after the 1820s.) The leather ends attach over buttons on the back of trousers. Suspenders crossed separately over the mans back, and buttoned on each side of the front waistband.  These were historic trousers for docent Carpenter, Joseph Hill, in the 1980s and 90s at the MCHA living exhibit of the last pioneer cabin left in Salt Lake Valley. (See fully dressed carpenter, elsewhere.)
source: Trousers were constructed by Carma from an antique cotton-woolsey blanket. Blanket had been made with hand-spun 2-ply yarn thread for weaving through a cotton warp strung on a wide blanket loom in early Idaho. Photo by Michael Paul. Free use.

caption: Mens underwear or drawers of 1840.
description: A wide waistband helped men have a firm waistline, or even the desirable wasp waist, if they cinched it tight in back. Below the buttons in the front was a 3 to 4 inch opening. In the back was a full-cut bottom for comfort, with a laced waistband to cinch the waist smaller or looser. Some drawers had even wider, reinforced waistbands that were cut somwhat higher and lower on the torso to function a bit like a womans corset. The legs were cut more narrow toward the knee, with ties that kept the drawer legs from riding up. Drawers could be worn under breeches or trousers, and some were of knitted silk for the wealthy.
source: online at 1800 mens drawers, possibly from the Met Museum. Seen on: www.pinterest.com/pin/292452569532734786/:lp=true

caption: Men's work clothing as a detail of a large painting, Defense of Nauvoo, 1846.
description: A detail of a very large painting called Defense of Nauvoo shows four men in working clothes preparing to defend their city from its final, destructive mobs. The man far left cleans his rifle while wearing a blue barn coat and tan trousers with a pale straw hat. The next man wears a white linen or cotton shirt with gray trousers tucked into his boots. Next right is a man in a brown vest over his white shirt, with brown trousers and another rifle. The man far right in the typical red work shirt of light wool flannel over brown trousers has a powder horn slung over his shoulder. Of headgear, the two on the left are fairly flat straw hats, while the two on the right are felt with higher, rounded crowns
source: This example of C.C.A. Christensen's series of 10 paintings (each about 8 ft. by 10 ft.) was created during his winter rest times away from farming. He depicted early Mormon history and pioneers, and exhibited them in many cities of Mormons, north and south, in the Mormon Corridor of settlements from Arizona to Northern Idaho. He linked the paintings together in a long roll, which was easiest for transporting. Christensen was converted in Denmark, entranced by the Mormon worldview of Christianity and the glorious after-life it taught. He painted the series after he had been in America for some years, living in Utah's Sanpete County. To each group of viewers in his journeys, Christensen explained his prepared story of early Mormon History. He unwound the scroll and described scene by scene from his wagon box, if it was a small village. If possible he spoke in a primitive chapel or at a farmyard gathering --charging observers a small-price. Christensens efforts to show his arts gave him a slightly increased income through the long winters in the west, and also allowed him to demonstrate his deep-seated beliefs. Authenticity of clothing in his paintings was not completely accurate or detailed, even on such large paintings. He had not, after all, seen the events himself in their time period. The entire art Roll is now stored properly in the BYU Museum of Art, Provo, Utah. Free use.

caption: A wagon driver transported goods and foods from east to west in America throughout the 1800s. This outfit is ca.: 1840.
description: This teamster or muleskinner wears grey wool trousers, mended from wheel snags and patched upon patches from harsh wear. Tough mid-calf boots have square toes. Separate leather suspenders (or braces) have some India rubber elastic in back. His thick, beaver, felt hat goes through rain, snow or sun without collapsing. A husky wagoneer was a backbone of rural America, carrying goods and foods, lumber and people, between farms, cities, camps, and to the river boats. An 1815 textile pattern book for looms provided his shirt's handsome 1815 checked design favored throughout the1800s. It is cotton and linen, hand spun, hand- dyed, hand-woven, and hand-sewn, with a large yoke and wooden toggles for buttons
source: Reproduced docent clothing for the LDS Museum of Church History and Art. Shirt fabric woven by Miss Rabbit Goody, who established the Thistle Hill Weavers in New York State. Designed by Carma; leather suspenders were artfully constructed by Dennis Rowley of Pleasant Grove, Utah. Photo and permissions from the Ensign magazine. Wallace Abrams, model

caption: Complete middle class outfit for a wealthy farmer, ca.: 1844.
description: A well-to-do farmer sits in his very clean carriage barn, working on his minor finances. His tall top hat could be straw, and his frock coat, hanging open, is heavy white linen with M-cut lapels. Flaring shirt cuffs extend below the sleeves. A rolled, notched collar tops a fine red vest, and his black tie is carelessly knotted. His trousers are of beige cotton twill above boots with wide, square toes. A jug of good cider is on the floor near his faithful dog. A woman on horseback is ambling away from the barn.
source: Calculating by oil painter Thomas Hicks, from a postcard at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, USA, Karolik Collection. Also seen online.

caption: Milk hawker in London,with a wooden yokecarries brass buckets of milk,.
description: This type of hawker had a long wooden yoke on her shoulders to ease her distribution of fresh milk throughout the big city.She wears a shawl to pad her shoulders,and a fairly short apron over her long skirt. A straw bonnet is tipped forward. A wagon with more milk cans may have awaited her refilling.
source: Jekyll- Gertrude Jekyll, Old English Household Life: Some Account of Cottage Objects and Country Folk (New York, Harper Collins Distribution Services; Revised edition ,September 1975)

caption: A mill-girl of America wears a long apron with back ties over a light plaid dress. 1830s on.
description: Girl working in an American spinning mill wears a plaid dress of low price wool or cotton, and a lightly patterned waist apron. She would have worn one or two petticoats depending on the temperature and whether she had them. Her flat shoes are square-toed from the 1840s to 1870s. Her hair is secured up in rolls or buns on her head, but her clothes are sometimes in real danger of being caught in the machinery. Even small child worked in the mill, crawling under the machines to collect balls of lint. The air was stifling with lint, causing workers of all ages and genders to suffer lung complains and shortened lives. The first American mill that lasted some years was founded in Pawtucket, Rhode island. Later in the larger mills of Lowell, Massachusetts, protests were launched against long hours of work and harsh conditions.
source: Idea taken from mill books of America. Drawn by Carma. Free use.

caption: Detail of a Mill girl of England. While tending spinning machines, she wears an all-over apron with back ties and elbow-length sleeves.
description: A mill-working girl in England wears a dark, cheap fabric dress with elbow-length sleeves.. She protects it with an all-over apron which ties at neckline and waist in back. Her hair is put up in a back bob, but her dangerously loose skirts could be pulled into the machinery, causing injuries. This situation was seldom supervised properly at any level of the ownership and hiring offices. Girls wore as few petticoats as they dared and old flat shoes, and rarely stockings.
source: Drawn by Carma from illustrations in many books describing mill girls.

caption: Minister visiting a family with child in the 1840s-50s.
description: The minister in this illustration is wealthy enough to own dark scholarly robes and a theology-college squared hat. Beneath the robe is regular, good, men's clothing. In this American country home the child are three girls and one small boy. The boy wears a little smock. The younger girl who holds a doll has a cotton dress to her knees and a wide neckline, while the older girl has a longer skirt and a pinafore with a large neckline. The rear girl is probably a teenager with a drawn back hair style. The mother is serving dinner to the minister and her family while the father pours the tea. Grandmother in the background wears a ruffled day cap. Note: the Swansea, Wales Ecumenical Ministry claims that there is no evidence of early Biblical Christians wearing any special clothing. Thus, the existing clergy of each generation just follows what seems a local style to identify themselves. If someone is searching for help from a minister, he or she can be found by the accepted ministerial clothing and assured that the clergy-person is dedicated to being a Christian in teaching and/or helping persons of a religious bent. The clerical dog collar was first used in Scotland some hundreds of years ago. Nowadays, only the Catholics and a few Protestant clergy still wear the outward form of black shirts or robe with white collar inserts in the center.
source: Sketch from a St. Louis, Missouri newspaper found with the Breckenridge Papers of the Missouri Historical Society, St. Louis. Missouri. Free use. The clerical collar is online.

caption: Modern Swedish Fiddlers wearing authentic country clothing of the 1800s.
description: These musicians in todays haircuts are playing for folk dancers at a traditional Swedish festival. They wear leather or twill breeches and colorful, striped vests. Buttons are horizontal across the waist for front-fall breeches. They also have 3 or 4 buttons at the knee and many more on the double-breasted vests. Shirtsleeves are 19 or 20 inches around, for todays larger size population, and gathered into cuffs. Red, white and black wool knit stockings to the knee, are tied up by decorative tasseled tapes. No caps are shown here.
source: From an advertisement in Sweden for tourists at a festival.

caption: Mormon immigrants debarking from Scandinavia and Europe gather in Castle Garden NY, 1878.
description: More women than men are in many of the ships bringing immigrants. Much scuffling with papers is necessary. Many little child seem to have retained their health and sparked their curiosity. Men are often in simple knit caps for less or more warmth, and fairly warm jackets. Women are in mostly long woolen skirts with aprons to preserve their working clothes, There is a lot of long hair among them in beautiful braids, but older women's hair is controlled by form-fitting caps from various nations in differing colors, often black. Immigrants usually had plans to live in ethnic groups north and south in the American Mormon corridor from Arizona to Canada as they spread. If only a single girl came from Europe she would be taken into an LDS home and her board and room given for prodigious work to help establish the new home in a Mormon community. If shge were educated she would be used as an interpreter at times, or a news writer .The best prepared families had brought their own tools, as they were advised in their countries of origin, and could go right to work at their far destination. They were told by Mormon immigration advisors to bring all equipment possible. So many Danes went to Spring City, Utah Territory, it was called Little Denmark for 50 years. Some wanted to settle on farms and would find old friends around them. Some young men will take almost any kind of work to send funds back so the rest of the family can come a year or two later-- or make short-term money so they can get land to start cultivating. Fewer wanted to be in big cities unless they were well-off. Most Immigrants who were poor could only bring bundles of a few clothes or wooden boxes of tools, but one determined woman cannot survive without her small linen or cotton winding wheel we see in the foreground. There is almost no such thing as real luggage yet, except for travelers in high society who have money for fancy large trunks. The immigrants just wrap their possessions in blankets and bags.
source: Designated as Mormons by Frank Leslie's Illustrated. News. January 22,1878.

caption: A Mormon missionary teaching about the Book of Mormon to a country family in Denmark
description: Utah's famous painter, Arnold Friberg copied a painting (with permission) hanging in the National Museum of Art in Copenhagen. The missionary is in a blue frockcoat and warm woolen trousers, rolled up. His hearers pay rapt attention to what he says. Even a maid outside the window is listening. One young man wears a carpenter's apron beside his workbench, and is looking into the Book of Mormon. Standing beside him is his aged father. The grandfather is seated wearing a long black woolen coat and breeches with many silver buttons. He carries papers in a top hat on the floor, and holds a cane in his right hand. In a special rolling chair beside him is a young girl who is unable to walk. She wears a gorgeous standing lace collar around her hair. a flowered shawl is over a red wool bodice. Her skirt is a warm wool of blue and red stripes. The girl in the background is a housemaid listening in to the conversation. She wears a dark serviceable apron and a striped bodice over her white blouse. A kerchief covers her hair. In the next room is a maid ironing, with a green bodice and a red skirt. She has a white cap. Under the carpenter's bench stands a toddler wearing a pink and white long baby dress.
source: The Friberg copy is in the Salt Lake City MCHA.

caption: Londons poor were legion, and without hope.
description: Mother and child in torn, second-hand clothes, without adequate warmth. Mother wears a short gown over a skirt without petticoat. The little girl has no cap and only ragged layers of very old dresses above her flat shoes.
source: A water color brush-drawing of two penniless figures. W. H. Pyne, Akerman's Edition of the "Microcosm," (Published in New York, by Dover, since 1977) Previous publisher in 1970 gave permission to Carma to use drawings at no cost. Small drawings in black and white, Britain.

caption: Mourning Fan, pierced wood
description: These fan-sticks are thin strips of lightweight wood, although there are many tiny round holes pierced through to make a lacy effect. The sticks are painted in black and white to use during later mourning months and years. This fan must have been for a young girl, or an early teenager, for the fan is too small for a grownup. This ingenious design is all curls in black on white, with a ring of metal at the base, which could be used for carrying the fan closed, and on a finger.
source: Courtesy of Wayne County Historical Society, Lyons, New York.  Photo by Carma.

caption: Mourning handkerchiefs of fine linen.
description: English and American mourning handkerchiefs, some with hand stitching and others with machine embroideries and edgings.
source: 1840-41 Jane Tozer and Sarah Leavitt, Fabric of Society p114; Ann Masson and Bryce Reveley. When Lifes Brief Sun Was Set: Portraits of southern Women in Mourning, --1830- 1860. The Southern Quarterly: A Journal of Arts. Hattiesburg, Mississippi: University of Southern Mississippi, 1988.  Drawn by Carma

caption: A fur or fur-fabric muff is, as usual, gathered in over padding and inside is silk lining
description: This fashion accessory is probably a practical 25 inches in circumference, whereas muffs of the early 1800s were much, much larger. This length is 9-11 inches long, with a silk tassel of about 7 inches.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840. ) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections.

caption: Fine white muslin apron with knotted lace.
description: Lace trims on this apron include insertions of lace and a wide edging, as well as tiny horizontal tucks for lines of design between the insertions. On the lowest edge is a simple crocheted faggoting.
source: Unknown donor 35 years ago brought it to Carmas collection, and she restored the broken threads in 30 places, to use it in fashion shows.

caption: Nauvoo Legion coat of dark blue with red sash, originally worn with light or white trousers for legion parades. Ca.: 1842.
description: A dark blue, calf-length coat with brass buttons and epaulettes, was worn with a red sash by John Leavitt in the Nauvoo Legion. He also wore it later in the Davis County(Utah) Militia. The coat was cut straight down from the hip measurement, but was drawn in at the waist by the sash. The Nauvoo Legion was a state-authorized militia of the city of Nauvoo, Illinois. With growing antagonism from surrounding settlements it came to have as its main function the defense of the city of Nauvoo.Wikipedia
source: Leavitts family donated the coat and sash to the Salt Lake City DUP Museum #1690. Photo by Joseph R. Putnam; free use, Free use.

caption: Working woman's neckerchief.
description: In a brightly colored neckerchief -green and red flowered European folk designs are often highlighted by backgrounds or figures in black, as is the border of piece. This neckerchief also has edging bands in gold, which brings to life the gold in the red flowers. Sometimes a neckerchief was used as a mans tie if it were large enough and fine enough fabric to make a small enough knot. However, this one is very likely to be part of a woman's peasant dress for the neck or head.
source: Carmas collection. Photo by Carma

caption: A black satin necktie appears to have been wrapped many times, then tied in a short knot. But a stock tie buttons in the back for convenience, ca.: 1840s.
description: A figured jacquard stock tie is completely fashioned on a flat piece of fabric, then surrounds the neck to button at the narrow back ends. This avoids the tedious wrapping of neckties during the 1840s and earlier for formal clothing. This is of paisley designs on a black background, and is draped and stitched to a stiffened inner fabric that is cut in a wide, modified U-shape. The silk fabric also covers the inside as a flat lining. A separate knot with pointed ends is sewn onto the front, as if it had been tied.
source: Designed and hand sewn by Carma for the Lyon Drug and Mercantile Store in Nauvoo, Illinois, which was restored and stocked with many kinds of appropriate goods, including bits of clothing and textile goods and silk sewing threads. Free use.

caption: American and British newsboys sold medium to small-sized newspapers in all major cities.
description: Young newsboy tries to make a few pennies on the cold streets of Britain or New York City. He wears patched trousers and a very short wool shirt with a single suspender over his shoulder. The hat is a small straw of the cheapest kind, and his feet are bare.
source: Carol Belanger Grafton, Ed, Trades and Occupations: A Pictorial Archive from Early Sources (Dover Pictorial Archive) August 1, 1990

caption: Nicholas Brown Jr. (1769 -1841), businessman and benefactor, sports a beautifully frilled shirt of ca.: 1836
description: The cravat over this fancy formal wear shirt is barely visible. Narrow coat sleeves and longish cuffs turn downward in a genteel manner and show a wisp of his white cuffs. Both his vest and his coat have buttonholes up to their collar attachments, though upper buttonholes were not used. Note the very narrow M-cut on his coat lapel. His father, Nicholas Brown Sr. with his brothers, gave a fortune to establish Rhode Island College. After Nicholas Jr. gave an enormous fortune to augment the college, it was renamed Brown University in honor of the generous family of donors.
source: Several online biographies have information and images.

caption: Norwegian broaches for neck and bodice.
description: The top piece is a single broach in filigree silver is for closure of a neckline. It has dangling bell shapes. The second is a small wreathe pin with seven spoons for glittering
source: Purchased by Carma in Norway.

caption: Norwegian common silver brooch of heart motif, 1 1/2 inches tall.
description: This latticework silver heart of 1700s design has many twisted cords of silver for scroll embellishment. It is pinned in the neckline of a lady's linen blouse. This design of crosshatching with scrolls above is similar to frosting put on tasty Norwegian cookies.
source: Purchased in Norway ,and photo by Carma.

caption: Norwegian womans folk costume from Telemark Province
description: The blouse is made of country calico in a simple gold print. Pale green silk jacquard neck scarf is under a high standing collar, densely embroidered in geometrics-- of the same pale green and gold.
source: Sewn and photo by Carma , with some of her students' assistance, learning how to embroider.

caption: Norwegian folk dress of Osterdal at an ancient log home.
description: Special holidays, family or city special days brought many Norwegians of the higher class out in their regionalcostumes. This womanof "Eastern Dal" wears a white linen blouse with probably some red embroidery at the neckline, under a vest ofpale blue wool. It has a small button closure,and she wears her white linen apron tied around under the edge of the vest. The red skirt could be heavyhand-woven cottonfor summer, and wool for winter. Stockings are hard to see but she has large silver buckles on her shoes, which have a real heel of width on them.
source: "Mittet"--postcard unreachable.

caption: Norwegian gentlemen in folk costume of the last two centuries.
description: One wears a novelty striped red vest, double breasted, with multiple small buttons. His black tie circles a turned up collar. Soft leather breeches have buttons at the knees. His tasseled garters hold up wool stockings in flat black leather shoes with semi-square silver buckles. A white boiled wool coat, unlined, is on the other man, with back bindings emphasizing each section. A red and yellow striped vest is just visible. Below black breeches, his fancy garters are woven on a small inkle-loom, which fits on a table, for spare minutes of sit-down work. . His hat is a medium high topper. Shirts are almost always white linen.
source: Norwegian book

caption: Norwegian girl in a Beltestakk sash of ancient origin. It was specially woven for Carma by the national weaver [a woman] in Skien, Norway, of local design and the most antique color scheme was chosen by Carma.
description: This reproduced NorwegianBeltestakk["bel-ta-stah-ka"] costume was almost all made in America by Carma. The skirt has 11 gores of fine wool so that a girl can whirl around in her log cabin and her hemline will touch all the furniture bordering the room. Well above the hem is a 2 inch band of green velvet below a rust ribbon band of woven gold designs. The apron is black moir silk with pale green, black, white and reddish-colored woven braid designs across the bottom and up 7 on each corner (a necessity of correct design). The ties for the apron are the similar woven designs with black edges. The tie-tapes are long, and cross each other in back to be tied in front, showing off the complicated tassels. The tassels are braided rust, white and black yarn, intricately made.  For complete formality, this costume should have a white linen blouse, but often one sees it with a calico blouse like this small-printed gold one shown here. This blouse copied a Norwegian picture from a folk clothing shop in Skien, on the coast. The sleeves have organ pleated gathers at the top, and simple gathering at the cuffs. The collar is almost 4 inches tall and is densely embroidered in geometric pale green and gold cotton floss. A pale green scarf fits snugly around her neck inside the collar.  Over the blouse is a lovely, airy, golden silk and multicolored shawl, which exposes all the silver jewelry on the woman's blouse front. A dark maroon bodice is low-cut over the blouse with gold trim around the edges.  The belt over the apron and bodice gives the name of Beltestakk to this entire costume from Telemark province. It is an ancient form of belting which is 4 3/4 inches wide. Beneath this dress are black stockings and shoes with high clumpy heels and silver buckles.
source: The model is Rebecca Groesbeck, a descendant of an original Norwegian Mormon convert, Nicholas Groesbeck.

caption: Norwegian grandfather's visit.
description: We see country fashioned men's head gear. The adult son wears a red knitted cap with a flop-over top. The grandfather has a woven wool cap decorated with black wool tape. Both the grandfather and little boy wear breeches with buttons, and gray stockings with flat leather shoes tied by simple cords. Grandfather's vest is heavy green wool with red edging and silver buttons. His outer jacket is old, battered, white wool with red embroidery and green cuffs. The young mother has hair pulled back in a cap and a colorful neck scarf. Her white linen blouse has a large silver broach with "spoons" around it to reflect lights. Her black jacket has red embroideries. Her skirt is heavy mottled wool with a decorative apron rolled up in her lap. The little boy in his red vest holds the string of his toy.
source: An oil painting by Adolph Tideman. NORWEGIAN BOOK or Tideman

caption: Norwegian Head-dress from Vest Agder Folk Museum, front and back views, showing even some decorative stitching of the layers of linen covering.
description: A head scarf frame, a sort of under-crown, is made of wicker and then covered in white linen. When tied on behind the neck, it will hold up a very fine linen head scarf. The five inch height of the headdress adds importance to the folk costume.   Carma sketched the wicker frame, which is rather like a hat brim that stands straight up. The frame has spacer props between the inner and outer circles to hold them in place. A fabric covering of the frame is hand stitched in white cotton or linen. A womans hair would be pulled back and up into a bob. The right drawing shows a soft fabric band at the base of the frame which circles the face to keep any wisp of hair completely hidden. (Folk fashion demanded that the hair not show at all on a married woman.) The headdress frame could be carefully washed on occasion, and passed down through generations. When needed, it could be re-covered with linen or the more modern cotton.
source: Drawn by Carma.

caption: Norway woman
description: This model wearing a Norwegian headdress in Ephraim, Utah, celebration shows how large cotton cords are wrapped around the head and tied in back. White tape woven with red and green designs is stitched in place around the fat cotton cords. Just this hand stitching required 6 full hours of hand sewing by Carma.
source: Photo by Carma.

caption: Norwegian men's woolen folk costume. Collar, back vent, and breeches are appliqued with red wool.
description: A dark brown raisin-colored wool was chosen for a young mans heavy coat and breeches. Silver buttons line both sides of the front over decorative red stitching, as if there were buttonholes. The coat collar displays red boiled wool applique in an ancient Nordic design. Copied by Carma from a picture, and is attached with many small stitches in red thread. The side pocket flaps have additional red applique (not seen).At the top of the coat's back vent is a decorative, appliqued, diamond design and two more silver buttons.  The top of the breeches is covered by a long, blue, wool vest with multicolored, wool embroidery on both sides of its center opening.  His breeches have red, vertical appliques on each side of the broadfall opening. At the knees are red wool appliques with silver buttons. The garters that hold his stockings are of decoratively woven tapes tied on each side.Stockings could be red or dark blue with heavy black shoes.  A silk bow tie in a red and tan print tops his white linen shirt. His black felt hat is a simple rounded fedora.
source: The body of the suit was sewn by Linda Moonwith a brown cotton lining.All decors and buttons were sewn by Carma.Modeled by ColinMurray.Photos by Carma.

caption: Norwegian Mother's Teaching, by Tideman, 1846
description: Amother sits on a low chair to teach her child. On her lap is her latest baby in a blue cap and wool dress. The woman has the typical scarf wrapped around her hair, which gives her warmth and status. Her bodice is dark and her skirt is dark red wool. The apron is a gray, heavy fabric with a small red print.The little girl she faces wears a Norwegian red woven wool cap and a striped blue and tan skirt.The girl on left wears a warm red jacket buttoned across to the side of the front, with a blue windowpane checked apron over a brown wool skirt. It has a stripe of red and green ribbon around the hem: The older girl seemsto be wearing simple, slip-on clogs, but not a total wooden shoe. She knits a stocking while she holds a small basket over her arm to carry her yarn and knitting work: always busy and producing was a female proclivity in the 1600s through1800s.
source: Painting by Tidemand in fromTideman and Gude.

caption: Norwegians packing a cart for travel to a port city for emigration. Center woman carries her Bride Box.
description: A donkey or pony cart with large spoked wheels has its two long staves up against the slight hill as luggage is brought down to load for emigration to America. Some luggage is just tied up in blankets. A young woman carries out all the specially valuable things in her "Bride Box" that she has accumulated through growing up years. Shewouldkeep her Bride Box always close to her.
source: Photo of image by Carma, Wisconsin State Historical Society, Madison, Wisconsin.

caption: Norwegian street clothes of 1852, painted by Dan Weggeland in Norway. He was an LDS convert and artist who emigrated to Utah.
description: The Norwegian man on the street wears natural, white wool breeches and a hip length coat. Fancy white cotton knitted stockings are held up with small string garters. His coat is much worn and collarless, with silver buttons high to the neckline. A very high-necked vest is double-breasted, red wool, and also has smaller silver buttons.His white linen shirt has some embroidered decor anda closure of silver clasps. His shoes are comfortable flats with a small tie. A jaw-line white beard covers the rest of his neckline. Long hair hangs to his shoulders. Over his perpetually pleasant face (often seen even today in Norway) is a black felt top hat of average height for Europeans. His walking stick is long to aid in hilly climbs.
source: The small watercolor on paper is 11 3/4 inches by 6 inches painted by Weggeland from his lifelong knowledge of Norwegian clothing in big cities. This picture is included in a book of paintings from those housed in theLDS Museum of Church History and Art in Salt Lake City.Photo by Carma.

caption: Norwegian, striped petticoat of dainty cotton.
description: On this extremely A-line petticoat, extra strips of bias-cut fabric are added toward the hem. This makes the stripes on the petticoat alternately vertical and diagonal, a very pleasant confusion of stripes. Such a petticoat would be worn over other petticoats of linen and wool to give fullness to the outer skirt of silk or alpaca, worn in the city.
source: This garment was seen in the National Art Museum in Oslo,Norway, and drawn by Carma .

caption: Norwegian woven wool stocking
description: Bright embroideries are up the sides of the ankle to the calf in this dark blue woven wool stocking. It has no bottom sole in the stocking; edges just tucked into shoes.
source: Norwegian Tour advertisementfrom a painting by Adolf Tidamand. This was copied in watercolor by Carma.

caption: Older woman in day dress, long apron and day cap, 1839
description: This woman wears a reproduction of a wool and cotton dress in a well-faded plaid, shirred at the shoulders and top of sleeves. A practical, grey apron, long to the ankles, doesn't have to be as good-looking as a spotless day cap, carefully shirred and ruffled. This woman represents the Mormons, young and old, who were forced from Missouri by death-dealing mobs in 1839. Many had little to begin with as they carved out farms from Missouri's fertile soil, but the pillage and murders drove them away again so fast they had not time to gather supplies for sustenance or comfort.
source: Historical and reproduced clothing for Patricia Hayes in Little Dorrit. Permission from Lord Snowdon, photographer.

caption: The Old Green Store, where Workingmen unload barrels of liquor while well-dressed men look on. 1847.
description: A carriage driver directs one boy to deliver a small barrel of spirits, while a man in a smock rolls a large barrel, probably beer, through the crowd. The driver is bursting his double-breasted coat and wears a low-crowned stiff hat. Top-hats and fine clothes are seen in the crowd. The man in the white smock wears a weathered old felt hat, while the man behind him has a large pilots cap.
source: Seen in: Gerald Carson, Country Stores in Early New England. (Sturbridge Village, Old Sturbridge Village Inc. 1955)

caption: Detail of an old woman with stenciled walls in her decorated home, ca.: 1841.
description: A folk painting of a socially prominent grandmother in a black dress. In the mid-1800s, black was a common color to wear during advanced age. There are wide pleats from shoulders to center waist point, and narrow sleeves. Her day cap is of white lawn with tight ruffles around her face. She is sitting in a special writing and reading chair with a small desktop attached to one chair arm. A pair of spectacles is held in her hand.
source: Folk artist, Jacob Maentel, painted this in 1841 in Indiana, USA. Exhibited in the Rockefeller Art Center of Colonial Williamsburg, Virginia. Free use.

caption: Orrin Porter Rockwell, Joseph Smiths bodyguard, shown in middle age with his lifetime, long hair. Ca. 1842.
description: Porter is shown warmly dressed in a checkered scarf. He was friends with the Prophet Joseph Smith ever since a close childhood. Prophesied Joseph Smith, So long as ye shall remain loyal and true to thy faith, you need fear no enemy. Cut not they hair and no bullet or blade can harm thee. Many knew of Porter, and feared him because he was a dead shot, clever, and very strong (note the pistol in his hand). Only late in his life, when the prophet was gone, he cut his hair to make a wig for the Prophet's cousin who had lost her hair in sickness.
source: Black and white Image in BYU Special Collections and online. Color image painted using historic photo by Ken Corbett, 2010, seen online. Free use.

caption: Outside of skirt is above.Below is the inside facing for hemline of Danishskirt.A little wool check augments the silk novelty vest fabric used for facing the hem.
description: The inside of womans Danish red wool and goat hair striped folk-wear skirt. Black decorative silk cording is sewn on the edge around the skirt. Below that is the brown silk novelty vest fabric
source: CARMA FIND THIS IN WHITE BOX

caption: Painting of Norwegian Christmas party tradition of feeding birds in the snow. Large oil by Adolf Tideman,1846.
description: This Norwegian Christmas scene includes a large bunch of wheat stocks secured to the peak of the roof to feed birds, while warmly dressed neighbors celebrate the season. Women consistently wear heavy black wool skirts over many petticoats for warmth.They often have decorative bodices which are covered by short, red, wool jackets. Some have aprons and fancy belts.All women have head coverings, whether agirls tiny red cap, her mothers white linen wrap with a green scarf, or an older woman's black head wrap. child become used to the cold in Norway, wearing various caps. The boy in the center has a typically Swedish and Norwegian round cap of red wool with black braid. Another boy has a very common, pointed, red, knitted hat as he falls from his skis.Long and short jackets are on all males. One tiny girl is enveloped in a huge green shawl.
source: From a book on Tideman's paintings:Adolph Tideman and Hans Fredrik Gude, Tideman and Gude, (Drammen, Norway, StiselsenModumsBlaafarvevaerk, 1849)

caption: Printed paisley designs on white kashmir wool.
description: Printed paisley designs on white kashmir wool. Beautiful pale blues. pinks, reds and dark brown. Self fringed.
source: Brought from England by Gorge and Lucy Taylor, early pioneers. Probably an import from France to England. DUP #8259. Donor, Della O'Dell. Photo by Lorie Davis for Carma.

caption: Shawl 1850 plus
description: Top half of image shows the right side of this Paisley shawl; the lower half shows the colored threads "carried" across the back side between designs, each color taken on to another position in the design. CD Fig ?, Top half of image shows the right side of the Paisley, the lower half shows the colored threads "carried" across the back side between designs, each color taken on to another position in the design. Shawls made in India, with their elaborate scroll and pinecone motifs were a great favorite across Europe and the British Isles from the late 1700s well into the 1800s. They were made of soft kashmir wool. This shawl shows the fringe completely worn off. On the right a spot of blue yarns shows where the fringe used to be all around the edge. This very old shawl was originally in India and is not a copy-cat shawl made in Paisley, Scotland. The Scottish were so conservative of their finances and materials that when a shawl was finished with tight weaving, there was a machine that sheared off the carried woolen threads from the back. These extra bits of wool were re-carded and re-dyed and re-spun to weave more shawls!
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Photo by Michael Paul .

caption: Paisley Shawl in orange, red black and brown print on white challis wool.
description: Paisley shawl design n orange, red and brown print on white challis wool. Worn across the plains by Margory (sic) Smith of the Willey Handcart Company, 1856.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum #10636. Donor, Jen Wilson Madsen. Photo by Michael Paul.

caption: Paisley shawl, folded, in Salt Lake City DUP Museum.
description: Paisley shawl at Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Designs are elongated paisleys printed on kashmir wool.
source: Used in Nauvoo about 1844. Brought across plains in 1850 by Eliza Doty Cravath. Salt Lake City DUP Museum, #4625. Donor, Orpha H. Stohl. Photo by Michael Paul.

caption: Paisley shawls made in Paisley, Scotland, 1850s,were sold throughout Europe. This red shawl was brought to Lehi, Utah by Scandinavian pioneers.
description: Paisley shawls made in Paisley, Scotland, 1850s,were sold throughout Europe. This gorgeous red shawl was brought to Lehi, Utah by Scandinavian pioneers. It is sixty inches long and fifty inches wide with wide paisley borders on the ends, and lesser borders down the sides. It is worn over a red wool plaid dress made by Carma. The broad felt hat is decorated with pale blue ribbons. The man is wearing a red wool cape described elsewhere. His gray felt hat was made in Scotland. He also wears fashionable yellow leather gloves. The couple modeling are named Mr. and Mrs. Herrick.
source: Clothing is in Carmas collection. Photo by Joseph R Putnam

caption: A parasol with a hinged handle made this sunshade more compact in a group situation or when no longer needed.
description: A circle of black lace is specially made for a parasol. This has a scalloped ruffle around it and is lined with white silk .The white painted wooden, hinged handle allows it to be folded up when the sun fades away.
source: Photographed by permission at Cat's Cradle Antiques in Provo, Utah by Carma.

caption: Parisian corset with baleen stays, laced in back, hooked in front, with lace edging.
description: This corset is unusual for the black lace on it, as well as ribbons that embellish it. It could be adjusted in back by lacing, which made it easier to put on by hooking up the front. Baleen (cartilage from the mouth of a whale)was strong enough to last a long time, even to the 21st century. Corsets in America and most of Europe went completely out of fashion in the middle of the 20th century, when clothing became comfortable in modern times.
source: This image from in Ernshaw, BYU LIBRARY LACE Permissions.

caption: Parley P. Pratt in heavy winter clothes, ca;1840s
description: A missionary who walked hundreds of miles in the US and British Isles, Parley P. Pratt wears a thick winter coat and high boots through icy weather. Pratt was diligent and intelligent in supporting Joseph Smith's efforts to spread the The Book of Mormon and the Church's teachings.
source: Ink drawing by Robert Barrett with clothing coached by Carma. Barrett is especially good in producing correct facial features. Displayed in Grandin Print Shop, Palmyra, New York.

caption: Hair style of Patriarch John Smith. Brother of Joseph Smith Senior, ca.: 1838.
description: Patriarch Smith had long sideburns that were kept neatly clipped, and no beard. His well-starched collar stands up from a silky black neckerchief with splayed ends. A very kind and spiritual man, according to many early Mormon diaries, Smith was a member of the Presiding High council of the LDS Church in Kirtland, Ohio. He continued in leadership service until his death in 1854.
source: This oil on canvas is a sensitive portrayal of a much loved man (artist unknown). Seen in Salt Lake City MCHA.

caption: Patty Bartlett Sessions best dress of plaid from late 1830s or early 1840s.
description: This is the youngest picture we have of Patty Bartlett Sessions, famous Mormon midwife, in a quality wool plaid dress. At this date there was still fullness at the top of slightly dropped-shoulder sleeves. She was fastidious about her day caps, collars and cuffs. She was by nature a cleanly person, but not given to pretentions. She wears a handsome square brooch from the time of her marriage fastening a small embroidered collar. Her day cap shows pretty flowers made of bits of silky fabrics and wire, which adorn the small ruffles on each side of her face. A chain about her neck was attached to a little, flattened watch tucked into the waistline pocket of her bodice. She cared little about enormous petticoats, for she moved rapidly around in the events of her life. In 1837 Queen Victoria ascended the British throne and used plaids excessively in silks and Scottish woolens for herself and all her attendants at Balmoral Castle. Soon, plaids in every fiber became more fashionable throughout the English-speaking world and much of Europe. British India was putting out cheap, plaid cotton ginghams by shiploads, bought by the poorest in any British province and American dry goods stores. Patty married at age 17, having grown up in the Maine woods. Highly intelligent, she felt great compassion for others. Becoming a midwife, she had consistent successes in the nearly 4000 births she aided in her lifetime. Pattie's talented hands were always busy, taking sewing materials along as she waited for babies to be born. Crossing the plains, she darted in and out of wagons and traveled by horseback even to a company behind or ahead, wherever needed. If scraps were available to make baby clothes, or her own collars and cuffs, she sewed on them in every spare minute. Her husband, David Sessions, helped Patty raise their own large family. She rode horses well, so, for the rest of her life, she rode anywhere to put a mother "to bed." There, she cared for the family until the mother felt well and confident. Patty's own family became accustomed to having her leave in an instant, no matter where they lived.
source: LDS Archives. Also From Internet: https://mormonbloke.wordpress.com/2015/02/27/trail-of-hope/

caption: Paying Stable Helpers in The Reconning, by George Morland.
description: An English boy who helps in the stables wears a white linen smock over his wool dress, and covers his stockings with buttoned gaiters to the knee. Poorer boys often wore dresses until age 7 or 8. A smaller boy who brings beer to the owner wears a black apron and a red wool vest. Both boys have shaggy hair and brown leather shoes. Painted ca 1800, clothing is typical through 1830s.
source: The Reconning, by George Morland, ca. 1800. Victoria and Albert Museum, London. given by F. Peel Round.

caption: People on the cold street of an English city can buy a hot drink before going home. 1840-60.
description: The woman in the foreground has two shawls: rust colored with gold fringe, and blue with a red stripe. Her heavy apron is brown over a wool skirt of gray-green. She has a small shawl over her black straw bonnet. While sitting on a milk can she drinks her coffee, and the yoke by which she was carrying two milk cans is on the stones beside her. The man in the black bowl hat wears a double breasted coat with a cape over the shoulders. He is in rust colored trousers with a tan scarf. . The man dispensing hot coffee wears a topper and an overcoat with brown fur lapels. A young couple on the left have coats and shawls. The girl's brown straw hat is far back on her head. Her companion has a maroon scarf tucked into a green vest, and his soft cloth hat is made of wool sections carefully sewn together. Advertisements are posted on the stone wall beside the coffee cart.
source: Large tinted engraving of 1860 by Linton in England, other data unknown; purchased by Carma at a low-priced imported art sale.

caption: Petticoat from Hindsted, Aalborg, Denmark with bow-knots and tiny flowers.
description: A black silk petticoat is aprinted silk designed with a decorative band running down one side of the fabric on the loom. The petticoat will be cut so as to feature the band horizontally near the hem. This undergarment is meant to be worn under more voluminous petticoats, and has a narrow waistband with a small button in the center back. This image was taken from a Xerox of the petticoat, so the color may be actually any dark color or black.
source: Aalborg Historical Museum, #13599 Photocopy given to Carma.

caption: Philippe Cardon, father of a large family, came from the Piedmont area of Northern Italy in 1850s-- all family converted by LDS missionaries
description: Father Cardon's double breasted coat has virtually no padding in the shoulders. The lapels are wide enough to have been tailored in the late 1830s, with buttons appearing to be covered with silk. His shirt collar is comfortably turned down with a dark-colored silk tie in a plain knot. His very shorthair and combed to the right side with tufts of beard on each side of his chin.
source: Genevieve Porter Johnson and Edna Cardon Taylor,compilers, Cardons! Descendents of Philippe Cardon and Marthe Marie Tourn 1799-1886, (Provo, Utah, Stevenson's Genealogy Center, 1990) Permission from Larry C. Porter.

caption: Girl's wool plaid hood and capelet
description: A girl's wool plaid hood and capelet was pieced together from scraps. The top point is blunted by a short seam sewn inside across the point. The hood is tied under the chin with cording of the same soft wool, and is lined with gray cotton flannel. It has been highly distressed to look well-worn for Carma's fashion shows.
source: Sewn by Carma. Photo on a mannequin head by Joseph R. Putnam

caption: Man's plush top hat has some silk fiber content or it could not be brushed to make a soft sheen on the outside
description: This medium-tall black felt topper has an early 1800s narrow, grosgrain ribbon around the crown with a 3/8 inch buckle. Silk fibers in the felt let it be brushed to a shine in the nap. It had seen much use when given to the Historical Society and was probably worn on the heads of various citizens through many years.
source: Ontario County Historical Society, New York. Photo by Carma

caption: Pocket book of striped linen and cloth or tape binding.
description: This improved on a waistline pocket tied on a woman for going out into social situations of marketing or traveling.
source: A freehand drawing by Carma after a photo in Fennely, The Garb of Country New Englanders

caption: Police in Longton, Pottery District, Staffordshire England, arresting members of an angry mob harassing Mormon missionaries  in 1860s
description: British mobs usually called police to throw in jail the  Mormon missionaries who arrived in England. The policeman has a high hat with a brim and wears a longish dark, form fitted coat with a stout belt and insignia. The Mobs wear every kind of hat from shapeless felt to top hats, pilot caps and knit caps. A man in front has a checkered shirt with a vest over it. Once in 1868 there was a most unusual mob scene, as shown here. The mob called protection authorities to come. As they did, the police listened to them mercilessly heckling missionaries as they were street preaching of Christ. After a few moments police turned the tables and arrested the mobbers for their rough and illegal way they yelled, pushed and threatened the missionaries. Key figures of the mob spent the night in jail, as the missionaries returned gratefully to their own dwellings.
source: All glued together from bits and pieces if small prints by Carma to create the scene. Information from letters to Salt Lake City sent from English convert Osmond Broad Shaw who was sent by Brigham Young on a mission back to his homeland during the years1868 to the end of 1869. From letters in Carmas possession from her own great grandfather. The image here is a collage of many public illustrations with Carmas drawings to enhance it.

caption: Poor, shabby child of New Haven, Scotland, all but one barefoot.
description: child are shown by the cage of animals theyve brought for sale at a fair. Two boys have hats, but all are barefoot. The boy with piglet seems to wear only a shirt and vest on top with no coat or sweater.
source: David Bruce, Sun Pictures, Calotypes.

caption: Poor Englishman in multiple, ill-fitting vests, but no coat over  his ragged shirt sleeves. Early 1800s
description: This is extremely worn out clothing was probably acquired at the poor people's rag exchange in southern England.. No one seems available to hem the mans trousers short enough. His felt hat is almost shapeless.
source: William Johnstone White, edited by Pamela Clabborn, Working Class Costume from Sketches of Characters, (London, Dedalus Press for Victoria and Albert Museum, by Costume Society, c.o. Department of Textiles. 1977.)

caption: Poor women gleaning grain.This could be seem in both Britain and America
description: After the main harvests are over on large farms, poor women and child were often allowed into the fields to glean some free grain they could use for their own food. This was a practice from Biblical times to the present. Even harvests in early Utah had gleaners going over the fields from the thousands of converts who poured into the Utah Territory to live, and had not yet any money-making jobs. Brigham Young taught in LDS Conferences all over the territory that gleaning was a good thing to do and no one should hinder it. He often preached against wastefulness and promoted recycling everything possible in the more isolated West.
source: : Pyne, W. H, Akerman's Edition of the 'Microcosm.' New York: Dover, 1977,augmented in ink by Carma

caption: Porcelain bust of Joseph Smith, Jr., viewed from above to show hair style,
description: This sculpture shows the parting of his hair from around the back of the head which is swept down and forward. Then his front hair is folded back over, which creates a fullness above the forehead. From a study of the hairstyles of Joseph Smith's time, this parting of the hair around the crown and combing it forward was popular.
source: Carma advised (the late) Florence Peterson Hansen in sculpting the hair and clothing on this beautiful bust of the Prophet, which is one half life-size. Photo by Carma; free use.

caption: Porcelain-headed-and-handed doll in Denmark, possibly French with 1830s dress
description: Seen in Denmark and probably imported from France.
source: In Den Gamble By historic site in Aarhus, Denmark, The Old Town Museum. Photo by Carma.

caption: Reversible smock on a Potato seller in America or Britain, ca.:1830-50.
description: A contemporary, watercolor brush drawing of a village potato market shows two sellers in long, smocks. The man in center wears a very plain, long smock which is reversible. It has identical, triangular neck openings front and back that fasten with a single button, and allow him to alternate sides to distribute wear. The woman at right back has a wide tray of bread loaves on her head to sell. All wear a variety of old, crushed hats. Some potatoes are in baskets, but others are in large sacks with another smocked man resting on top of them. It appears that the men wear gaiters  the man on left with very long, over-the-knee gaiters, which may have protected him from the dirt of the potato fields, or from excessive wear on his knees.
source: W. H. Pyne, artist, in "Microcosm,"

caption: Press printing with child help in manufacturing towns of England and Wales. 1840s and 50s
description: This apprentice boy has an old linen shirt with trousers probably hand-me-downs of poor quality. He has two long suspenders but likely not a warm enough coat for his growing body. Long hours of work from penniless child gave them little or no time to be taught other basic skills of life. child like this learned how to print, but missed so much else of the skills, beauties or delights of life.
source: Jules Ginswick, Labour and the Poor in England and Wales 1849-1951: Vol. 1, Lancashire -Cheshire, Yorkshire (UK, Routledge; 1st edition, 1983). Not in print.

caption: Print dress with bell-shaped sleeves, engageants, and day cap. The model holds about a dozen ells of folded linen, ca; 1840.
description: This print dress has elbow-length, bell-shaped sleeves which require simple engageants from elbow to wrist to cover her fore-arms. She has a lace collar on her fine cotton dress and decors of dark braid trim her wide sleeves. Petticoats widen her skirt. The day cap has batiste ruching around her face and neck with narrow ribbons tied under her chin. The model portrays the daughter of a weaver delivering many ells of refined linen to a client. (An ell is an English/American unit of weaving, comparable in length to 45 inches of fabric.)
source: Clothing sewn and Photo by Carma; free use. The model is Holly Hinckley Lesan.

caption: Young woman of ordinary means in Scotland wears a printed dress in a Calotype image.
description: Margaret Morgan wears a fine cotton dress with a dark leaf print on a light ground. It had a tiny white-work collar of miniature scallops and a silk scarf pinned around her neck. Sleeves set in the drop shoulder were narrowing toward the cuffs , augmented by white work in the 1840s.when this calotype was made. She would twist or braid her long, uncut, front hair and neatly fasten it up into her back bob. The alternative for formality (and a lot of labor) was ringlets in front. The corset she wore created a "shelf" bust-line so her bodice never had a smooth line unless she were standing up. Her less expensive "Kashmir" shawl is white with a multicolored Indian design printed on it.
source: Calotype by David Octavius Hill in David Bruce.

caption: curled brim Quaker mans hat, with edges neatly bound in grosgrain ribbon.
source: Online: http: //.4www. us hist. com/19th-century_mens_hats. shtml#item19b

caption: A kind Quaker in his wide-brimmed hat talking with and teaching child who often followed him around.
description: Friend Goodrich wore his old breeches and stockings and a long plain coat. He loved child and spent time with them as well as writing about his being raised in a loving Quaker community--which helped him figure out solutions to childhoods problems.
source: Samuel G. Goodrich, Recollections of a Lifetime (New York, Miller, Orton and Mulligan, 1856).

caption: Rttvik, Swedish Folk Dress modeled by a Utah teen with wonderful long blonde hair for Carma's fashion show.
description: This dress does not have a separate black skirt with a striped apron, as the genuine costume would have, but for selling to tourists, the back of the skirt is made of black cotton. Then the front has the apron colors of red, yellow, black, green and white stripes sewn together from separate cotton pieces. Outside the bodice is a wide black velvet very low bodice over a full scale bodice of printed red roses on green background cotton, with wide strips of solid red on all edges seen here separately). Green or red ribbon bows are tied on each side of front bodice pieces, to adjust it to the height of the girl's upper body. This is always worn with a high necked, long sleeved white blouse, and a flat little black cap fitted on the head. When worn, the cap forms a point on the head where it is held together in the center seam by red cotton binding. There is fabric stiffening inside the cap's linen lining. Around the face is a line of tiny handmade white lace. On each side the cap is a red tasseled strong inch-wide tape, not meant to tie beneath the chin. An appropriate stole for warmth came with it, about 20 inches wide and 50 inches long. Amazingly it was red and green plaid! Plaids were used all over the world with different nations' folk costumes. Is there any way this Rtvik costume could be more "jazzed up?"
source: Purchased by an American tourist to Sweden in 1927, and recently given to Carma for her historic collection.

caption: A man's original red and green wool shawl belonging to Joseph Cain from the Isle of Man, brought to America by 1849.
description: A man's original red and green wool shawl belonging to Joseph Cain from the Isle of Man, brought to America by 1849.It has self-fringe and was worn over the regular coat and vest of a man who did not have other warm outerwear. When his child were finally settled in Salt Lake City, they asked him to give them the shawl. He tore it into 4 pieces, 3 for his child's keepsakes of the original trek, and the fourth piece donated to the Salt lake City DUP Museum.
source: Photographed by Michael Paul. Free to ues.

caption: Red Paisley Shawl made in Scotland as a valuable copy of those from East India.
description: A highly elaborate, soft, kashmir shawl was brought to Lehi, Utah, by pioneers in the later 1800s. It is in near perfect condition, sixty inches long and fifty inches wide with wide paisley borders in many colors on the ends, and lesser borders down the sides.
source: Purchased in Lehi for Carma's personal collection. Photo by Joseph R. Putnam.

caption: Red shawl of fine kashmir, embroidered in silk. From Dronninglund,Hjorring, Denmark.
description: On this triangular shawl, a wide border of leaves and flowers is embroidered equally throughout to be worn with either side showing! What a feat! At the corners are some triangular designs. The rest of the shawl is scattered with medallions of small flowers. The fringe extends from the cashmere wool of the shawl itself,
source: Exhibited in the Aalborg, Historical Museum, #8477 in Hjorring, Denmark. A photo copy image given to Carma by the Museum as a Xerox with information, when Carma had to leave the museum quickly.

caption: American Atlantic sailors on a ship in port are repairing sails, 1840-80.
description: These sailors are using their time while in port to repair their canvas sails, an endlessly repeated task. They wear warm woolen coats and jackets, most with wide white collars outside their coats, and tall hats. An older sailor wears only shirtsleeves with a small round cap.
