He has a dark neckerchief tucked into his shirt. Ports would be anywhere from Boston to Charleston. Every sailor needed to know how to sew with large needles and strong thread for canvas.
source: Trades and Occupations, A Pictorial Archive from Early Sources, Carol Belanger Grafton, Dover Publications, Inc.,1990

caption: Draped ribbons of mid-1800s would have been heavy silk satin or taffeta from France..
description: A multi-colored plaid ribbon was used on bonnets or around the neck of a dress with a broach. The leaf green ribbon with gold and white edging stripes was a favorite color to wear with blue accessories, a color combination from Mother Nature.
source: BYU Fine Arts Collection of Historical Clothing. Purchased in France and Germany by Carma

caption: Romanticized chance meeting at byway Shrine in Norway. Peasant girl speaks to young hunter.
description: A Gudbrandsdal man hunts in the fall in his red knit cap and tall black boots that reach his knees.He likes his white wool stockings and colored tape garters. His pants are tan wool, probably lined with cotton or linen. His natural white blanket-weight wool coat is cutaway with designs of brown buttons down the front, and unbuttoned pockets on each side, perhaps to carry ammunition. Theres a neckerchief tucked in his coat. He has shot a large bird! The young woman asks questions, and the man points an answer. She wears a common black cap of wool or silk, embroidered in black. Her neckerchief is simple blue with white and pink flowers. Her fitted jacket, much like a shortgown, is royal blue wool over a green and black striped skirt. Her hand-knit stockings match her jacket, and her shoes are black slip-ons.
source: This is an antique postcard showing costumes from Gudbrandsdal, #8425, Atlantis Antikvariat, Oslo, Norway.

caption: Rough seas that tossed the passengers and their food made life miserable in 1800s sailing ships.
description: The man in the center top is traveling in a linen smock, other men wearing pilot caps and one felt hat. The woman in center left wears a daycap.
source: From Dennis Judd, The Victorian Empire 1837-1901(New York? Prager, 1970).

caption: American sailor holding a sextant, all 1800s
description: Common Sailors often wore heavy white cotton pullover shirts with a large square collar on the back of their shoulders and a front V neckline. Their pants were also white, heavy cotton or black wool or Navy blue wool. In cold climes they wore heavy wool jackets buttoned over their shirts, or in later 1800s could buy oiled canvas rain guards, called "slickers" for managing the sails in driving rain storms. Often young underlings on a ship were wet much of the time.
source: From a small advertisement.

caption: Samuel W. Richards, LDS political and religious leader, shown in a fine coat, shirt, vest and tie. Ca.: 1840s to 50s.
description: Samuels coat and vest are barely detailed, but he has a pleated yoke on the front of his pullover shirt. The 9 inch opening shows 2 tiny buttons for closure. The collar is turned down over a bow-tied cravat which probably buttoned in the center back of his neck. His satin vest with a rounded shawl collar is double breasted with small buttons. The coat lapels have additional sewn-on sections of buttonholes (called revers) from top to bottom, but they are not worn buttoned at the top. Samuel Richards had more hair than some of his brothers, and it is cut here at ear length.
source: Drawn or engraved by Frederick Piercy who did many illustrations of Church leaders and pioneers coming from England and crossing the plains. Seen in Mormon Historical Studies by Matthew Chatterly, online, portraits courtesy of Maurine Carr Ward. Free use.

caption: Sarah de Armon Pea Rich wears beautifully made accessories with her dark dress. Her hair is in a popular style, ca.: 1840s.
description: Beautifully made accessories are shown in an oil portrait of Sarah de Armon Pea Rich, the bride of Charles Coulson Rich. A delicate embroidered lawn tucker fills her neckline, with a wide, semi-sheer collar held by a rectangular enameled broach. Lace is around her collar as well as her wrist cuffs. We see a double, gold necklace, and a ring on her index finger. Her navy, wide-neck dress has diagonal tucks from shoulder to center front point, and her skirt has un-pressed pleats for its massive width. Sarahs long, dark hair is in multiple braids looped around her ears, with an unseen bun in back. A woman liked to show off her pretty, shell-like ears.
source: Detail of an oil painting, painter unknown. Photo by Carma in the Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Free use.

caption: Accessory cap for a folk costume in Scandinavia.
description: This two-piece black woolen cap (with linen lining) is on a white plastic display "head." It would be worn on the back of a person's head and the hair would be smoothed back from a center part and made as close to the scalp as possible. The cap's a strip of some length of fabric to attach over the top of the head to covers almost to the hairline around the face. In this design, most of the woolen embroidery is concentrated on the rounded back fabric. There are some auxiliary fancy stitches to make the front sides pretty with more curly flowers placed near the cheeks. In different counties of Scandinavia the caps vary from very plain to heavily embroidered all over the exterior. A great number of them have a colorful binding around the edge as seen here in the popular red color. Sometimes there was a little white cap worn under it, or white lace could be around the face of either cap.
source: This was purchased at an antique store in the USA long ago in case Carma needed it for a costume. It could be from any Northern country, depending on the maker's taste; but it could not be from Iceland.

caption: Scandinavian Girl
description: childs clothing
source: Drawn by Carma

caption: Scandinavian man in seal skin coat and wool cap with slight brim.
description: Sealskin is ideal to wear in a rainy climate, since seals live in water. The coat collar came from white baby seals. The buttons on this coat are large and strong, possibly metal for overcoats. This man has short cut hair beneath his red wool cap. We see a bit of collar and silk knotted tie at the neckline.
source: This photo was given to Carma with no note of origin. Source unknown.

caption: Scandinavian Marriage Wreath with hair samples from bride and groom.
description: Marriage wreath in a large, elaborately framed shadow box lined in black velvet. Flowers are, botanical European "straw" flowers, using only white ones. Added are other natural sprigs of white in addition to tiny white artificial flowers. The Scandinavian immigrants were probably Norwegians. This strawflower wreath was obviously a home-made delight in one of the later towns founded in Utah. Native Norwegian bridal headdresses in the last 300 years were usually a metal frame adorned with all kinds of jewels (real or manufactured), and metallic fabric ribbons, which became "Wedding Crowns" (seen elsewhere).
source: Carma bought this marriage keepsake from Spanish Fork at an antique store in Provo, Utah.

caption: Scandinavian woman's tan wool shortgown, back view.
description: Has a box pleat in the back, and a V neck in front. Added pieces of wool lengthen the sleeves, with a sleeve folded to the back to view it: not full length, but "work length." The shortgown lining is cream cotton muslin to make it strong.
source: This item was made by Carma, and severely distressed for international fashion shows. No buttons to close it in front, but it closed over the chemise by an apron tied around it.

caption: Sea captain with his sextant (astrolabe). Ca: 1700s to 1900s
description: The Captain has a flat topped cap that is not as deep as a Kepi military cap but is snug on his head with small front brim. The dense wool coat is good for protection in cold winds. His coat collar is possibly heavy corded silk or silk velvet. Dark trousers are equally warm on deck.
source: Carol Belanger Grafton, Ed. Trades and Occupations: A Pictorial Archive from Early Sources (Dover Pictorial Archive) Paperback  August 1, 1990

caption: Seamed stockings on a working man. Originated in Britain, worn in America,. 1810-1850
description: This hard working man with low pay wears breeches that bag a lot in the seat, and has his long worn- out apron with a shaggy hemline. His shirt, without a vest, still has the wrists buttoned with two buttons, After taking off his battered straw hat he is walking to work or home with stockings that have seams up the back. This shows that his stocking had been made on a knitting machine, and were knitted of cotton or wool in one flat piece. Then they were farmed out to local seamstresses and hand sewn with matching threads to make them into a tube of varying widths up the leg. There was more width for the heels, then narrowing for upper ankles, then much more width again for the calves of legs. A working man could actually buy his stockings commercially at a store in the early 1800s if he had no one to knit stockings for him. This was a time of certain areas in America and Britain where ready- made clothing was beginning to be manufactured in quantity.  Knitting machines in Britain produced fine wool for wealthy men's skin- tight breeches
source: William Johnstone White, edited by Pamela Clabborn, Working Class Costume from Sketches of Characters, (London, Dedalus Press for Victoria and Albert Museum, by Costume Society, c. o. Department of Textiles. 1977.

caption: A seamstress wears a fashionable silk dress as she carefully arranges white lace for a customers order, ca.: 1840s-50s
description: Although a working woman, a seamstress had to dress well to advertise her fashion sense and skills. This ladys lovely dress is a dark and light basket-weave print on silk. It has wide, lacey black trim above her elbows, and narrow white lace standing at her high neckline. The bodice has a shirred bosom with long, slim sleeves. Her glossy, dark hair falls in two long side-ringlets.
source: 6th plate daguerreotype, Minnesota Historical Society, St. Paul, Minnesota. PERMISS345 W. Kellogg Blvd. St. Paul, MN 55102 651-259-3000  1-800-657-3773 director@mnhs.org

caption: Serge Ballif ("Bah-eef ")awell dressed man of some means in French-tailored clothing (1821-1901).
description: Serge has a fashionable mustache and short beard for his origins in Switzerland. There is a French tailoring in his beautifully bound collar and lapels of about 1860. His stiff shirt collar stands up with front points sharply turned down, and his tie has pale figures on medium tones of silk. He wears no sideburns, and his hair is short and neat.  The Ballifs of Lausanne, Switzerland had come from a long line of noblity with very high education. Elder T. B. H. Stenhouse baptized Serge Louis Ballif, an ancestor to President Ezra Taft Benson..Brother Ballif gave money to support missionaries and many types of Church publications. He baptized several other Swiss families who emigrated with him to America., where he gave great service to community and church.Later he returned to Switzerland as an effective missionary, speaking French and German from 1879-81. He died in Logan, Utah
source: BYU Lee library, Special Collections.

caption: Emma Hale Smith's black silk shawl.
description: A shawl probably kept for mourning; about 38 inches square. It has contrasting woven-in lines around the edges and is self fringed. Emma Smith had so many people to mourn through the 1830s onward among her family members.
source: Private collection in Independence, Missouri ,which family descended from early inhabitants of Nauvoo, Illinois. Photo by Carma

caption: Shawl from Scotland of black kashmir center with colorful tapestry borders
description: this shawl is almost 5 ft. long and 3 ft. wide. It is solid black kashmir in the center, but all edges are designed 23 inches deep, with the ends having larger designs of about 30 inch depth of beautiful tapestry. Woven in intricate, multi-colored paisley shapes, it has fringe on each end made from the basic black kashmir wools with the colored threads of the end designs. These shawls were folded and draped in different ways, sometimes simply over both shoulders and brought forward. At times a shawl was anchored around the shoulders with double shawl pins in center front. For the photo Carma draped it over 1 of 2 little golden-tan painted, delicate wedding chairs brought from Staffordshire,England, with her great grandparents, Osmond Broad Shaw and Eliza Wilding Shaw who arrived in Salt Lake in 1852. They were both fairly small sized people who used the chairs.
source: Shawl given to Carma by (the late) Madeleine Frazer Watson of Salt Lake City, inherited from her sister, Mabel Frazer, at her death. Mabel was an important Utah artist Carma had researched for art history in the latter 1900s. It was brought back from Scotland after Frazer had been in Europe studying many arts in her earlier life. Photo by Joseph R. Putnam.

caption: Original shawl from Southern Wales brought by Jane Treharne to Salt Lake City.
description: A Original shawl from Southern Wales brought by Jane Treharne (1838-1898) to Salt Lake City. Avery long shawl is made of natural gray, black and white wool grown in Wales, gathered, carded, cleaned, and spun by Jane Treharne. The thin red stripe was her hand-dyed yarn. Self-fringe is on all four sides of the shawl, formed by cutting the shawl off the loom with long side spaces not woven. Three or so fibers were carefully twisted with fingers into each cord that makes the fringe--a long, tedious process by a very determined woman. It was woven to keep Jane warm in coming from Wales to America, then crossing the plains. Jane played an important part in Utah as a talented weaver, and was part of founding Welsh communities in Utah, some of which have now lost original Welsh names.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Photo by Michael Paul.

caption: Shawl entirely of goat hair, lacy look, possibly for wrapping a small baby.
description: Goat hair is very springy and curly. When knitted into a shawl it was water-tight in a rainstorm. The goat-hair was often combined with wool for weaving in rainy countries.
source: Photo by Carma

caption: Shawl in John and Elsa Johnson Farm Home, LDS historic site, Hiram, Ohio. Restored textiles by Carma.
description: A green and white plaid shawl of heavy cotton is thrown over the black rocking chair, as if both owned by Elsa Johnson. She enjoyed the black, green and red floor squares painted on wood, which were found in the original home, making a powerful folk effect. Old woolen fabrics were cut in tiny strips and hooked into canvas backing for both charming little rugs on the left. The armless chairs are Hitchcock style with cleverly woven rushes for the seats.
source: Johnson Farm Home, Hiram, Ohio. LDS Textiles (including sewn clothing restoration by Carma, et. al.

caption: Shawl in silk satin, thick and buttery soft. It is creased from folding,(should have been rolled in acid-free tissue.)
description: This 100% silk shawl from the second quarter of the 1800s was brought to Carma in Provo by the owner who allowed it to be photographed. It was a creamy fiber of incredible thickness and softness. It had been washed many times by descendants of the first owners, as we can see in the worn out natural fringing It must have been originally expensive. in the Mid-1800s.
source: Private collection in Salt Lake City.

caption: A modern neckerchief.
description: Neck shawl in print, reproduced in 1900s because of it's East Indian beauty of stylized flowers and berries.
source: Modern retail store for Carma's wearing.

caption: A medium-sized shawl of apricot silk jacquard.
description: A medium-sized shawl of apricot silk jacquard. Artfully woven in. it has flowered ombre bands of apricot fading into green and then a dash of white. A generous fringe of rust silk is hand-knotted from the fabric itself. Made in India, it was brought to Salt lake City in 1840 by Belinda Cummins Foley Edmonds
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum, #10155. Museum. Donor Josie Foley. Photo by Michael Paul

caption: Woolen shawl of authentic design: red Stewart Dress Plaid (meaning a dressed-up, best plaid).
description: a Royal Stewart plaid for full dress is primarily red with dark blue and green stripes and thin white and yellow lines. This wool shawl was brought from England in 1840. In 1852 it belonged to Mary Jenkins Parsons, pioneer, age 39. It is much worn, as is seen on the ragged fringe. It may have been handed down in a Scottish family for generations before coming to America.
source: Donated to Salt Lake City DUP Museum, #10048, by Lucy W. Wright. Photo by Michael Paul.

caption: Shawl 1850s
description: Shawl of cross bar and checks, lambs wool, modern weave of 1800s design,
source: Carmas collection. Photo by Carma.

caption: Original shawl of Hannah Greenwood Fielding, of England, who came across the plains in 1842.
description: A heavy woolen shawl is boldly striped in red, black and white. It was given to Hannah Greenwood Fielding in 1842 as a gift from her young sons' earnings to make their widowed mother warmer in cold travel times.
source: Salt Lake City, DUP Museum, photo by Michael Paul

caption: Modern shawl.
description: Printed shawl on white wool challis, probably printed in Edinburg, Scotland in the 3rd quarter of the 1800s.The wide border of semi-paisley designs in red, black and sky blue, leaves the great center part free of design.
source: Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Photo by Michael Paul. free

caption: Small neck shawl for a drafty home
description: Neck shawl in brown and white lamb's wool worn daily for comfort, pinned in front with a straight pin.
source: It belonged to Elizabeth Golliher and was donated to Salt Lake City DUP Museum. Drawn by Margaret Weber.

caption: Sheep shearing, in England. Watercolor detail by Frederick Taylor, ca. 1864
description: A farm woman and a seated adolescent girl watch an elderly man sheering sheep. Both females have bare legs and feet, but wear warm jackets. The woman wears a bodice and skirt with a shawl tied around her waist, and a bonnet. The girl wears a plaid dress with a gathered skirt, and a large tam oshanter on her head. The balding man, a father or grandfather, wears a long sleeved shirt and a high-buttoned vest. The publisher assumes the sitting teen is a girl because a boy would have been helping with the work.
source: Bury Art Gallery. Museum, Lancashire, England. Detail: Sheep Shearing, a watercolor by Frederick Taylor, c. 1864.

caption: A shirt and a smock of 1700s & 1800s compared
description: For outerwear, a British or American smock were actually cut the same way as any linen or cotton shirt of these years for men. Plain shirts were considered as underwear in the early 1800s, so men usually wore vests over their shirts.   Note the necklines in the diagram: work shirts usually had only a collar band instead of a collar; but a heavy wool shirt for logging in winter had a pointed collar approximately 4 inches deep. This simple shirt pattern could be slightly enlarged in heavier wool to make a hunting shirt worn over the top of other clothes (seen elsewhere in a painting by artist Tait) to give another layer of warmth. Many edges of their construction were top-stitched by hand to strengthen the garment and to aid in smoothing it when it is washed.  During the 1840s there was decreasing use of a 2 inch fancy ruffle down the center front opening for about 10 inches. Such an embellishment was only used for best white linen wear, and the British kept that symbol of a fine dress shirt longer than Americans. Front yokes were usually box pleated or had vertical tucks starched and ironed on each side of the placket.  Separate starched collars for dress shirts were buttoned on after the front placket was closed with hidden buttons. Thus, we see tiny buttonholes on the bottom edge of a standing dress collar which match up with small buttons on the shirts collar band.
source: : Illustrations by Carma from hundreds of shirts seen in museum collections of America and Britain. Also, from the linen dress shirt worn by Hyrum Smith when assassinated in jail by vicious mobs in Liberty, Missouri. His death clothes were brought to Utah, and, many years ago, in Salt Lake City, Eldred G, Smith allowed Carma to make photos and patterns of his ancestors clothing: shirt, trousers, and vest. Meticulous copying and photographing were done on Patriarch Smiths dining room table with his eager assistance. From these patterns much has been learned by hundreds of costume developers.

caption: Shoemaker with "brain band and spectacles. 1700s-1800s
description: The shoemaker's clothes are covered by a strong canvas apron. He sits while sewing the innersole to the upper leather shoe. We see that there are holes made by an awl through which he pulls his strong twine. His long hair must be held out of his eyes with a "brain band" of heavy tape or soft leather.
source: T. Wright, The Romance of the Shoe: Being the History of Shoemaking in All Ages, and Especially in England and Scotland, (C.J. Farncombe & Sons 1922, now in Open Library Online).

caption: A shoemaker needs a good seat for his work in 1829.
description: Much of his shoe sewing with tight linen thread is done in the mans lap. His heavy work shirt and low blousy breeches are well covered by a bib apron of tow linen or leather. His woolen sox are in square-toed tough shoes. The leather tanner and shoemaker pictured here, Jared Carter, made footwear to finance his family, as well as his own missionary work, which was intense and effective. He spread the Book of Mormon to a wide population beyond Palmyra, New York.
source: This quarter life-size, portrait of Jared, drawn by Robert Barrett in ink, is shown in the Grandin Print Shop, Palmyra, New York. The shop is a modern display in the very place where The Book of Mormon, Another Testament of Jesus Christ was first printed in 1829.

caption: New York City shoeshine boys in shabby clothing
description: The boy in front wears a shirt with large checks and carries a wooden shoeshine box on straps over both shoulders. His narrow suspenders hold up patched trousers. Cheap straw makes his hat. Another boy behind him wears a short jacket and knit cap.
source: Trades and Occupations: A Pictorial Archive from Early Sources: Carol Belanger Grafton, Ed (Dover Pictorial Archive, August 1, 1990 One of ten free images

caption: Short gown of a working woman. An apron is worn over it, and an ankle-length skirt beneath it, 1830s-70s.
description: As seen, short gowns are jacket-like garments with no buttons in front. They are worn directly over a chemise with short or long sleeves which is next to the skin. Some of the neckline of the chemise can be seen in the front opening of the short gown. (This photo can't show the large bird's-eye beige fabric from which this short gown is made, but see Textiles for "birdseye" weave. This British style extends down to the hips, and is longer than the styles of Scandinavia. Usually the British style carried over to America when so many thousands of poor to middle classes emigrated across the Atlantic Ocean. The strong waistband of a dark gold cotton apron holds the beige short gown closed. Under the apron is a hanging pocket bag which is tied with a cord around the waist over the short gown. A red silk handkerchief dangles from the pocket through a slit in the apron. (More such pockets are seen in Womens Accessories.) The aprons bound slit in the side lets a womans hand reach into the pocket. This pocket is a great convenience that holds valuables like money, handkerchief, little child's toys or small books to take along, all-stored safely. We can see the handy white cords sewn to the blue pocket and tied in back.  Beneath the short gown, a separate skirt covers petticoats and chemise. Here the skirt is black and red striped, very heavy folk cotton. The facing on the skirt is green cotton fabric scraps barely seen at bottom of both photos, showing how they used anything available for meeting the simple needs of work clothing.
source: Photographed by Robert Putnam from an exhibit in the Joseph Smith Memorial Building at BYU Campus, Provo, UT, in 2005.Items designed and sewn by Carma; free use.

caption: Pattern for Short gown, worn in Europe since 1600s. In America, worn since ca. 1700s to 1890s in most areas by working class people.
description: To make a pattern for cutting this shortgown, this design must be enlarged so sleeve length measures from the wearers neck to her middle forearm. For the front and back, measure from her neck to her mid-thighs or upper hips. The body can be lengthened or shortened as desired. Some Carma has seen in American Eastern states were quite short (8 inches past waist line). One was heavy linen in checks of white and sky blue indigo, and was very worn out and quite short. Others have been made of pleasant cotton prints or stripes of cotton or wool lined with simple white muslin.   The patterned short gown shown in this color image was made of medium weight cotton fabric. It could be made in linen. It commonly has a V neck in an open front which allows the embroidered neckline of the under-chemise to show. A short gown has no fastenings in front, but is lapped over, and always an apron holds it shut.   Photo is of beige cotton loosely woven birdseye with white muslin lining set in. Seen on a mannequin in the Joseph Smith 200th Birthday Exhibit BYU, 2005.
source: Clothing made by Carma. Photo by Joseph R. Putnam

caption: Detail of a painted silk fan with punctured ivory sticks
description: The silk at the edge of the fan is pearly grey with tiny bright flowers painted on the fabric in wreathes or garlands. The sheer silk below is a lace design on the ivory sticks.
source: Courtesy of Wayne County Historical Society, Lyons, New York.  Photo by Carma.

caption: Late 1840s sleeve of a woolen dress from Oderupp, Nord-Fyn, Denmark.
description: Danish speckled red and yellow with a tone darker wool-- which appears to be a beautiful brown, A detail of the sleeve design from a two piece dress not yet on display at the Local Archives Museum. It was from the 1840s but fashioned with wide fullness at top of sleeve in close pleats, then a fullness of fabric sewn on to end at wrist. With a tiny cuff it was a European style of 1830s to 1850s;.
source: Carma visited in Nord Fyn, and was given a Danish book by the writer, Margit Egdal, with photographs, (not in English translation). Margit spoke good English, fortunately.

caption: An American Smock with no embroidery and less smocking than European Styles. 1700  1900.
description: Smocks were the most common working-mans clothing of the 1700s & 1800s in the old world and the new. This is a linen smock from America. It has smocking in front and a placket of four buttons. It is not a "round smock," which would have a placket on the opposite side for reversibility. There is a little smocking at the collar line in center back. On the shoulders are double layers of linen that cover all raw edges, and are called the "straps," for reinforcing the smock for (sometimes) future generations.  American smock fronts have varied smocking designs, with only two inches of smocking on the cuff-lines of the sleeves. Note that the smocking does not go all the way around the cuffs, but is centered, and simply for beauty's sake. Other pleats in the sleeve fabric attach to the side of cuff opening.  Under the rectangular arm sections are the usual seven-inch squares sewn into the sleeves and body as folded, triangular gussets. On the shoulders, the long straps, and the facings inside the smock, cover the raw seams of sleeve insertions, and are pressed inward toward the neckline. This completely covers the raw edges of the sleeves and straps. All raw edges of fabric are tuned under with small hand whip-stitching that is hardly seen on the outside of the smock, This adds strength to the garment. Such construction will survive generations of work and washing.   At the bottom of the side seam, which is French-seamed with no raw edges, we see a tiny gusset at the top of the side slit. This is to prevent side-seam tearing and is sewn securely into the hemming of the slits. There is plenty of room within this smock for a farmer to comfortably lift hay, drive a team, etc. The smock could be any neutral color of linen, or dyed dark navy blue or brown linen for little boys' smocks. In New England, Nova Scotia or Canada smocks could even be wool, subtly striped, and much longer. Wool would protect men better than linen from cold, rain, snow, and dirt.
source: Drawn by Carma after a smock made by a Nauvoo missionarys wife with Carma's measurement and sewing tutelage

caption: Smock (1830s to 40s) in the collection of Old Sturbridge Village, a wonderful national park in Massachusetts showing historical America.
description: This man's smock was not worn out, but had been repaired, as we can see a carefully reinforced seam where a tear had taken place from the front hem and upward about 15 inches. Perhaps that split in the fabric was there when the smock was first made, many years before, and was sewn up not to fray out. Then it could still be used as good white linen to actually finish a long-sleeved smock for young man or older man. This design has only a square of the smocking stitches in front, no wider than the flat collar spreads, and all stitching designs are identical on the other side, being a reversible "Round Smock.". The sleeves have the expected section of smocking near the narrow cuffs, but not all the way around the cuffs. It had lasted a long time by being used on both sides for many years, or more than one generation. The owner donated it to the historic village. It is definitely a New England type of smock and is badly tacked up for a photo. The shoulder width would have dropped a little off the farmer's shoulders when worn.
source: Old Sturbridge Village booklet.

caption: A young girl wearing a snood over her long hair.
description: During the 1840s to 1880s A pretty mesh snood was made of silk plush fibers, or a net was crocheted of fine cotton yarns to hold long hair in place. Snoods reached only down to the upper shoulders. This girl has put silky flowers over the crown of her head instead of a flattened ribbon bow to make the snood more becoming.
source: Drawn by Carma

caption: Snoods on girls' hair styles
description: The partial snood of chenille and the all-over net snood here have formed a chignon at the back of each girls neck.
source: Drawn by Carma

caption: Woman in a snood wears a wreath around her head for greater beauty.
description: This young woman of the Mid-1800s is wearing a snood, probably made of silk chenille, which is decorated with a full wreath of little artificial flowers around her head. Her naturally wavy hair is draped back to her ears, with her long hair caught up into the snood that would be anchored solidly with little combs. She has teardrop earrings, of metal or jet. Her eyebrows would not have been plucked so narrowly in her time, as many modern artists mistake in their "historic" illustrations and paintings.
source: Detail of a woodcut published by KBYU FM station, Provo, Utah in an advertisement

caption: Spanish riding hat with veil and woman's topper for a riding habit ensemble, ca.: 1840s to 1860s,
description: A Spanish riding hat often sports lace veil hanging down to the woman's shoulders. It is trimmed on the hat with curving cock feathers. Her friend in the picture is female, but wearing a common top hat for riding. Her hair is looped in braids below her ears. Huge numbers of buttons were sewn on riding habits for a military style.
source: Godey's Lady's Book' 1848. Free use.

caption: Eel spearing at Setauketin rural Long Island, 1845.
description: A servant in the large household of William Sydney Mount goes out in a boat to spear eels for their supper. The woman wears a battered felt hat over her red head kerchief. A white, striped shawl is anchored at the waist by a black apron string. Her skirt is a dull red. This detail of one of Mounts paintings shows this African-American woman who was both the farm nurse and a valuable farm helper in many other ways. The Mounts never owned slaves.
source: Seen in American Heritage, The Magazine of History, (Marion Ohio, American Heritage Publishing Co. Aug 1960). Also online.

caption: David Whitmers spectacle rims, worn ca; 1840s
description: David Whitmer's heavy gold spectacle rims are missing the temple bars.
source: Rims seen in Museum of Community of Christ, Independence, Missouri. Redrawn by Margaret Weber from Carmas measured sketches. Free use.

caption: Stockings, several pair.
description: Hand knitted and hand dyed wool creates the blue stocking which reaches to the knee, and would have needed a garter to hold it up. In the center is a fine white stocking with feminine embroidered designs up the leg. The beige and gray stockings to the knee are modern knit to appear like those of the1700s and 1800s. Center top red, black and dark green Argyle, is beside a second Argyle of black, dark green and white. In the center of the pile is "rag wool" knitted into stockings reaching to the middle calf. It is the poor man's stocking, which, when worn out, is pulled apart and re-spun into knitting yarns, called rag-wool of indiscriminate color.
source: Assembled and photo by Carma.

caption: A fine straw hat of the early 1800s is reproduced for display on a bed with a quilt. It would have been worn by Elizabeth Johnson of the LDS restored Johnson Farm in Hiram, Ohio.
description: A fine womans broad-brimmed straw hat, reproduced for display, lies on a bed quilt in CD Fig ?This shallow crowned straw hat was very common and where possible could have much ribbon attached outside or inside to secure it under the chin. The checkered ribbons seen here fit into grooves steamed into the straw brim to tie under the chin and hold the hat securely on during wind and work.
source: Modern-made commercial hat for a period costume. Steamed and sewn with ribbons by Carma

caption: Homemade straw hat shades a boy pioneer.
description: Completely homemade in modern times. Grain seeds were planted, harvested, cut, braided and sewn together by his mother. This is a modern reproduction using antique methods.
source: : June Kraft Garges, Handcrafted Straw Hats: An Early American Home Industry, (Souderton, Pennsylvania, Indian Valley Printing, 1982.)

caption: Wedding suspenders, embroidered.
description: Made by a bride for her future husband, these separate suspenders are embroidered on strong, light-colored fabric. The leather ends are attached by a leather worker and are adjustable. As in other fine suspenders, they are buttoned on the inside of the trouser waistline.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, 1840.) Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections

caption: Sweden dancing farmers
description: No description
source: Malberg 1863 Nordiska Museet

caption: Swedish cap of fine black wool has red piping on all its edges. Around the face is a tiny line of handmade lace.
description: This original light wool cap is stiffened inside with mesh buckram, and then lined in a fine red wool fabric. It is much worn-out inside in the back neckline area. At that point we see the last bits of the original unwoven,soft ,wool padding. The tiny handmade lace is original, but the ties for the cap, which are to hang down each side, were made by Carma after seeing other photographs of such caps.  The tassels were meant to hang at each side, and the cap fits snugly over smooth front hair.
source: Cap was donated to Carma. Photo by Carma.

caption: 1844 Swedish embroidery on the front of a blouse with name and date of the original owner.
description: On strong home-loomed linen is cotton embroidery down the front of a blouse for a folk costume. Reds and pinks are very important colors and are often used in different tones often. The date this blouse was first made is embroidered:1844. We can see that the back fabric is probably not as bleached and pretty as the white front linen. The blouse would be covered up on the back and sides by a green, blue, red or black wool bodice to show off only the front and sleeves.
source: Swedish book cover, Folkligt Festliga Monogram, Ur Kulturens Samlingar by Britta Hammar

caption: Swedish families are leaving from a 5 A M Christmas Morning celebration in their Lutheran Church.
description: On Christmas morning, women wore little caps over their hair and brought their child to church, also wearing caps. The married women wore black and white woven bands on their white linen caps, and the younger women and girls wore bright colored bands woven for caps, Not all men were devout enough to attended the services at 5 a.m. The men attending are seated separately from the women and child on opposite sides of the church. The next picture shows church members waiting to speak with the pastor in his office. We see that the women and girls are all wearing leather jackets with fluffy sheep fur on the inside for the totally unheated church buildings. Beautiful woven tapes adorn their jackets on the edges, also. Heavy woolen skirts over warm petticoats are traditional for the very cold Christmas time. Their shoes often have large leather flaps styled over the low leather female shoes. Younger women wear bright red stockings. It is interesting that women's hair is bound to the head so tightly under their caps, while men generally wear felt hats over loose hair and beards.
source: Swedish post cards of art from oil painter C. Malm sent to Carma from Kerstin Hamp Pederson, born in Falun, Sweden. No other source known.

caption: Swedish figure detail from "Visiting Mother."
description: A grown man holds his black felt top hat in an arm and goes in to see his mother. He wears long coat of white wool to mid-calf and it has five buttons up the front and eased- in fabric at top of sleeves but not padding in shoulders in his beautiful folk-designed coat.He also has very flat buckled dress shoes.
source: Upplandsmuseet near Malmberg. PERMISON Upplandsmuseet  Fyristorg 2  753 10 Uppsala  Tel: 018-169100  info@upplandsmuseet.se (Sweden) Lorie sent an email asking for name and email of person who gives permissions. Dec 6, 16

caption: Swedish folk costume decor tape and woven belt tassels.
description: This cheerfully colored cotton tape can decorate folk costumes; and the ends of a belt with tassels is red and blue . a table-sized inkle loom can be themeans of a person seaving at home the decorations that they could wear for festivals or sell to others for profit. These wool colors are red, blue and yellow. Blue silk threads added in the red tassels of wool yarn.
source: Purchased in Stockholm, Sweden and photo by Carma.

caption: Textiles: Swedish linsey-woolsey stripe, from an aged wool and linen outside skirt.
description: This long-wearing fabric is badly damaged but still holding together. The red color is still bright with the white and dyed black yarns. Possibly these black yarns from the loom are from naturally black sheep.
source: Upplandsmuseet  Fyristorg 2  753 10 Uppsala  Tel: 018-169100  info@upplandsmuseet.se (Sweden)

caption: Swedish Militia man with breeches, stockings and wooden clogs
description: This man's breeches are form fitting but with a baggy seat to enable sitting. His clogs are shaped with a carved heel of 2 inches high. His fitted jacket is sturdy and short, reaching to his middle hips. He wears a red hat with black tape designs around the border, a common Swedish style.
source: Sketched by Carma from a group picture celebrating a militia holiday.

caption: Swedish monogram 1842 with red silk embroidery, and black floss.
description: The date this was imortant to a piece of clothing is1842.
source: Swedish book cover, Folkligt Festliga Monogram, Ur Kulturens Samlingar by Britta Hammar

caption: Swedish Rtvik apron with binding.
description: Bright yellow-orange and red were woven in stripes for this apron, which is bound by dotted black and yellow tape.Additional red and white tape was usedfor making a facing on the inside of the apron hem.
source: Courtesy of Roselle Anderson Stevenson

caption: Swedish Rtvik bodice front (left), and back (right) with red binding and adjustable ribbons.
description: This adjustable bodice front will grow with the girl who wears it by the tightening or loosening of the red (or green) ribbons between the shoulder straps and the lacing on the wide waist band. The lining is any available cotton print, which is never seen when worn. Silver or brass rings are sewn onto the bodice front to thread an adjustable cord through. This bodice was brought to Carma for her collection of historic clothing. It would have usually accompanied a black skirt in wool or cotton and an apron in stripes of bright colors.
source: A Donation from a friend for Carma's collection.

caption: SwedishRtvikk headscarf.
description: This brightly printed fabric is two layers and a green cotton binding around the edge. It is meant to be joined under the chin with a pin when worn.
source: Roselle Anderson Stevenson

caption: Swedish School Boy at Home.
description: A young boy of wealth is dressed in international European clothing to have his portrait painted. There is a fine white linen shirt showing its collar and a bit of its cuffs. A small white bow is tied on top of his collar. On his black jacket are at least 7 silver buttons, with a belt barely discernible. He would have black trousers hanging loose to just below his knees. His stockings would be white above black shoes.
source: From the western border of sweden, Gothenburg Art Gallery, byMathias Stoltenberg, Permissions. Already asked, no answer?? //// Lorie ask again.

caption: Two-sided Swedish silk shawl with enhanced lines arranged in plaid design
description: A shawl in green, lavender/orchid and creamy yellow and black jacquard weave. It is approximately 34 inches square with one side predominating in lavender and the other side in green. It was woven in modern Sweden from a very old pattern of a hundred years before 2000, as Carma was told. She was taken to the Stockholm weavers by dear friend Monika Karlsson, and saw personally the complicated machinery at work. Carma purchased the shawl to add to more Swedish costumes she wanted to have in her collection. The supple, thick silk would bring warmth as well as beauty to an ensemble.
source: Photo by Carma.

caption: Swedish traveling salesman with fine white fabrics to show.
description: Man in a long tailed coat barely on his shoulders probably wears a red striped vest, and has doffed his hat to be gracious to the ladies. A mother and daughter are both wearing colorful striped wool skirts and the younger one has a hip-length fitted jacket in a blue or green with a silky kerchief tied under her chin. The mothers hair is quite covered by a black cap and she wears a small shawl over her shoulders.
source: Scandia book

caption: Swiss blue smock on wagon driver.
description: From his wagon seat, this mad driver is trying to capture a horse. He wears the typical blue color of smock from Switzerland and France. This has the center neck opening unbuttoned. A large brimmed mashed felt hat is worn.
source: This image was on the lid of a huge box of Swiss Chocolates. This painting's source was completely unknown, when Carma made a telephone inquiry about it at the chocolate company.

caption: Swiss girl in folk costume of Lucerne, holding an oval Swiss clock.
description: A Swiss folk costume adorns a clock maker's daughter from Lucerne. She wears a pale straw hat with a black ribbon over a crown of braids. Tied around her waist is a precious, white-on-white, embroidered apron with commercially made Swiss machine-embroidery. Added to the band of white flowers on the apron are crocheted and embroidered ovals. A dark brown, heavy cotton bodice has dark, light blue and white embroideries on each side of the laced-up front, which is criss-crossed with a tiny cord. She tucks cord ends under the apron band. On the back vest are unusual curved straps which center a large medallion of flowers in the variegated blues of the front embroideries. Black leather and wooden clogs are often worn among Europeans, and we see these with white stockings and a bit of her embroidered white petticoat.  SOURCE? . Costume entirely made by Carma except clogs and stockings. The clock is an antique from Switzerland from Carma's clock collection.
source: Modeled by 9 year old Katherine Helena Hamblin . PhotobyRavel Call, of the Salt Lake City Deseret News at one of Carma's international fashion shows.

caption: Swiss Kindergarten in about the 1860s.
description: child are gathered in a large home for Swiss beginning education: to learn to eat properly and be polite. Little girls are in short dresses with all-over aprons. Boys wear dark skeleton suits with white shirts underneath. The teacher wears a black dress of honor, with her huge gray apron to the floor. The apron's top flap is pinned to her bodice. Such pinning gave rise to the name "pinafore," even when straps were attached later and even rufflesof the late 1800s. The large triangular scarf is always immaculate and the back area only is starched, to tie comfortably under the chin.
source: Zurich, Switzerland-- unknown, from a loose picture given Carma from unknown source

caption: Hyrum Smith's parade sword, sheath, pistol and epaulets for his Nauvoo Legion Uniform, ca.: 1842.
description: Hyrum Smith's uniform accoutrements include epaulet fringes and bases made of high quality gold thread and plated metal. Above them is his pistol. His dress sword has a leather and brass hilt attached to a fine steel blade which appears black in this photo. The sheath is made of polished brass with double loops to attach by chains to his belt. The papers shown attest his status as a commissioned officer.
source: Displayed in the Museum of Church History and Art in Salt Lake City, Utah. FREE

caption: A tam and smock for a boy to wear over short trousers.
description: a four year old boy can be comfortable in a heavy cotton smock with ivory or composition buttons at neck and cuffs. It is a simple pullover with a gathered fabric body. A teal and orange tam o'shanter with a yarn pom-pom is lined in black cotton and used by both boys and girls anywhere in the many British Isles and often in America.
source: Both were sewn by Carma. Smocking by Nancy West. The fabric is red and blue cotton fibers woven together, making a beautiful lavender-color fabric.

caption: Tanners work hard in unpleasant surroundings to process hides into leather. ca.: 1830s to1860s.
description: These men wear long leather aprons to protect their clothing from the solutions in the odoriferous tannery. It is a wonder men could even breathe in an environment that took a lot of getting used to. Man at left scrapes hair off pelts, another trims fat and tissues from the inner side, while men on right work the hides in different solutions. The men's shirtsleeves are rolled above the elbows, and most wear caps with or without brims. They all wear gaiters over their ankles and feet for leg protection from the intensely strong solutions.
source: Seen in Carol Belanger Grafton, Ed., Trades and Occupations: A Pictorial Archive from Early Sources (Dover Pictorial Archive)Paperback August 1, 1990. Up to 10 images may be used at no cost.

caption: Tapestry designs woven on a black Kashmir shawl, self fringed in black.
description: Tapestry designs woven on a black Kashmir shawl, self fringed. A paisley shawl from Britain in a small square shape, and was less expensive. This, photo image shows both sides of the shawl, with the carried yarns of tapestry on the underside. .
source: Shawl was in the Brigham Young Forest Farm home of Deseret Village for tourists to Utah, in Salt Lake City Photo by Carma.

caption: Teenage boy with his grandmother wears hand-me-down clothes. 1840s
description: A worn velvet collar tops a short cutaway coat with square tails. This shows the usual padding around the back neckline, but none in the shoulders. His white tie and shirt are clean. This double-breasted coat is over gray flannel trousers which have a button front placket and are 4 to 5 inches too short. They are also patched around the lower part. His high-topped shoes lace above his ankle. He has somehow acquired a very tall top hat of dubious condition.. The woman wears a long-worn wool plaid dress fashionably sewn to form a V-shape in both the fabric and the loose flanges over the shoulders. Her very small daycap is tied above a clean white collar. She has tiny ruffles at her wrists.
source: From the British film Little Dorrit. Photo by Snowdon.

caption: Theatrical couple in Irish best clothing
description: The woman with a reed basket wears a jacket of orange tweed with many buttons, which extends to her upper hipline. She has a very fancy day cap of laces with white ribbon ties, and shirring on each cheek. Her heavy wool and linen striped skirt is worn beneath a long black cape with a satin collar. Her partner has a brown tweed Swallowtail coat and hard hat. He carries a hardwood walking stick. These actors wear fine leather shoes and must keep up appearances as successful theater makers.
source: Anne O'Dowd,FIND IRISH THEATER from County. Armagh, Ireland. FIND AT BYU

caption: The back of a demonstration dress to show how a poor woman would make a simple dress.
description: Carma made this dress from cotton that looked like heavy linen, and bound the neckline and cuffs with sturdy striped fabric. There are a variety of mismatched buttons in the back, since they were relatively expensive. The usual slanted shoulder seam is wrapped over from the front, seen at left in the image. The dress is mended and patched, and was worn in a fashion show with a ragged bonnet and apron.
source: Photo by Carma.

caption: The Injured Hunter is a very large oil painting done in Norway, 1856.
description: The major artist of the 1800s in Norway is Adolf Tidamand. . The mother is consoling a bleeding son who has successfully killed a bear in the forest. She is in her beautiful bodice with linen blouse and flowered head scarf holding back all her hair. Her daughter stands behind her holding a large mug of clean water to assist her mother. The son was hunting in gold wool breeches, laced up at knees, heavy shoes and dark blue wool stockings. His red wool jacket is still on. After cleaning up his bloody face his mother waits patiently with pressure on his head. She has a blanket to wrap him in to rest when first aid is finished. His proud father is tall and smiling in the common kind of red knitted cap ,which could be pulled farther down around the ears for wind and cold.. His older brother, or friend, has on a black cap of more stylish fashion, and a a black wool coat with red = checkers of wool on his sweater underneath it. .The younger brothers and sisters are inquisitive and impressed in their ordinary clothes of sweaters for some, and others in folk bodices.
source: This painting hangs in the National Gallery of Art in Oslo. Internet Information. Universitetsgata 13 Oslo, Norway

caption: This old English smock has been worn by two generations
description: This densely stitched smock has the entire chest in close pleats of smocking, white embroidery on white linen, for weddings and Sabbaths. On the two boxes, each side, there are round designs with four petals in the centers. And the upper sleeves have many diamond smocked designs matching the center front. The fairly small collar is almost worn away on this knee- length smock for shorter English people. The cuffs could possibly have been replaced when worn out, as there is much smocking on the lower sleeves before the long cuffs.
source: Gertrude Jekyll, Old English Household Life: Some Account of Cottage Objects and Country Folk (New York, HarperCollins Distribution Services; Revised edition ,September 1975).

caption: The painting of the Haugianersof 1852 , Norway, shows a home meeting of highly religious people who followed the simplicity of early Christianity,
description: In the painting, Haugianerne Low Church Devotion, the followers of Hans Nielsen Hauge are shown in a home meeting of neighborhood believers, waiting for priesthood leaders of Christ to be sent to them.They are wearing authentic clothing of Norwegian peasants. The men are either in breeches or woolen trousers with heavy leather shoes.All wear warm woolen stockings. Some men have vests over heavy sweaters. The man preaching has a natural wool jacket with dark green piping designs over his shoulders. Wide belts are common. Homes were only heated by the large cooking hearth and they were generally cold in winter. Women cover their hair with white linen, though the young girl bowed in thought has no head covering. Women wear striped or plain colored aprons over their black wool skirts. The small boy on the right has breeches and a jacket over a white shirt. A bald-headed old man lies in his bed, which is built in the wall. Light comes from an opening in the roof, and is symbolic [in this painting] of spiritual enlightenment.
source: Haugianerne Low Church Devotion, painted by Adolf Tideman. On Internet: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolph Tideman

caption: Thomas Barthelemy Cardon, with short hair for the 1850s
description: Thomas Barthelemy is the youngest Cardon brother from the Piedmont of Italy, with a gentle, sweet personality. His hair is combed back from his face and reaches just below his collar line. His tie is difficult to analyze, but may be of a figured fabric tucked under the lapels of his high-buttoned vest. The collars of his shirt turn down.
source: Genevieve Porter Johnson and Edna Cardon Taylor,compilers, Cardons! Descendents of Philippe Cardon and Marthe Marie Tourn 1799-1886, (Provo, Utah, Stevenson's Genealogy Center, 1990) Permission from Larry C. Porter.

caption: This Thomas Christian Jensen Family was possibly from Denmark in about 1866.
description: There are three sons and three daughters in this professional Jensen family portrait. The child are all dressed better than their sacrificing parents. The Father's coat seems a bit ragged down his left side, though his ear-lobe length hair is smoothly combed to his left and off his forehead. The mother wears very smooth, parted hair under a black silk cap. Large ribbon ties form a bow in front. She is wearing a black or dark silk jacket but a rather thin wool or linen fabric skirt. Her apron is not of quality and her petticoats are skimpy at best. She has no shawl. The tall boy between his parents has a pale vest under a tailored dress suit, and a small black tie. His short hair is neatly cut with curls on each side. His blonde brother on far left has a printed neckerchief. He is in a good tunic over his trousers. His fashionable belt of that period was seen on boys of both America and the Continent. His smallest sister on right has a similar elastic belt in a dark color over her white, short, dress top, and a ribbon around her neck to match. In addition, she wears a modestly longer skirt of pretty silk in a modified plaid. The oldest daughter, growing into a real beauty, has a curious ribbon hanging from her hair on her left side. There is no ribbon in view on her right, so it may be part of a hair ornament. She wears a middle-toned, silk dress with a button front. The sister at her side has a little lacy collar and some decorative edge on the front opening of her dress .The small and middle girls both have their hair slicked back from their faces, so their hair may be hanging down their backs, tied in longer bunches of ringlets or straight braids. The clothing of the girl in center is difficult to see, but may be plaid with a ruffled lace collar. This family may have even older brothers or sisters who are not present for the portrait, as many larger family groups are listed (but not pictured) among those who came from Denmark as LDS converts. How we wish we knew their individual names and histories!
source: Photo given to Carma many years ago. Family names unknown.

caption: These three Irishmen edited the LDS Welsh newspaper, UdgornSeion, 1856-1862 for converts and investigators.
description: William Ajax, Daniel Daniels, and Benjamin P. Evans were Irish converts living in Wales. All three were within 15 years of each others ages, and wore medium to small beards and fairly wide mustaches. They had medium to much hair loss in the 1850s.Devout missionaries through their preaching, they produced excellent writings, which were latertranslated into English.
source: Ardent student of Welsh,Ronald Dennis made the newspaperUdgornSeion,available to an ever-widening audience withhis translations, as an Editor for the Religious Studies Center, Brigham Young University.

caption: Three old Irish people of 1840-1860.
description: This photocopy of unknown origin show two old men with shaggy whiskers in working clothes. The man on left has a wide-brimmed hat and dark vest, with narrowly striped trousers. His flamboyant tie boasts wide stripes. The center man in a felt cap wears a light coat with wide, rounded lapels.. The womans hair is either cut medium length, or is very loose at the sides, but gathered back into a bob, and is partially covered with a kerchief. Her high-necked wooly dress has a shawl draped over one arm supported on a straight, ball-handled cane.
source: Source unknown

caption: Three Welsh baby caps 1800- 1850.
description: Baby Cap (top) Pale blue lace, (left) Cream crocheted wool (warm); white lawn and lace bonnet, for summer.
source: Ken Etheridge, Welsh Costume, (Swansea SA2 9BE, Christopher Davis Publishers, ltd. 1977).

caption: Tiny Eliza Gibson Wilding, wears her wedding clothing in Staffordshire, England 1838.
description: Eliza was 21 when she married. Of very modest income, she was a professional seamstress of stays (the two separate pieces of a laced-up corset in the mid-years of the 1800s). Excellence in sewing is shown in her beautiful clothing. She wears a best wedding dress of dove colored gray because working classes could not afford a one-time-wearing of a white wedding dress. A frill of lace at the neckline is emphasized by a black Jasperware broach. Around her shoulders is a "serpentine" shawl of flowered stripes alternating with geometrical stripes. Her bonnet is pale green silk, lined with rose shirring on the inside of the brim to lend color to her cheeks. A pale green binding surrounds the brim. Matching light green silk ribbons for the ties. One white ostrich plume was afforded for her bonnet. Beneath the bonnet is a perfect white daycap with ruching on the cheeks, showing this to be the middle 1840s. Eliza was a dainty 4 feet 11inches tall. Eliza and her father joined the LDS Church, but kept it a secret from her true love during a years time of courting! Meanwhile, her fianc employed the same deceit of silence, because the Mormons were badly persecuted in that English area. But they fearfully told each other a week before the wedding. What joy as they embraced!
source: Painted in 2008 in oil from Carmas watercolor designs, enlarged and embellished from a minuscule, aged, facial photographs in the Shaws Salt Lake City years. Enlarged from terrible old photos. Ben Sowards (a skilled Art graduate of BYU) was hired to portray the young bride and groom in oils, exactly as Carma desired. Owned by Carma. FREE Carma, the footnote will be correct when it is printed.

caption: This toddler smock was found in a very old New England house, in very poor condition.
description: This grey and tan gingham smock with a drawstring cord at the neck can have plentiful gathers for free movement. Cross-bar design indicates cotton gingham. Carefully restored with extra fine thread and tiny hand-sewing by Carma.
source: Collection Winifred Bowers given to Carma. Drawn by Carma.

caption: Traditional hats from Carmarthen and Gwent in Wales.
description: The black felt (left) has a flat brim with a black mourning ribbon around the base of the crown, worn from1700s on, especially in Pembroke and Cambria. On right is a black, straw, a Gwent hat made after the preserved designs of nationalistic Lady Lanover, who tried hard to perpetuate old folk-ways in costumes. The left daycap has profuse ruffling around the face and neck. Interesting that day-caps beneath both hats have bows on the back.
source: Ken Etheridge, Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century, free

caption: A triangle fan is a clever variation for a woman's fancy accessory
description: A ladys fan in this shape is clever and distinctive. The wood slats are covered with fabric of flowers and radiating stripes. Ruched lace around the edge and a tasseled pivot complete its charm.
source: Louis A. Godey, Godey's Lady's Book and Magazine, (Philadelphia, Louis A. Godey, publisher, March 1864.)Original copies held at Brigham Young University's Harold B. Lee Library, Special Collections.

caption: Triangular black lace shawl.
description: This silk shawl, made of one whole piece of lace, would be worn over a best day or evening dress for decoration rather than warmth.
source: The shawl was brought to Carma's home by a friend who knew Carma would want to photograph it. It was probably made in France on a lace machine. It was about 36-38 inches on the long side. Photo by Carma

caption: Triple-tied apron on a serving woman in a soup kitchen, ca: 1860
description: This apron provides extra protection to a full skirt. Working in a soup kitchen, the woman has hair covered with a red and white patterned scarf tied in the back, with only a little of her front hair seen. A faded red cotton bodice does not show the neckline, but long sleeves fit closely at the wrist. A small, fringed, yellow and red shawl, folded in a triangle, is crossed over the chest and fastened with a straight pin. A dark blue, bell-shaped skirt is over petticoats. Her heavy apron is buttoned or tied at the waistline in back, plus two more places behind her skirt: at hipline and calf line, to anchor the apron around the skirt and gather it in more firmly.
source: Drawn by Carma after Margot Lister, Costumes of everyday life: An illustrated history of working clothes, (London, Barrie &Jenkins, 1972)

caption: Trouser pocket opening on adolescent boy's corduroy broadfall trousers.
description: A broadfall pocket opening in a tan pair of corduroy trousers shows vertical buttonholes on the horizontal closure. At the corners, the buttonholes are slanted at 45 degrees to allow for stress. One side button could be left open for easier access to the heavy muslin pocket which hangs inside. For poor people, buttons were expensive and often unmatched.
source: Sewing and photo by Carma.

caption: Tan cotton corduroy and blue striped cotton show a front view and a back view of trousers from 1820-60
description: : Tan cotton corduroy and blue striped cotton show a front view and a back view of trousers from 1820 to 1860. CD Fig ?Corduroy trousers of greenish-gold have various types of buttons which were gathered from old clothes and a few purchases. Animal antler, white bone, wood, metal, glass   and gutta-percha were authentic materials for common buttons of the 1800s. For costumers today, modern-made matt finish plastic buttons are made to look like much older buttons of natural or dyed bone. Metal buttons were always expensive for the poor. Metal fasteners were sometimes even more expensive than the cloth for a garment.   For convenience, one button of the pants' broadfall opening may be left undone while shopping, making it easier to put a hand into the inner, heavy, muslin pocket for money.   Suspenders in dark green and red heavy cotton tape are attached to the pants higher back waistline. Suspender ends are hand sewn onto a heavy leather tab which can be slit with a tool to make a buttonhole. Suspenders were very seldom attached to each other at the crossing in back, but were each single strips.   Below, the striped, blue and white, sturdy, cotton poor-boy pants can be cinched in the back with cloth strips to fit a slim boy. The strips have no expensive buckle, but are simple cloth made to tie in a knot. We also see two bone buttons which attach to suspenders. A heavy inside facing across the back waistline is usually of canvas to take the strain of the suspenders
source: These are examples Carma made for historic fashion shows. Photo by Joseph R. Putnam.

caption: Tucked-up outer skirt on working woman wearing shoes. A ragged plaid petticoat is underneath, and a remnant of white apron still in front.
source: William Johnstone White, edited by Pamela Clabborn, Working Class Costume from Sketches of Characters, (London, Dedalus Press for Victoria and Albert Museum, by Costume Society, c.o. Department of Textiles. 1977.)

caption: A turn-over shawl.
description: This white shawl with a tiny squares dotted print has machine embroidered dark ribbons with roses on the edge of half of it; and then the right side of the ribbons are sewn on the back side of the fabric for the other half of the shawl. This is intended for always folding the shawl in the same triangle, and it will always exhibit the right sides of both embroidered ribbons. Worn out fringe is left on part of it
source: Probably made in Paisley, Scotland, -- CHECK Pamela Clabburn, Shawls, (Shire Library Series, Shire Publications, now Bloomsbury Publishing, London, 2008)

caption: Two Welsh smocks
description: These ornate smocks which hang only to the mid-thigh are of heavy linen in neutral colors. It is likely that one could have been bleached white to wear for a Welshman's wedding, sewn entirely by his bride. The sleeves have two-button cuffs and embroidery, with the lower cuff unbuttoned and folded up when doing wet work. Usually white thread was used to smock and embroider. Over the shoulders of the front smock from Dolgellau are rain collars that button on under the smaller collar. Both scrolls and zig-zags are embroidered. On the back smock from New Cross, Aberystwyth, we see elaborate collar decorations of clover designs and close tucking to make the collar thicker. The chest areas of both are heavily smocked almost to the sides of the body, and would have much smocking in the backs. Both have front openings at the neckline with small buttons of shell or hardwood. They were long-lasting.
source: Ken Etheridge, Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19thCentur,(Swansea, Wales: Cristopher Davies, Ltd., 1977). Republished in 1990 by Third Impression, Llandybie, Dyfed.

caption: A man in vest and shirt stands by the printer's rack of lead font sizes and styles. He is arranging letters and spacers for printing. Mid 1800s
description: His light colored vest has a shawl collar, and a dark apron hangs over his clothing. His hair is full and curly but not long, and he wears a little jaw-line beard.
source: From an old newspaper of the 1800s

caption: Women's underwear: Chemise with embroidered, shirred yoke, and fancy pantalettes with separate legs.
description: The chemise has a beautiful shirred yolk at the top with embroidered bands and faggoted lace around a wide neckline. If a woman of any age were wearing a short-gown, a conveniently decorated chemise was necessary to properly show at the neckline.  Pantalettes went over any sort of underwear the woman was already wearing, and often were made in two separate legs, buttoning in the front and the back at the waistline. They could be very plain for a poor woman, or highly decorated for a wealthy one. Their length varied from calf length in the 1830s to much longer when skirt hems dropped to the top of the shoes from the late 1840s on. Decors included insertion lace and/or edge lace, and very often small tucks.
source: Calico Chronicles by Betty Mills. Drawn by Carma

caption: Villagers go to English country Church in this wood engraving from a newspaper.
description: The boy in foreground wears a pilot cap over a fitted frockcoat and light trousers. A large white collar from his shirt is worn outside his coat. The little girl wears a waist-length cape and has a larger fabric bonnet with ribbons curled around the brim. Her skirt is very full with a sash tied in the back and pantalettes down to her ankles. The mother wears a long satin dress, possibly lustring [or lutestring] with an expensive cape adorned with ruffled silk lace in graded layers. The man has a side-curved brim on his topper. Another woman to his right wears a lace shawl over her bonnet and down to her skirt--possibly his wealthy mother.  The family farther ahead shows two women and a child. One woman has a plaid shawl with a deep bonnet, and another with a long cloak with its hood lying down, not over her bonnet. Her little boys coat has claw-hammer tails, and he wears a round cap.
source: Half a page of newspaper Carma found on a train in England, when someone had left an article he wanted to read while commuting. Carma glanced at it during her ride and discovered that it was a indeed a wood engraving printed on the sheet. Sorry, no date or masthead on the newspaper, just a lucky find on a clothing research trip.

caption: Waldensians of Italy, Town Center, detail.
description: This Waldensian town square shows many two story buildings and tall trees. Men are in their usual tall crowned hats visiting from various places with the aid of their staves for hiking mountain trails. A woman waits under a balcony to sell her wares from a basket. Her wide hat has slipped to the back of her head and shooulders. The donkey in the street carries panniers of goods and hand-woven fabrics. Felt hats are on all males with medium brims for warmth and shade. The crowns tend to narrow at the tops. Men wear dark vests, coats and breeches with light stockings.   These very private religionists of ca, 225 AD lived a thousand years peacefully until they were early sought out and slaughtered in the 1500s by the Pope's Catholic Armies, from southern Italy . But many Waldensians retreated higher and higher into the mountains. They remained faithful for 1500 years to their Christian expectations of real Apostles and original Biblical teachings. Mormon missionaries arrived in 1850, and more than 100 people from the Piedmont were converted, as well as from Waldensians in France where they had previously escaped through the mountains. Many families and single people left Italy, France and Switzerland. They joined with Mormon missionaries and many gathered to live with Mormons, in the American West .Waldensian surnames are still common in Utah? Beus, David, Malan, etc.
source: Auguste Jahier Pasteur, Prarustin et Rocheplatedans, L'HistoireVaudoise (Torre Pillice -- Imprimerie Alpine, 1928).

caption: Waldensian villagers walking-- to Church?
description: Both men and women wear large brimmed hats, with few bonnets seen.We have no descriptions available of how they dressed in Church, or whether they wore nicer aprons with their Church clothing. They wear triangular small shawls around their necks and the men wear coats without any tails or skirts. These people of the Upper Piedmont valleys and high mountains had to be self-sufficient, having little contact with lower Italy. They claimed to be waiting for the Christian Church to come back with apostles and prophets. Some remarkable families were converted to the LDS Church, and emigrated to America during the 1850s. Their names are still in our populace as surnames of Beus, David. Malan, etc.
source: This and other Waldensian sketches are from a book written by Auguste Jahier Pasteur, Prarustin et Rocheplatedans, L'HistoireVaudoise (Torre Pillice -- Imprimerie Alpine, 1928).

caption: Waldensian woman carries a large flat basket for shopping or selling things.
description: She wears a blouse, simple folk bodice and ankle-length skirt. A very large- brimmed hat of straw or felt is functional, not elaborate with only s few small trims on clothing since they were quite Puritan and did not want elaborate clothing. Her elbow-length sleeves are full, and she may wear an apron over her wool skirt and petticoats. She has flat shoes with, of course ,hand-knitted stockings, likely fine spun wool.  Her skirt is full and ankle length. She likely wears a darker apron. The horses bring in fresh products to market.
source: Auguste Jahier Pasteur, Prarustin et Rocheplatedans, L'HistoireVaudoise (Torre Pillice -- Imprimerie Alpine, 1928).

caption: Waldensian working women wear short gowns are worn over heavy skirts in northern Italy.
description: Short gowns were worn in Europe and America during the 1800s. They were long, open-fronted tops, overlapped at the waist, and held in place by aprons. With a chemise beneath, short gowns hungover the top of a womens longer skirts. These Waldensian women carry baskets on their backs over their shawls, and one is barefoot. Men often carried cone-shaped baskets from fields or villages.
source: Auguste Jahier Pasteur, Prarustin et Rocheplatedans, L'HistoireVaudoise (Torre Pillice -- Imprimerie Alpine, 1928).

caption: For a toddler, learning to walk is made safe and fun by being inside a wicker walker.
description: This little "Toddlekins" can move freely with the motion of her own legs and even carry her own toys. She has a scarf or ribbon around her curls and a simple dress with a ruffled collar. She wears colored socks and white Mary-Jane shoes. This is a child's early entertainment.
source: Katherine Morrison McClinton, Antiques of American Childhood. (New York, Bramhall House,1970

caption: A watchman must dress for all kinds of weather. 1830s to 1870s
description: A heavy overcoat with rain cape on it has a high standing collar to keep out rain and cold. Here a watchman is out in any weather in a coat that was probably inherited or given him: a huge tuck was taken to make it short enough. Military tabs with buttonholes were in use on men's greatcoats in the 1700s until the 1850s.
source: Illustrator, George Cruikshank

caption: This Norwegian folk ensemble was watercolored by the LDS artist, Dan Weggeland, in his home area in Telemark, Norway.
description: In 1852 a woman is shown in her Norwegian folk costume. She is from the southern corner of Norway, the area of Tinn, part of the province of Telemark. Her local costume has a black wool skirt with decorative tape on the hem.Over the skirt is a dark blue silk apron with more trim on the bottom edge, which typically continues a few inches up the apron sides. Above the tape may be a black velvet piping.  She wears a black bodice which has buttons up each side from waist to neckline. It could be wool or silk damask. Beneath it is a white linen blouse with long full sleeves gathered at cuffs. Around the neck Norwegians love to wear silk scarves, and hers is a small colorful one knotted under the chin. Below the knot is a large round Norwegian broach (shown in this book as Norwegian Jewelry). Little of her hair is seen because women often wore a silk scarf over their hair, almost like a turban.To secure it firmly, she was painted with a smaller rolled black silk scarf to tie it in place. Her green wool stockings are knitted in ribs, and flat, square-toed shoes have large silver buckles.
source: Published in holdings of the Museum of Church History and Art, this small watercolor is on paper 11  inches by 6 inches. In the book Images of Faith compiled by past leaders of the MCHAwith an erroneous caption about her place- specific folk clothing, The description written above is ethnically correct according to Carmas personal research in Tinn.

caption: Wealthy English child and their gardener
description: The gardener wears tough, roomy trousers supported by suspenders. The legs are rolled up over heavy boots, and he carries a small sledge hammer to break up the rocks beneath him. His shirt is checkered and covered by a scraggly beard. He has a leather cap and glasses.  The little boy of the manor house wears a fine Scottish kilt with a sporran and a tam o'shanter for walking about. He has argyle knee stockings and buckled shoes. His older brother wears short pants and dark stockings for school days, with a light jacket and a fine straw hat. He has flat oxfords, probably brown.
source: Possibly Margot Lister, Costumes of everyday life;?An illustrated history of working clothes,(London, Barrie & Jenkins, February 24, 1972)

caption: Welsh add-on sleeves.
description: No description
source: Drawn by Carma from Etherington.

caption: Welsh Cardiganshire betgwn (bedgown)
description: This betgwn ensemble is striped wool with a dark green apron in which she carries flowers. Her figured kerchief keeps her neck warm. A tall black felt hat fits neatly over a white daycap with tiny ruffles reaching to the end of the lappets. Black gloves extend from below the elbow to her knuckles.
source: Original in the National Gallery of Wales, modified by Ken Etheridge in Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century.

caption: Welsh clothing includes a multi-colored shawl named after Joseph's coat of many colors in the Bible.
description: Women going to market in South Wales, 1800s. Woman on right wears a "Joseph," a woolen wrap with fringe, striped in red, yellow, green, blue & black, for public occasions or church. The working woman on left has removed her tall hat to balance a basket of vegetables to market. She wears a cheery cross-barred dress with an apron of 2 more different colors. Her flowered shawl is likely yellow, and much favored. Welsh women in the 1800s wore fine wool stockings of white, black and darker colors, with stout, black, leather shoes. In the 1850s on , most Welsh LDS converts came from the South of Wales and thousands emigrated to America on well organized sailing ships. They brouht their talents and education and their wonderful music echoed from ship decks to the rolling waves and barren prairies. Few converts would have worn bright folk dress, which could be too costly, but wore reserved colors of British cites and work clothing of their home woven woolens and linens.
source: Ken Etheridge, Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century.(Swansea, Wales: Cristopher Davies, Ltd., 1977).

caption: Welsh gaiters of black wool with metal buttons and an under-strap.
description: Thomas Job cut off his gaiters across the top edge to be much shorter, without adding any finishing stitches. At the time he had no wife to sew for him. These gaiters had buckled straps under the arch of his shoes.
source: From the Thomas Job Trunk, Goshen, Utah.

caption: Welsh miners in brown wool and blue or grey clothes.
description: In the 1850s, most Welsh LDS converts came from the South of Wales , many from the mines. They joined with other British peoples for emigration to America from labors of Dan Jones, and other very effective missionaries. In making this momentous change they faced other new hardships but gained large and beautiful western lands where many farms were available and their musical talents were essential to all other converts from other countries to America.
source: Ken Etheridge, Welsh Costume in the 18th and 19th Century.(Swansea, Wales: Cristopher Davies, Ltd., 1977).

caption: Welsh wedding of 1866
description: Male and female attendants of the wedding couple (far left) are called "Shigouts. " The man with a harp can play simple songs without being seated.
